column2: Weston ended his second day's walking at 12:25 this morning, having completed sixty-two miles for the day, and 139 since the start.

TYRONE, Penn., May 20. A fire broke out at 11 o'clock this morning at the Moshannon Lumber Company's mill, west of Osceola. Fifteen million feet of lumber were burned and the wind was so strong that fire-brands two feet long were blown to all parts of the town of Osceola. Fires are breaking out at every point.

The second day of the session of the United States Centennial Commission found the members ready for work, and eager to proceed to business of vital importance to the success of the enterprise. Promptly at 11 o'clock A.M. the meeting was called to order by Gen. Hawley, at the Continental Hotel.

OSCEOLA, Penn., May 20. One of the most destructive forest fires that has ever occurred in this section of the country is now raging all around the top of the mountain near the summit of which the town of Osceola stood at 10 o'clock this morning. ALBANY, May 20. One of the most important bills relating to New-York City, and known as Controller Green's Taxation bill, was reported from a Conference Committee, and the report concurred in by both Houses to-day. This is one of the six bills introduced by Senator Booth, and known, collectively, as the Booth bills.

A meeting of dry-goods importers who desire to prevent smuggling will be held at the St. Nicholas Hotel this afternoon at 3 o'clock.

Rev. Joseph Wild, D.D., was yesterday installed Pastor of the Union Congregational Church of Brooklyn, which bas been formed by the union of the State Street and Elm Place Congregational Churches. They seem willing to agree to a treaty for the cession of the Black Hills country, but will hold out for the best...

Campbell's resolution in the Assembly, providing for a sweeping legislative investigation into the administration of justice in the City and County of New-York, was regarded with much interest yesterday. ALBANY, May 31.--The Legislature passed a bill to-day designed to give "a plaintiff" a standing in court in reference to an old claim of 1862 for services rendered the City of New-York by repairs made to the pavement of Broadway from Fourteenth street to the Battery.

Plymouth lecture-room was well filled last evening without being overcrowded. On the Pastor's table was a loose bouquet, in a gilded vase, consisting of dielytre, hyacinths, almond and quince blossoms, and smilax vines. Mr. and Mrs. Brecher were five minutes late. Brother Shearman gave Mrs. Beecher his seat, and took one on the platform, behind the Pastor.

The utmost indignation is felt and expressed, both by the students of Rutgers College and by the citizens of New-Brunswick, in consequence of the recent raid of the Princeton students, and their capture of twenty-eight muskets from the armory in the basement of the Geological Hall in Rutgers College. The daring act is freely characterized as burglary, and the failure of the Police to discover ...

The adventures of the few Americans who have married into royal families do not encourage republicans to seek entangling alliances of that sort. The career of "Prince PERKINS," as he is sometimes called, certainly ought to be a warning to such of our young folks as may pine for relationship by marriage with European Princes and potentates.

BOSTON, Mass., May 21.--The case of Abram Jackson was the theme of the street, to-day. The full extent of his irregularities cannot be ascertained, those having had transactions with him being exceedingly reticent. It is known, however, that there are at least $300,000 in losses. The deficiency in the funds of the Franklin Insurance Company amounts to $35,000, and another of $17,000 is ...

The desire to succeed, which is of itself an incentive to exertion, is active. It is counted both base and cowardly to abandon one's ...

The absorbing question of the local political world, as to the final adjournment of the Legislature, was decided to-day by the concurrence of the two houses, in a resolution fixing the dispersion of "the statesmen" to take place at noon to-morrow. There was no debate or discusion in either body on the subject.

The question where to go this Summer is now under discussion in a great many families. One of the points which it is often considered necessary to settle in order to the solution of this problem is the inquiry who is or is not going to this or that particular place. This point is certainly not an unimportant one. A great deal of the comfort-- or as a cyncially-disposed individual might ...

WASHINGTON, May 21.--The Indians had a conference to-day with the Indian Commissioner, and made a number of complaints. Red Cloud and Spoted Tail demanded that a change be made in their present quarters, which was peremptorily refused, much to the chagrin of those chiefs. There are good reasons for refusing the request of Red Cloud and Spotted Tail.

The painful proceedings in the County Court, Chicago, on Wednesday, when an inquiry was made into the mental condition of the widow of President Lincoln, are reported in full in the papers of that city. The Tribune says that it has been genarally known in the circles of the lady's acquaintances and personal friends that something of this kind would eventually be necessary. The London newspapers of May 10 and 11 are filled with accounts of the loss of the Schiller. Although the outlines of the story have already appeared in THE TIMES, more minute details will, no doubt, be read with sad interest.

The Columbia Yacht Club have decided tohold their eighth annual regatta on Wednesday, June 23.

On Wednesday Judge Porter began to sum up for Mr. Beecher, and the speeches of counsel on that side and the other will occupy the remainder of this week and the whole of the next. On the following week we may look for a verdict.

The special order was the election of officers, which was proceeded with immediately after organization. Gen. An election for Second Lieutenant will be held in Battery K next Wednesday evening.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 22.--The Mill Operatives' Convention resumed its session at 8:30 this morning. Mr. Smith read a paper on the best means of establishing the ten-hour system throughout New-England. It advises the forming of unions, and urges all foreig-nborn operatives to become ...

A meeting of the stockholders of the Erie Railroad was held yesterday at Dolmonico's, Beaver street, for the purpose of taking into consideration the most effective means of relieving the company under its present embarrassment.

TYRONE, Penn., May 22. Reports were received here late last night that the fire was approaching the town of Phillipsburg, and in order to save the town from destruction the Burgess ordered that all the brush around the place should at once be set on fire, which was done at a late hour.

On Wednesday we were threatened with a financial crisis. I do not know how it came about, but at the races on Sunday, when all the members of high society were present, and among the rest the Orleans Princes, rumors of war began to circulate. Everyone asked what news had been received from Berlin.

The competitive examinations for the West Point Cadetships from the Tenth and Eleventh Districts were held yesterday morning and afternoon at the New-York City College. The Congressmen having the gifts at their disposal are B.A. Willis and Abram S. Hewitt.

The Spring meeting at Fleetwood Park terminated successfully yesterday. The attendance of spectators was large, and the interest greater than on the preceding days. The first race called was the postponed 2:24 purse, in which Vanity Fair had two heats to his credit, Tanner Boy two heats, Music two heats, and Mystic a dead heat.

WASHINGTON, May 22. The President this morning appointed Ferdinand Meyer to be Supervisor of Internal Revenue for the States of Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas, and Texas, and the Indian and New-Mexico Territories, vice McDonald, removed. He also signed the cemmission of Asa C. Matthews to be Supervisor of Internal Revenue for the States ...

About the middle of the seventeenth century Nicholas Zambelli, a citizen of Lucca, visited England on business, and, pleased with the country, settled there. His affairs propered, and by the time he was fifty years of age he had accumulated a handsome fortune, and felt a desire to end his days at Lucca, where a brother of his still resided. The ladies of Texas are endeavoring to collect money for the pupose of purchasing a home for Jefferson Davis in that State, and presenting it to him. His welcome seems to have been a very cordial and enthusiastic one. His speech to the veterans at Houston is very imperfectly reported in the State ...

At 12:40 o'clock to-day the Legislature of 1875 adjourned sine die, and the closing proceedings, in both Houses were marked by dignity, courtesy, and general good feeling. Nearly all the members took their departure for the City by the afternoon and evening trains, and next week the capital will have resolved into its conventional Midsummer drowsiness.

On the corner of Broadway and New-Jersey avenue, in East New York, stands a plain two-story frame house, in the centre of a pretty garden. It was built by a thrifty German tailor, John George Young, who went to that village and settled there more than fifteen years age. He married a Miss Reichert, and lived happily with her, earning good ...

The extraordinary sale of pews in the new church-edifice occupied by the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church deserves more than passing attention. The sale was extraordinary, because nothing like it was ever before seen in this City, and we doubt if Church history anywhere in this country affords a similar example of an enterprise of great magnitude so speedily carried forward to completion.

At Bow street, on May 8, application was made ofr a warrant to detain and bring up for examination three men, George Miller, William Smith, and John Clew, on the charge of murder and mutiny on the high seas.
The programme of the Cape may regatta promises some good sport. It is as follows:

We cannot better describe the representation of "The Lady of Lyons" at Wallack's Theatre, yesterday evening, than by the word respectable. It was neither very interesting nor very effective but all the parts were carefully filled; and if the audience was never startle it was certainly never shocked.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 22. The annual Spring regatta of the Cornell Navy took place on Cayuga Lake this morning. The weather was perfect and the water in splendid condition. Special trains were run on the Cayuga Lake Railroad. The programme for the races was carried out promptly and satisfactorily, and the large crowd in attendance heartily manifested their pleasure with the spirited contests and the admirable arrangements of the Directors of the Navy.

The following are the acceptances in the Fordham and Jockey Club Handicaps, and the Grand National Steeplechase Handicap, to be run at the Spring Meeting of the American Jockey Club: FORDHAM HANDICAP, ONE AND ONE-QUARTER MILES.

Nothing can be more surprising than the development of racing within the past ten years. Not only are ten times the number of horses trained, and at least ten times the amount of money given, but the interest of the public has certainly increased in a corresponding ratio. It may be a moot question whether the American Jockey Club should or should not be considered the cause of this.

There are three classes of non-conformists in society, the people who cannot dress or act like the rest of mankind, natural-born originals and eccentries, men and women whose minds are cut on an unusual pattern, people who must be odd, not always aggresive, but always alone ...

Under the act of the Legislature of 1855, amended and modified in 1865 and 1875, there will be an enumeration of the inhabitants throughout this State, beginning on June 1. The law requires the Secretary of State, Hon. Diedrich Willers, Jr., the present incumbent, to furnish each County Clerk with the requisite for blanks for each election district in the several counties.

The question relative to the position of Treasurer of the Police Department, upon which the Police Commissioners have been at issue since Gen. Smith became a member of the board, was definitely settled yesterday by the election of Commissioner Voorhis to that office.

The case, Robinson against Adams, in the last volume of Maine Reports, just published, is a very interesting commentary on the question whether a belief in what is popularly called Spiritualism is, in its legal aspect, an insane delusion.

Our London correspondent, in the letter which we published on Wednesday, states that the visit of the Prince of WALES to India is an event definitely determined on. As regards the wisdom of the experiment there is, as Sir Roger de'Coverley said of the picture, "a good deal to be said on both sides."
Frank Lowenburg, a boy residing in Division street, Albany, was drowned in the river yesterday.

Inspite of the backwardness of the season, the prospect for a large yield of fruit is very favorable. The fear that the frosts had destroyed the peach buds to such an extent as to put an end to the bright anticipations of the orchard men, has been dispelled by the good news that the frosts of April had but few buds to nip.

Yesterday was the seventh practice-day of the American team preparatory to the contest in the international match. All the members were present at an early hour, and at 11 A.M. commenced practicing at 800 yards distance.

Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Friday night, Patrick Kehoe and his wife Catherine were heard quarreling loudly in their apartments in the rear of No.354 Third street, Jersey City. Kehoe was heard to say with an oath that he would get rid of the woman before morning. The noise of a scuffle ensued and the sounds ceased with what seemed to be the heavy fall of a body to the floor.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 22. The Presbyterian General Assembly met again this morning. After devotional exercises and routine business, Rev. J.S. Noble, of New-Jersey, introduced the following resolutions, which were referred to a committee:

The last day's session of the Centennial Commission was one of great importance. From the Executive Committee it was announced that Mr. Daniel J. Morrell had been chosen Chairman, and Mr. A.T. Goshorn had been re-elected Director General.

A case has been decided in the English courts which very clearly defines the limits where the functions of trades-unions cease. In effect, it exactly coincides with the views we have frequently expressed in these columns; but hitherto no legal decision upon the precise point at issue has been reached, and thus the judgment becomes of the atmost importance as a precedent for the guidance of working men.

Rev. Dr. Heber Newton, Rector of the Anthon Memorial Church, preached yesterday the fifth of his course of sermons on the subject of "Science and Religion." He considered, in the first instance, the foundations of the position on which religion rests, with the view of ascertaining whether science by its burrowings of inquiry has undermined or in any way endangered them.

The political situation in New-Hampshire has within a week assumed a serious aspect. No thoughtful man can look forward to the meeting of the Legislature in June without apprehension of events such as were never known in this State. The nature of the case predicts that there will be trouble.
Mr. Rubinstein has been giving piano recitals at the Salte Evard in Paris. Mr. Hallirgshead announces performances at the London Gaiety by Signor Rossi, Signor Salvini's rival.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--There is an musual amount of log-rolling and quiet caucusing by the various parties directly interested in the Sioux Indians now here. First, there is the party of interpreters and traders who accompanied the Indians 'at their own private expense,' as they boastingly give out. This party embraces the "squaw-men," and has the confidence of the Indians. No one believes they came here "at their own private expense," ...

The work of drafting Mr. Lick's revised trust deed in accordance with his latest views regarding the disposition of his immense property is completed, and all that remains to do before placing the instrument on file is to obtain from certain beneficiaries under the former deed their consent to the terms of the revised instrument, and to settle the suit commenced by the Trustees named in the former deed to free themselves from the trust.
Dr. Saville, the agent of Red Cloud's band, who is now here with the Sioux delegation, makes this explanation touching the charges of Red Cloud, preferred through Prof. Marsh.

The opponents of civil service reform made the competitive examination system the chief objective point of their attacks. The statesmen who praised our civil service as the best on the planet recurred with evernew delight to criticisms upon the questions proposed to applicants for office. A great many funny stories vere told at the expense of the examiners.

There was decided in the United States Supreme Court the other day a case which may be properly called historic. It is known as the Broderick will case. It confirms the validity of the last will and testament of DAVID C. BRODERICK, once a Senator of the United States. The decision must recall to the minds of some of our older readers one of the most singular tragedies known in American politics.

The first event on the programme of the Spring games of the Olympic Club, which were held on the quarter mile track at Ridgewood, N.J., was a hundred yards race, in which Bennett Greig, Maurice E. Burnton and Richard A. Pennell started, out of seven entries.

A fire occurred yesterday afternoon in the paint and oil store of Messrs. J.W. Hunnewell Co., on Commercial street, Boston. The flames burned briskly, and the firemen had great difficulty in preventing them from spreading. The losses amount to $45,000. Hunnewell Co. lose $25,000. They have insurance to the amount of $20,000, of which $11,000 is in Boston offices, and the remainder in New-York and Pennsylvania offices.

WASHINGTON, June 30. The Postmaster General has been interviewed upon the results of his late tour of inspection, and is apparently much gratified with his trip, and what he has seen and learned. He states that he met some 500 or 600 Postmasters, besides 200 or 300 other Post Office employes, and expresses himself as pleased with their general appearance.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., June 30. The United States steamer Lancaster, Capt. Francis A. Roe commanding, arrived here on Friday last, thirtyfive days from Bahia, having left Rio Janeiro on the 22d of April, homeward bound, with all on board well.

The legislative committee appointed to inquire into crime and its causes in this City reassembled at the City Hall yesterday. All the members were present Messrs. T.C. Campbell, Hustod, Dessar, Hess, and McGowan. There were besides several citizens interested in the revelations being made.

John Van Hasset, a laborer, residing at Blissville, while digging a grave in Calvary Cemetery yesterday was instantly Killed by the caving in of the earth. After some difficulty he was extricated, when life was found extinct, his neck being broken.

HAZLETON, Penn., June 30. The starting of A. Pardee Co.'s Laurel Hill Breaker on Monday was attended with no forcible opposition on the part of the Miners' Union, and the example of those men who went into the mines on that day has so encouraged many others as to overcome all timidity on their part, and induces them to signify their willingness to go to work.

BOSTON, June 30. A more successful Commencement Day at Harvard has not been witnessed for many a year. Some of the old customs were revived, and a much larger number of the Alumni than usual were present.

Capt. Alfred F. Puffer, Deputy Collector of Customs, died suddenly at his residence in West Twenty-fourth street, yesterday morning, of apoplexy, caused, it is thought, by imprudently taking a bath while in a heated condition. Upon leaving his desk in the Custom-house on Wednesday afternoon he walked home, and, shortly after his arrival, feeling very warm, he retired to take a bath.

CONCORD, N.H., July 1. In the House today the resignations were received of Ivory Varney, Republican, from Dover, and C.I. Hillsgrow, Democrat, from London, on account of a dispute in the committee. An act was passed incorporating an association for building a monument at Dover Point, in commemoration of the first English settlement in New-Hampshire.

The enumerators employed in taking the new State Census in the Fourteenth Assembly District have made their returns of population. Mr. Charles A. Pavie, Chief Clerk of the Census Bureau under Marshal Sharpe in 1870 and 1871, who has been assisting ex-Alderman William Rielly, Census Adviser for the Fourteenth Assembly District, has made a comparison of the returns of the district with those of Marshal Sharpe's census takers in June, 1870, and corrected in 1871.

WASHINGTON, July 1. Secretary Bristow's efforts to break up the fraudulent and unlawful transactions of the whisky ring will not have been completely successful till the courts shall have done their duty, which will be pressed on them as rapidly as possible. The results already reached are, however, exceedingly important, and they show, when collected together, the immensity of the combination of capital and ingenuity employed in the work of cheating the Government.

DUBLIN, July 1. The shooting for the Abercorn Cup began to-day at Dollymount. The American riflemen participated. The match was not finished and will be continued to-morrow. The best scores were made by Pollock and Wilson, of the Irishmen, and Fulton and Gildersleeve, of the Americans.

Well, I am reminded by what is going on around me of that piece of Liszt.

The second annual regatta of the Central Hudson Yacht Club took place over the twenty-mile course off this place to-day. The weather was all that could be desired, a fresh westerly breeze prevailing. The race was set down for 12 M., and for hours previous the scenes around the piers and along the shores for mile were of an enlivening character.

BOSTON, July 1. Commencement week at Cambridge closed to-day with the annual exercises of the famous Phi Beta Kappa Society, Alpha of Massachusetts. This is July 1, 1875. On the first day of July, 1840, the first "money" article appeared in the Public Ledger as a department of the paper. The same individual that pens this paragraph prepared that first article, and in all the thirty-five years intervening the two dates named, this particular department of the Ledger has been in his special charge and daily contributed to by him.

The Commencement and Semi-centennial of the foundation of the University of Virginia, by Thomas Jefferson, has been going on for the past few days. A large number of the Alumni are in attendance, and many distinguished gentlemen present from all parts of the Union.

An important seizure of diamond jewelry was made yesterday by Capt. Charles N. Brackett, Special Agent of the Custom-house, associated with Col. Frank E. Howe. Some days ago it was reported to Capt. Brackett that a German had been offering to sell a lot of diamond jewelry in Maiden lane and John street at prices that led to the belief that it had been smuggled.

To-day is known at Yale as "Presentation Day." It is so called because the instructors of the Academical Department, having carried the graduating class through the whole curriculum, now "present" those who have passed the requisite examinations to the "corporation" of the university, as deserving of the degree of Bachelor of Arts.

Senators Anthony and Burnside, Col. Lippitt, and others made brief speeches, and the occasion passed very pleasantly.

The usual committees were appointed, and the convention took a recess. Permanent organization was effected, with ex-Gov. James T. Lewis for President. The following ticket was nominated:
PARIS, July 7. In the Assembly to-day the Public Powers bill was debated. M. Marcou, a Radical, moved an amendment in favor of making future Assemblies permanent.

Mr. Charles Francis Adams delivered the following address to-day before a large audience, setting forth the present demands upon the colleges. He compared the oratory of the present with that of the ancients, the latter of which he concluded was the better fitted, especially from the brevity of the speeches, for the guide of modern students. The address is given in full below:

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 7. The residence of John Canniff, on Cherry street was struck by lightning last night. The family were in the house at the time, but no one was hurt. The damage to the house is about $200.
At the close of the Commencement exercises at Princeton College last week 130 students made application for admission, of whom 118 were successful.

The Springfield Republican believes that it has detected an error in the review of the evidence in the Beecher case which we published last Saturday. As thorough accuracy was one of the chief things aimed at in that article, we should be sorry to find that even the slightest mistake had been made.

A meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday, Mr. W.H. Neilson presiding. A report was submitted by the Superintendent of Truancy for the true elapsing between June 17 and July 2. It showed that was total number of cases investigated during that period was 1,155. Of this number, 337 had been kept from school by various minor causes, and there were 193 whose residences could not be found, leaving 623 truants and non-attendants.
A fire at Tulare City, Cal., on Monday afternoon destroyed the entire business portion of the town. The loss is $120,000.
The Yonkers Gas Company has advanced the price of gas to $3 per 1,000 feet.

BELFAST, July 7.--The contest for the Mayor's and Citizens' Cup was held on the range on Lord Dufferin's ground. The distance was 1,000 yards. Each man was allowed five shots, the highest possible score being twenty.

The second miniature yacht regatta of the season took place at Central Park yesterday afternoon. No less than 2,000 spectators were present to witness the sport, and the enthusiasm manifested by them, as well as by those who participated, was sufficient to prove that the experiment of miniature yachting is destined to be successful wherever it is introduced.
Among the callers upon Mayor Wickham yesterday was Mayor Fulton, of Galveston, Texas.

It is seriously proposed in Russia to investigate what is called the spiritualistic phenomena. It appears that the Imperial Society of Experimentalists in Physics, attached to the University of St. Petersburg, have appointed a committee for this purpose, and Mr. ALEXANDER AKSAKOFF, who signs himself "Counselor of State in the Imperial Chancellary of St. Petersburg," addresses an appeal to American "mediums," asking them to go over and be investigated. This looks like business.
The demolition of the Old Dutch Church in Fulton street was completed yesterday morning, and was attended with disastrous results to the adjoining building.

BRUNSWICK, Me., July 7. In connection with the Commencement ceremonies of Bowdoin College there was a reunion of the Class of 1825 last night. There were present Rev. Dr. Cheever, the poet Longfellow, John S.C. Abbott, Charles J. Abbott, of Castine; Hon. Horatio Bridge, of Washington; Prof. Nathaniel Dunn, Rev. David Shipley, D.D., of Providence, and Prof. Packard, who was tutor in 1825.

There was an immense audience assembled last evening at Tweddle Hall to witness the inter-academical contest between twenty-seven different contestants, representing fifteen academies and union schools. The Albany High School was the favored one, carrying off nearly all the first prizes.
The Commissioners of Rapid Transit intend to select temporary offices in the new Court-house, and it is probable that the meeting called for to-day will be held in one of the vacant court-rooms.

Imagine how breathless the interest with which we should have awaited each revelation of the marvelous instruments which science employs in the work of lunarian discovery, if our satellite had been inhabited, and we could have discovered something like our own human life? Unhappily any such imagination is out of the question.
There were 297 deaths for the week ending July 3.

Those who remained home from Monmouth Park yesterday, missed an unusually good day's sport. A slight sprinkle about the time of the third race was all that came from the threatening storm, while the heavy clouds completely shut out the fierce rays of the sun, and rendered the atmosphere at least bearable.

The village of Rockaway was almost free yesterday from traces of the fatal disaster of Monday last. In one house lay the body of young Mott; in another the fireman, Finn, was tenderly nursed by charitable hands, and along the track lay portions of the debris of the wrecked trains; but the excitement having no further food had died away and the little village resumed its wonted air of quiet.

The legislative committee appointed to investigate the causes of crime in this City resumed its sessions yesterday in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen.
The fifty-fourth annual report of the Mercantile Library Association has just been issued, and it contains a number of facts which will be interesting to the public.

The sale of the Marlborough gems, announced for Monday next, affords a favorable opportunity for the study of a collection that has been famous for nearly a century. Apart from the beauty of individual examples of antique or of modern workmanship, the collection is interesting as containing in itself a record of the rise and progress of English connoisseurship.

the correspondent of the Manchester Examiner and Times says: "The debate on the Public Safety law in Sicily is likely to be long remembered, not only for itself but for its consequences. Mrs. M. Hathaway, of Everett, Mass., died yesterday of an overdose of chloral.
The men who are trying to make the "Independent Voter" an important figure in political life may depend confidently upon the New-York Tribune to render them and their cause ridiculous.

An exciting game of base-ball was played on the Union Grounds, in Brooklyn, E.D., yesterday afternoon, between the Atlantics, of Brooklyn, and the Olympics, of Manhattanville. It was very closely contested, and twelve innings were played before it was won by either club.

If the current of the regatta programme runs smooth, if the Freshman crews' race is rowed on Tuesday, and the University crews get through their great contest on Wednesday, then the running and walking races will take place on Thursday at Glen Mitchell.

The Board of Aldermen held a long and exciting session yesterday, during which an attempt was made to pass a resolution appropriating the sum of $500,000 to Commissioner Fitz John Porter to lay new Croton mains and increase the supply of water in this City. The effort, however, was unsuccessful. Nearly all the members were present at the appointed hour, and a good deal of ordinary business was then transacted.

OTTAWA, July 8. The members of the Agricultural and Art Association are in session here, arranging for the coming provincial exhibition. The cities of Kingston and Hamilton are making efforts to be represented at the Centennial.

Chancellor Pruyn last evening formally conferred the degree of M. D. upon Edward William Victor and Howard Lansing Walds, in behalf of the University of the State of New-York. They also received the Grey prize from the hand of Secretary Woolworth.
Philip Maxiemus, an Italian, died in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken, yesterday, from the effects of sun-stroke.

MADRID, July 8. The Alfonsist General, Arrando, has, after a five hours' engagement, defeated nine Carlist battalions, under command of Sabals, and relieved the town of La Junquera, in the Province of Gerona. The loss on both sides was considerable.

The badge presented by the National Guard of Virginia City, State of Nevada, to the New-York National Guard, to be shot for by the latter with military rifles at 200 and 500 yards ranges, has been received at the office of the Army and Navy Journal.

The celebration of the natal day of the Republic in Memphis, Tenn., was marked by some extraordinary scenes, not least remarkable of which was the gathering of negro societes and clubs who had specially invited Gens. N.B. Forrest and Gideon J. Pillow and other former Confederates to address them.

Yesterday the first meeting of the NewJersey Jockey Club of 1875 ended in a blaze of glory. The racing throughout has been exceptionally good, and yesterday's was not behind that of either of the three previous days. The bright skies drew a very fair attendance to the course both from this City and from the surrounding watering places.

The Rapid-transit Commissioners held a private session in the Mayor's private office yesterday. After the meeting Col. Harrison, the Mayor's secretary, and also acting secretary to the commission, said that all the Commissioners were present at noon, and organized by electing Mr. Seligman permanent Chairman and Col. Harrison acting Secretary.

Rumors of an irregularity involving a large amount prevailed in Wall street yesterday causing considerable excitement, which was not allayed until late in the afternoon, when the facts in the case became known.
Selina Anderson, aged forty-eight, fell out of a second-story window of her residence, No. 325 East One Hundred and Thirteenth street, and sustained serious injuries.
Mr. Carl Rosa has engaged Mlle. Ostava Torriani to sing in English opera.

The inquest on the bodies of the victims of the railroad collision at Far Rockaway on last Monday, was begun yesterday in the Atlantic Hotel of that village by Mr. Hicks, Coroner of Kings County. Contrary to general expectation, the proceedings attracted but comparatively little interest, and of those in attendance the majority were officers and employes of the Southern Railroad.

BELFAST, July, 9 A farewell banquet was given to the American Team this afternoon. Mr. Robert Thompson, a prominent merchant, presided, and made a speech wishing the Americans every success.

The Allgemeins Zeitung states that the chair of Chemistry at the University of Munich, vacant since the death of Liebig, has been accepted by Prof. Baeyer of Strasburg.

BELFAST, July, 9--Col. Gildersleeve to-day received letters from the Secretary of the National Rifle Association, inviting the Americans to shoot on the 17th inst., at Wimbledon, against a team of eight picked from the United Kingdom, the range to be 1,000 yards, and each man to have thirty shots.

Mark Brown was hanged at Monticello, Sullivan County, yesterday, for the murder of Sylvester Carr, in the Village of Purvis, in that county, on the 3d of October last. Brown was a laborer in the lumber regions of that section, and lived at Purvis. He was very intemperate, and when intoxicated inclined to be quarrelsome.

CINCINNATI, July, 9. A dispatch to J.H. Rhodes, Superintendent of Adams Express Company, states that a desperate attempt to rob Express Messenger Burke was made at Long Point, Ill., on the Vanadalia Railroad, last night. The engine and the car were cut loose and the engineer killed. Burke barricaded the doors and kept the robbers at bay until help arrived.

In the suit brought by Israel J. Solomon, a pew-owner in the synagogue of the Jewish Congregation B'Nai Jeshurun, in which an injunction was sought to restrain the Trustees from making certain alleged innovations in the mode of worship, , a decision was rendered by Judge Larremore, of the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, adverse to the plaintiff.

The array of empty seats in Plymouth Church yesterday morning testified to the absence of Mr. Beecher in the country. The only persons of any prominence present were Rev. Edward Beecher, Mr. Bullard, Mrs. Beecher's brother, and United States District Attorney Tenney.
Mr. Fechter acts in Rochester to-morrow evening.

It has always been maintained that the system of municipal representation in Connecticut, by which the House of Representatives has a large membership, has been a preventive of corruption, and has secured in the main honest legislation; and the claim has not been made without good reason.

Addresses were delivered last evening at the Forty-third Street Methodist Episcopal Church by Rev. Dr. Weekly, of Grace Church, and Rev. Dr. Willis, Pastor of the Seventh Street Methodist Episcopal Church, upon the work of City evangelization in New-York.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 11. Cape May is all activity, and the promise of a successful regatta grows stronger every hour. Every train brings hundreds of visitors, and each day's arrivals cover pages of the hotel registers. The scene to-day has been wonderfully brilliant and animated.

The Freshman race, on Tuesday, at Saratoga, will be a bright prelude to the grand struggle of the next day, in which thirteen crews will participate. The men are now all on the spot, and some of them have been in training there long enough to make them familiar with the water and all of the points about a race-course, which are so little to the spectator and so much to the rowers.

Writing from Levuka on April 23, an occasioinal correspondent of the London Times says: The result of the visit of his ex-Majesty King Cakobau to New South Wales forms an awful era in the history of Fiji. In the native mind it has dimmed the lustre which surrounded annexation, and it has filled the chiefs and people with consternation and dismay.

This, Saturday, was the last day of training which the crews can get, and most unfortunately the water was rough. Only three boats were out during the four hours that I passed on the lake and the shore inspecting the grand stand. These were the Williams, the Yale, and the Dartmouth crews. The two former slipped through the narrow passages of the bridge and got into the smooth water on the other side.

LONDON, July 11. Messrs. Moody and Sankey held their closing meetings to-day. The attendance was enormous. Many persons were on their way to Camberwell as early as 5 o'clock this morning. Thousands were unable to obtain admission to the evening services.

Coroner Hicks will to-day resume his investigation of the causes leading to the disaster on the Rockaway branch of the Southern Railroad on Monday of last week.

The St. Louis (Brown Stockings) Club are making their first visit to this City, and yesterday afternoon they played the first game of the championship series with the Atlantic Club, of Brooklyn, on the Union Grounds, in Brooklyn, E.D. About 500 persons had gathered on the grounds, and the game was called at 3:55 P.M., the Atlantics going first to the bat.

LONDON, July 12.--Messrs. Moody and Sankey's farewell meeting took place at Mildmay's Hall to-night. The Earls of Shaftesbury and Cavan, Samuel Morley, M.P., Right Hon. Cowper Temple, Mr. McArthur, and 700 clergymen were present.

WASHINGTON, July 12. A letter has been received from McGrew saving he has made no charges against Chief Clerk Holt, of the Internal Revenue Bureau, in connection with the whisky frauds. No information whatever has reached the department to-day from any quarter on that subject.

In his "Report on the Hygiene of the United States Army," to which attention has already been called, Assistant Surgeon John S. Billings deals at some length with the subject of clothing for the Army. Within the last three years great improvements have been made in this direction, both in pattern and material.

At 2:20 P.M. yesterday the telegraph at Sandy Hook reported the schooner Mary Chilton, C.P. Marsden master, from Pinar del Rio, in the offing, with cargo consigned to D. De Castro Co. Soon after the vessel entered the harbor in tow of a tugboat, and wasanchored in the stream.

My last letter, written an hour or two after the match, told you a little something of the general feeling of the people concerning the result. Since then we have had two days, during which the defeat of the Irish has been the theme of town and country.

In Brooklyn the census enumerators have completed only a few of the wards of the city. In the First, Sixth, Eighth, Ninth, Tenth, Fifteenth, Nineteenth, Twenty-second, and Twenty-third Wards the total population is 164,244.

An exploit was performed yesterday in a house in West Eleventh street which has rarely been paralleled in the annals of crime for boldness of aesign and success in operation. In broad daylight the three-story and basement brown-stonefront residence, known as No. 50 West Eleventh street, and occupied by Mr. Matthias Danser, was entered by a band of robbers.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. A private letter received here to-day reports an outbreak of hostilities on the part of the Hoopa Indians, on Klamath River. They shot and killed Raymond Carpenter, of the Florence Mine, and then surrounding the mine, compelled the men to quit work. Word was sent to Camp Gaston, and a detachment of soldiers dispatched to the mine.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. The Australian Steam Navigation Company's steam-ship McGregor, from Sydney, via Auckland and Honolulu, arrived here to-day.

An inquest was held in New-Haven, Conn., on Saturday, to inquire into the death of Mrs. Michael Ready, who was shot and instantly killed, at a late hour Friday night, at the house of Mrs. William Brennan, by Edwin Hosmer. After a physician and a Police officer had testified, Hosmer gave his version of the matter, in substance as follows:

Persons who lost friends or relatives by the wreck of the Schiller will find but little consolation in the knowledge that, after careful inquiry, a competent tribunal has thrown the entire responsibility for that disaster upon the Captain of the ship. Neither is it likely that the German Government will accept, even if it rests satisfied with, this decision in a foreign court which reflects upon the competency of a German officer.

The second meeting of the New-Jersey Jockey Club at Monmouth Park, which was begun auspiciously on Saturday last, will be continued to-day. The programme presented is of unusual excellence, being composed of races in dashes, heats, and over the hurdles, with a sufficient number of horses in each to make them interesting.
The Directors of the Cheap Transportation Association will meet at 3 P.M. to-day.

The peach growers of Delaware and Maryland are making stupendous efforts to secure a wide market for the sale of their crop this season, and semi-weekly meetings of the growers are held at Middletown, Del. the centre of the great peach-growing section to arrange with the various railroad companies east of the Alleghanies for special facilities to ship direct without change of cars, and on schedule time to the various principal cities and towns.

The Freshman race is set for to-morrow at 11:30 A.M., but I am somewhat afraid that it will not come off quite so early. The weatherwise are prophesying considerable wind, and the indications are that such will prove to be the case. Of course, none of the Freshman crews are upon the lake, for the men invariably rest upon the day before the, to them, all-important race.
A movement is on foot to establish a female college at Columbus, Ga., by private subscription.

A correspondent, who signs himself "Merchant," writes us a letter which we publish this morning, strongly urging on the Government the policy of preparing for resumption by funding its legal-tender notes.

The coming regatta is naturally the event of the season most discussed here at this moment, and it is drawing people from every quarter. Still it must be admitted that the fervor of anticipation does not make itself so apparent this year as it did last not that the interest felt in the fortunes of the contesting crews is a whit less now than it was in 1874.

Taking the two seasons together Nebraska has suffered more from the grasshoppers than any of her sister States that have been afflicted. Last season her fertile fields were the first prey of these insects in their southern flight, and this year they have been the feeding-places of the hordes that hatched in Lower Kansas and Missouri, and are passing over to their proper dwelling-place upon the alkaline lands of the North-west.

Our attention has been called to the following passage in the Review of the evidence in the Beecher case which we published on the 3d instant, in reference to Mrs. Bradshaw: "She declares that Mrs. Tilton admitted the adultery to her, and said if the charge was ever made publicly she would 'sacrifice her husband and deny everything.'

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 12. Last night the now notorious Corbin saloon building at Westerville was discovered to be on fire, but before it was fairly under way the flames were extinguished. It is said some unknown parties entered the building, and placing a lot of rubbish in an inner room, piled all the bottled liquor on it, and then set it on fire.

The physicians and visitors engaged in the sick relief work of the Children's Aid Society report that sickness and destitution prevail to a great extent in the crowded portions of the City. In addition to the large number of accidents for which men are immediately responsible, this year will be memorable for its great disasters by flood and earthquake. There have been destructive inundations in many portions of Europe, and terrestrial disturbances in Asia and South America have been more frightful and wide-spread than any known in late years.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 13. The Cotton States Congress was called to order this morning in Commons Hall, by D.E. Butler, President. Fifty delegates were present, representing Georgia, South Carolina, Tennessee, Arkansas, and North Carolina.
The Marquis and Marquise De Bassano are in Quebec. Mrs. Winchester, of Peabody, Mass., fell from a window yesterday morning and broke her neck.
There is a balance in the City Treasury of $322,014.01, deposited in twelve city banks. Dudley Bulger, who was run over on Atlantic avenue on Monday, died yesterday in the City Hospital.

CAPE MAY, July 13. If everything militated against the regatta yesterday, everything favored it to-day. Yesterday it was sombre, dull, stagnant. To-day it was clear sunshine, with sparkling waves and a breeze that was a perfect balm to the heart of a yachtsman. In the morning the wind was southwest, very light, as it nearly always is in the early hours of the day, but it gave good promise.

The late trains last night and the early ones this morning brought up immense crowds, and Saratoga began to put on a gala appearance. The attendance, however, was not nearly so great as last year. The morning broke with a cloudless sky and with just the faintest whisper of a breeze. Disheveled heads peering out of chamber windows pronounced the prospect "lovely," and contentment reigned over the matutinal toilet.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 16. The House today, in that true spirit of reform which has so far characterized the great uprising of the Democratic Party in this State, voted to indefinitely postpone a bill prohibiting members of the Legislature and State officers from accepting free railroad passes. WASHINGTON, July 17.--The reports of the existence of yellow at Norfolk have been investigated to-day, and to all inquiries answers come that there are no cases. AS to the general will, which people pretend to discover by universal suffrage, it belonge to the same category as the philosopher's stone. Of what will do they speak? To-day, the masses wish a man or a government, because they expect what is impossible; and to-morrow, when they see that they have not obtained the impossible satisfaction of all their desires, they wish the contrary of what they wished the night before.

The story of Punch is the story of a literary period in English history. It is concerned with the lives and works of the leading wits, humorists, essayists, novelists, and statesmen of the Victorian era. Punch may be said to have introduced to the world the best compositions of Douglas Jerrold, Tom Hood, Albert Smith, Stirling Coyne, Thackeray, Shirley Brooks, and F.C. Burnand. It has made Doyle, Leech, Keene,Du Maurier, and Bennett famous.

A remarkable case of catalepsy has lately occurred in one of the principal hospitals of Paris. Professional men found it a rare subject for attention and study. The closest examination was allowed, and every witness was afforded an opportunity to apply his own means of verification. The phenomonon is not one of those which are often shrouded in the clouds of the supernatural, but simply a pathological fact of purely scientific interest.

The Chi nese divide the day into twelve shih-chen, or periods of two hours each, which are called by the characters of the Ti-chih, or terrestrial branches, (these characters are often spoken of as the horary characters.) Thus 11 P.M. to 1 A.M. is tsze; 1 A.M. to 3 A.M. is chou, and so on.

John Hill, and others. All the morning trains passing from both directions into Newark were filled to overflowing with crowds going either to participate in or to witness the display.

Last Fall Custom-house Inspector Andrew McCort found a lot of brandy in the possession of Thomas Jones, a bung-starter in the employ of Constantine Schnerr, a Custom-house Gauger, and seized it on suspicion of its having been stolen from cases on which Jones had been at work.

No. 52. October Term, 1874. The Equitable Safety Insurance Company, appellant, vs. George Hearne. Appeal from the Circuit for the District of Massachusetts. Mr. Justice Swayne delivered the opinion of the court.
LONDON, July 21. The action of the mill operatives in Oldham, yesterday, will result in a general lock-out.

George Templeton Strong, the Controller of the Corporation of Trinity Church, and an honored and prominent citizen, died at 5 o'clock yesterday morning at his residence, No. 113 East Twenty-first street.

The cooler weather does not perceptibly diminish the number of poor mothers, with suffering little ones, who daily apply for aid at the Sick Relief Bureau of the Children's Aid Society at No. 327 Rivington street. Early in the morning and late at night they unfold their tales of suffering and want.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 21. The Democratic State Convention organized at noon to-day at the Maryland Institute, Hon. Stevenson Archer, temporary Chairman, and from that hour until a little after 4 o'clock P.M. an animated and excited discussion ensued, participated in almost entirely by the friends of Mr. Hamilton on the appointment of the Committee on Credentials, a motion having been made by them ...

The new Post Office building is fast approaching completion, and the United States Circuit and District Courts have begun to remove from their old quarters in Chambers street to their spacious chambers in the new building, the majority of the latter being upon the third floor.
Walking has of late been a favorite diversion here for both sexes, and the growing popularity of the exercise gave rise to a remarkable amateur race this morning.
Judge Emmons, of the United States District Court, has lately delivered an opinion at Detroit, Mich., in an important case affecting the bankrupt Lake Superior Ship Canal, Railroad, and Iron Company.

There were 359 deaths in Brooklyn during the week ending July 17. The writing up of the tax-rolls of 1875 was finished yesterday, and the rolls transferred to the Clerk of Supervisors for completion. Justice Riley administered the usual oath to the Assessors.

The experiment of introducing the sport of miniature yachting at Central Park may now be set down as entirely successful, and the third regatta of the season took place there yesterday, when the interest manifested amounted to intense excitement.

Mr. JESSE JAMES thinks it high time that this cruel war were over. Pursued as he is by a bloodthirsty radical press, he addresses a letter to a Nashville newspaper asking in terms of great bitterness why the bloody chasm is not closed.

The New-York Mutual Gas-light Company made a contract in April, 1873, with the Park Commissioners, to light Central Park at the rate of $36.50 for each lamp, and upon this contract brought a suit against the City to recover $2,865.12, a balance alleged to be due them for such service. The total tax levied in the village of Tarrytown for corporation purposes last year was $14,958, of which over $3,000 remains unpaid.

Thomas Gooch and Patrick Oates, two boys, were yesterday found on the Boulevard by Officer Burke, of the Thirty-first Precinct, with a horse and harness in their possession, which they were offering for sale for a sum far beneath the value of the property. They were arrested and taken before Justice Flammer, at the Harlem Police Court, who committed them to await the appearance of the owner.

The grain excitement was at its highest yesterday in the local market. The news from all quarters favored activity and buoyancy. Weather and market reports from Europe were decidedly encouraging to operators, and the Western markets went all higher and very active.

Twenty-three years ago, Jeremiah Perce, a grocer in Providence, eloped with the wife of one of his tenants, leaving his own wife and two children. The woman was Mrs. Thomas M. Harrington, and she was the mother of three children, two girls and a boy.

Although new in its present form to American readers this book is not, strictly speaking, a new one. It is necessary to state this, because, treating, as the author does, chiefly of Don Carlos and his cause, the reader must be reminded that his observations were made some time ago.

The steam-ship Algeria took out yesterday 17,872 letters and twenty-six bags of newspapers. The apartments of George Leonard, on the first floor No. 342 Second avenue, were entered by sneak thieves on Tuesday afternoon and robbed of jewelry valued at $94.

A gentleman residing in this city had occasion a few days since to take a journey down the river and several miles back from it, using a saddle-horse. Darkness overtook him in a sparsely-settled district, and as the roads were in a bad condition and the evening looked threatening, he halted before a forlorn-looking hut and asked if he could find lodging.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 21.--The second day of the soldiers' encampment was a great success. Several thousand old soldiers were present. In the morning a meeting of Andersonville and other prisoners was held, some 600 being present, and a permanent organization was formed, with Capt. V. B. Chamberlain, of New-Britain, as President, and Ira E. Forbes, of Hartford, Secretary. Many interesting addresses were made.
About 12 o'clock on Tuesday night a woman of about twenty-eight years of age, shabbily dressed, but of a refined and delicate appearance, was taken into the Fourth Precinct station by a patrolman.

LONDON, July 21. In the Presbyterian Council to-day the constitution of the future union was discussed. The American delegates favored the formation of a confederation, but a large majority of the Council preferred the title and form of an alliance, as less restricted in scope, and it was ultimately agreed that an alliance of all the Reformed Presbyterian Churches of the world should be formed.
The Red Cloud Investigating Commission concluded their labors in this City for the present yesterday afternoon, and will leave the Fifth Avenue Hotel for the West this evening.
At the regular meeting of the Commissioners of the Department of Docks, yesterday, President Wales offered the following resolution, which was adopted:

At 10 o'clock the convention was called to order and President Hall, in pursuance of the resolution passed yesterday, requested the delegates to select Vice Presidents from each State and Territory represented.

Mary A. McGovern, aged fifteen, and employed by Mrs. Bertha Fernandez, No. 989 Broadway, was yesterday held in $1,000 bail by Justice Kasmire, at the Washington Place Police Court, charged with stealing twenty-one yards of silk, worth $60, from her employer.

The heaviest rain of the season fell at Nashville, Tenn., yesterday. Nearly two inches fell between 1 and 2 o'clock P.M.

To-morrow the long-talked of swimming match for the championship of the world and a stake of $2,000, between J.B. Johnson, the English swimmer, and a man who is wholly unknown to the aquatic and sporting world, Mr. Thomas Coyle, of Chester, Penn., will take place.

Notice of an appeal by the people to the General Term of the Supreme Court from the decision of Justice Donohue in favor of William M. Tweed in the $6,000,000 civil suit was served upon Messrs. Field Deyo, the defendant's lawyers yesterday, and was duly acknowledged by them.

LONDON, July 21.--Alexander and William Collie, of the firm recently suspended, were arraigned at Guildhall to-day on a charge of obtaining large sums of money from the London and Westminster Bank on false pretenses. The

CHICAGO, July 21. This was the second day of the second July meeting at Dexter Park. The first race was for the 2:34 class; $1,500 premium, divided among four horses. Eight horses started. Young Magna won the race, Frank Reeves second, Anglo Saxon third, and Kitty Stratton fourth.

Sit down on the porch, children, and let me tell you about Aunt Rachel, and the story she once told me. One day, when I was about twelve years old, I had planned to go after strawberries, but Aunt Rachel said to me: "A girl of your age should begin to learn how to do house-work. Take off your hat, roll up your sleeves, and help me do the baking."

The Court of General Sessions, having concluded the business before it, yesterday adjourned for the term.

In the suit of Philip C. Cummings against William B. Timberman, an application was made to compel the latter to apply $49 due him from his customers for milk in part payment of a judgment against him by Cummings. The San Francisco Alta has tidings from the Navigators' Islands to May 10, from which it appears that the flag of the United States was hoisted at Samoa on the 22d of April, and preparations were at once made for the adoption of a Constitution and the choice of a legitmate ruler in lieu of the twoheaded Government hitherto prevailing.

WASHINGTON, July, 21. The President unexpectedly arrived in Washington this morning and at noon a meeting of the Cabinet was held at the Executive Office. All the members were present except Secretary Belknap, who is gone West.

Early yesterday morning a fire broke out in a two-and-a-half-story frame building on West Hannah street, Tompkinsville, Staten Island, owned and occupied by Mary Yates, which was entirely con sumed, together with the adjoining house, owned by Oliver Taylor.

The Washington Chronicle says that the original draft of the appended letter from ex-Senator D.L. Yulee to Joseph Finigan, Secretary of the Secession Committee of Seventy, and the resolutions inclosed, are flow in its possesion: PRIVATE.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 21. The session of the State Committee of the Liberals here has drawn the leading members of the Liberal Party to Saratoga, and so far as can be judged from their individual expressions, the disposition is to reunite with the Republicans.
Joseph Doyle, the murderer of Philip Sheridan, was yesterday taken to State Prison to serve out his term of twenty years.

ALBANY, July 21.--Accountant Warren, of New-York, who has been examining the State Treasury at the request of Treasurer Raines, has just completed that work, and reports having found everything all right. The amount of money on hand and on deposit in about 100 different banks on the 30th June last, was 87,521,108 03. The books

Bids were opened yesterday at the office of the Improvement Commissioners of Long Island City for the erection of a bridge over the track of the Flushing, North Side, Central, and Long Island. Railroads, at the crossings of West Central, Jackson, and Borden avenues, in Hunter's Point. Messrs. J. H. Rooney, of Paterson, N.J., were the lowest bidders. The contract will be awarded today.

GREEN-BRIAR WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, West Va., July 21. The National Cotton Exchange Convention met this morning at 10 o'clock. The President, John Phelps, of New-Orleans, occupied the chair. John S. Toof, the Secretary, was present, assisted by A.G. Mills, of Galveston.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 22. The difficulty between Messrs. McGrath and Wilkes has assumed greater proportions than was anticipated. The simple charge of assault and battery preferred by the latter against the former, growing out of the fracas that occurred on the 21st, will be settled tomorrow, but Mr. McGrath has sued Mr. Wilkes to...

LONDON, July 22. The attendance at the Wimbledon meeting to-day was small at first. The ranges in the Elcho Shield contest were 800, 900, and 1,000 yards. The possible team score at each range was 600 points. At the 800yard range the English eight scored 515, the Irishmen 502, and the Scotchmen 498.

LONDON, July 22.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Disraeli announced that the Government had abandoned the Merchant Shipping bill for this session. He expressed the hope that the session would be closed by the 10th or 12th of August, or possibly at an earlier date.

The examination of the Police Captains by the Assembly Committee on Crime was continued yesterday in the rooms of the Board of Aldermen, at the City Hall, Messrs. T. Cooper Campbell, Hess, McGowan, and Dessar, of the committee, were present, and the direct examination was conducted by Mr. Aube, in the absence of Mr. John D. Townsend.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 22.--This was the third day of the Second July Meeting at Dexter Park. The attendance was large, the weather rainy, and the track very heavy.
This season of the year is a time in which there is not only a great deal of travel, but also a marked variety in the objects that people seek to accomplish by their journeys.

The sixth annual regatta of the Manhattan Yacht Club took place yesterday in Long Island Sound. The morning opened bright, with only the slightest perceptible breeze, but just after the start, which was effected at 12:2:21 P.M. almost an hour after the appointed time the wind came fresher from the south and a little to the westward, and sped the yachts on their way.

It was whispered early yesterday morning among some of the Democratic Aldermen that Mr. John Kelly who claims to have no influence over the Mayor so far as the question of reducing the wages of City laborers is concerned had actually induced his Honor to nominate Col. Thomas Dunlap for the office of Commissioner of Jurors, which commands the handsome salary of $10,000 a year.

Mr. John Folk, who has been for over a quarter of a century in command of the Brooklyn Police, and who has been connected with the force almost since his boyhood, was yesterday placed on trial by the newly-appointed Democratic Police Commissioners for neglect of duty and general incompetency.
Mr. D.D Whitney the newly-appointed Register of Arrears, announces that he will make a number of changes in his department on the 1st of August.

GREENBRIER, WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, West Va., July 22. The second day's session of the National Cotton Exchange Convention opened this morning at 10:30 o'clock, the President, John Phelps, in the chair, and John S. Toof, Secretary.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 22.?The Bankers Convention adjourned here to-day, sine die. Most of the members had gone home before the time of assembling. The session was long, being devoted principally to the following resolutions, which were adopted toward the close:

The Mayor has nominated and the Aldermen have confirmed THOMAS DUNLAP to be Commissioner of Jurors in place of DOUGLAS TAYLOR, whose term of office was declared by the charter of 1873 to have expired on May 1 of that year.

The friends of the celebrated oarsmen, the Ward Brothers, of this place, are much disturbed by a well-founded story that has just reached here of the very questionable and unprofessional conduct of Ellis Ward, one of the brothers, at an amateur rowing regatta, held at Red Wing Minn., on the 28th ult.
Albert Wylie, aged nine years, has been missing from his home, on Atlantic street, Jersey City, since Monday last. His parents fear that he went in swimming and was drowned.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 22. The Democratic Convention continued in session until 4:30 o'clock this morning, when it adjourned to 10:30 A.M., without having reached a vote on any nomination.

Gen. Thomas L. Young, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor of Ohio, addressed a large political meeting in Columbus, the State capital, on Tuesday evening. Speaking on the subject of the national finances, he said:

A bold and well-planned scheme to swindle a business firm and a bank in Newark has just been discovered and frustrated. On Friday, the 9th inst., an advertisement was inserted in the Newark Advertiser, announcing that a gentleman had from $10,000 to $30,000 to invest as an active or special partner in any well-established business enterprise in the city.
There were no new developments yesterday in the suits of the people against Tweed and others for the recovery of a portion of the money stolen from the City Treasury under the Ring regime.

This afternoon the long-expected report of M. Savary respecting the Nievre election, and the alleged frauds committed by Baron de Bourgoing and his friends, will be distributed among the members of the Assembly.

Mrs. Sarah Merrigan, who has twice been tried for the murder of Miss Margaret Hamill, was released yesterday on $5,000 bail. This is regarded as the virtual ending of court proceedings in the case which is one of the most extraordinary on record.
Patrolman William H. Kelly, of the Seventh Precinct, died last night, of consumption, after an illness of three months.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 22. The Democratic State Convention, that met on Wednesday, continued in session until daylight of Thursday morning, and then took a few hours' recess, adjourned finally at 3 o'clock this afternoon, after nominating Carroll for Governor, Gwynn for Attorney General, and Woolford for Controller of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, July 22. The removal of District Attorney Fisher is merely a matter of time. It will take place on the return of his designated successor, ex-Gov. Welis, Mr. Fisher sought an interview with the President last night, but was unsuccessful in obtaining it.

We should be very glad to see good grounds for the conviction that a policy of repudiation would never be seriously proposed by any great party in this country. Yet what are we to make of the attitude taken by the Democratic Party, especially in the West? Only last year, Gov. HENDRICKS presided over a convention in Indiana at which a resolution recommending a distinct form of repudiation was inserted in the platform.

Those of our readers who are not immediately interested, and who have noted for the last few days the frequent statement in our commercial reports that wheat had advanced from three to five cents a bushel, do not probably realize the extent to which the market for breadstuffs has recently been affected.

The census enumerators for Southfield, which comprises two election districts, report a population of 1,280 for the first, it being an increase of 300 since 1865, and for the second 3,300, making a total of 4,580. The returns from Westfield show a population of 6,000; Middleton; 8,000; Northfield, 9,000; Castleton, 13,000; total for the county, 40,580. The increase during the past year has been considerable.

The inquiry into the cause of the death of the victims of the South-side Railroad of Long Island disaster, was resumed yesterday before Coroner Hicks, at Far Rockaway, and in the afternoon the case was given to the jury. The question at issue

The trial now in progress in Utah, whatever comes of it, is likely to be a curiosity in criminal jurisprudence. The crime of which the defendants stand accused was committed nearly twenty years ago; the original and surviving witnesses of the deed have grown from infancy to maturity, the number of defendants, though still large, has been reduced by the ordinary process of time, and the indictments have been changed since the trial was opened.

Louis Fredericks, a butcher in New-Haven, Conn., committed suicide by drowning yesterday. A young German from Strasburg, named Paul Letes, eighteen years of age, was killed on the railroad at Trenton yesterday.

Right Hon. Sir Francis Bond Head, Bart., formerly Governor of Upper Canada, and an author of some repute, died in England yesterday. He was the son of James Roper Head, Esq., and was born near Rochester, Jan. 1, 1793, making him eightytwo years old at the time of his death.

LONDON, July 23. A protest placed by Mr. Plimsoll on the table of the House of Commons last night is published. In it Mr. Plimsoll, says: "I protest in the name of God against the delay of the Shipping bill. Although the bill itself is an atrocious sham, there is enough humanity and knowledge in the House to change it into a good measure."

Although the mean temperature last week was, as registered at Central Park, only 74.5 Fahrenheit, there were 890 deaths reported in the City, against 743 the previous week, 601 being those of children under five years old.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. The steamer Abbotsford, reported lost on the Welsh coast, was a brig-rigged iron vessel of 2,611 tons register, with a carrying capacity of 2,300 tons of cargo, and accommodating thirty saloon and 650 steerage passengers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Friday, July 23, 1875. Mr. George Wilkes, in answer to the sum mons and warrant of arrest served upon him yesterday, appeared before John Carr, Notary Public in this town, to-day, and gave security in $2,500 to appear to answer in the libel suit for $25,000, before reported, in which Mr. McGrath is libellant. Rush C. Hawkins and C.K. Smith, of New-York, were his sureties.

WASHINGTON, July 24 1 A.M. The barometer is highest over the east Gulf coast. It has fallen somewhat in the North-west. A diminished pressure has moved eastward from the lower lake region to the New-England coast, preceded by brisk easterly winds north of Cape Cod. Cloudy and rainy weather has prevailed in New-England, but now followed by clear or clearing weather.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 23. The report of the signal service of only one inch rise at Cairo for the past twenty-four hours, and three inches here, has dispelled all fears of any serious damage from overflow, as the Mississippi River will be declining before the freshet from the Ohio reaches the cotton lands, and the general impression is that but little damage to the cotton crop will result from the present rise.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. Great excitement was raised here this afternoon and to-night by the statement from Coyle, the swimmer, that he had every reason to believe that he had been drugged, and that it was the cause of his sudden sickness in the water yesterday.

The Democrats of Ohio formally opened their campaign at Gallipolis on Wednesday. The telegraph has brought us a portion of the speech delivered by Mr. Pendleton on that occasion, but it neglected to say anything about that made by Gov. Allen at the same meeting.

LEWISTON, Mo., July 23. The National Bank of Winthrop was entered by burglars this morning, and the bank vaults and safe of the savings bank were opened. The work is supposed to have been done by New-York professionals, who came up on yesterday's train. The robbery was a bold operation. It was effected by at least three persons, who must have been professionals.

BOSTON, Mass., July 23. Hugh Donahue, the pedestrian, completed at Mystic Park, last night, the wonderful feat of walking 1,100 miles in 1,100 consecutive hours one mile each hour. He was in good condition at the close.
The Connecticut Legislature has adjourned sine die. The San Domingo Congress assembled on the 10th inst.

Stewart vs. The Western Pacific Railroad Company, involving land in the limits of the claimed Mexican grant Moquelomos, rejected in 1865, prior to the definite location of the road, but subsequent to the withdrawal upon a map of general route.

The past week was one of violent storms furious tempests, and general atmospheric perturbation. Rain fell every day in the week, sometimes abundantly; there was a heavy falt of snow in the mountains; in some sections furious hail-storms did great damage to the crops, and in many places the lightning fell upon towns and villages with fatal result.

Mr. George S. Opdyke, of the firm of George Opdyke Co., stated to a TIMES reporter that he know very little about the failure beyond what was currently reported on the street. He had heard it stated on apparently good authority that the collapse of the house was due mainly to speculation in cotton and Erie Railway shares.

BEAVER, Utah, July 27. The most of the day was occupied with the discussion of legal questions. The defense said they desired to examine Brigham Young and George A. Smith, and as both are too feeble to travel, asked leave to have their depositions taken at Salt Lake City.

Some new developments were made yesterday in the case of James Miller, the man who is supposed to have been thrown from the steam-tug Cornell, is Newark Bay, on Sunday afternoon. The examination of witnesses was resumed yesterday morning in the First District Court.
Thomas Crooke was yesterday held to answer in default of $1,000 by Justice Morgan, of the Essex Market Police Court, on a charge of burglary made by George Metz, of No. 6 Jackson street.

WASHINGTON, July 27. The United States Treasurer has issued the following circular: The observance of the annexed regulations in the transmission of currency to the Treasury is of the highest importance to the department, and will greatly facilitate the making of returns:

The regular semi-weekly meeting of the Board of Health was held yesterday, with President Chandler in the chair, and a large amount of important business was transacted. Dr. E.H.
