Regarding his position relative to the reorganization determined upon by the Tammany Committe on Organization, Alderman Lysaght, who was excused from signing the report of the Subcommittee on Discipline, made the following statement yesterday:

At an early hour yesterday morning an incendiary fire was started in a boot and shoe store adjoining the Academy of Music in Shamokin, Penn., but was extinguished with but little damage. Much alarm is manifested in Shamokin, as this is the third attempt within three weeks to burn that portion of the town. There is no clue to the incendiaries.

As soon as the news of the failure of Duncan, Sherman Co. was received here there was a great rush to the Stock Board, and Third street was alive with excited individuals rushing hither and yon, endeavoring to ascertain the facts in the case. Very soon the news was confirmed, and the bulls made desperate efforts to keep the price of stocks up.

There is a balance in the City Treasury of $1,447,245.06, deposited in twelve city banks. For the week ending Saturday, the 24th inst., the mortality report shows a record of 297 deaths, 3 of which resulted from small-pox, 11 from diphtheria and 111 from cholera infantum.

The suspension of a firm so widely known and doing so large a business as Messrs. DUNCAN, SHERMAN Co. is calculated to spread uneasiness throughout the mercantile community. But there are many reasons why the event, unfortunate as it is at best, is not likely to create anything like a general alarm, much less a panic.

WASHINGTON, July 27. The following information relative to the currents in the Saguenay River is from a report made by Capt. D. Tremblay to the Government of the Dominion of Canada, and obtained at the Navigation Bureau of the Treasury Department:
AEneas Fox, aged fifteen years, was drowned yesterday morning while bathing at Cedar Grove, N.J.

The mortality of children in this City is reaching proportions which demand serious attention. The number of deaths of children under five years of age during the last five weeks has advanced with extraordinary rapidity. There were 219 infant deaths during the week ending June 19, 288 during the week ending June 26, 308 during the week ending July 3, 466 during the week ending July 10, and 648 during the week ending July 17.

Yesterday afternoon two colored boys named Johnson, residing at New-Brunswick, attempted to kindle a fire by pouring kerosene oil upon it, when the can exploded, killing one of them instantly and injuring the other so severely that his life is despaired of.
The work of erecting the new buildings of Trinity College, at Hartford, Conn., has commenced, and will be steadily pushed forward. The Courant gives the following description:

WASHINGTON, July 27. Reports received by Surgeon General Barnes, United States Army, from Brevet Major Gen. Brannan, commanding Fort Barrancas, Fla., and George M. Sternberg. Post Surgeon there, show that the yellow fever is raging violontly at that place. On the 21st inst. there were six cases and on the morning of the 22d there were fifteen.
PHILADELPHIA, July 27. At a special meeting of the United States Centennial Board of Finance held at their office to-day, the board adopted the following statement and resolutions:
Manuel Cortez, a Spanish cigar peddler, was held by Commissioner Shields yesterday, to answer a charge of selling unstamped cigars on Second avenue, near Fifty-second street.

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday a communication was read from J.H. Breslin Co., of the Grand Union Hotel, Saratoga, requesting that, by the courtesy of the board, Detective William G. Elder might be permitted to remain at the hotel during the rush of the season, for the protection of the guests, who are mainly residents of this City.

LONDON, July 27. The Daily News says the partial relapse in the corn market yesterday, following the complete change of weather, indicated a revival of hopes respecting the harvest which the persistent rain of the previous three weeks seemed wholly to forbid.

The adjourned hearing in the case of Annie Small, on writ of certiorari, was again before Judge Westbrook in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday. As already published, Mrs. Small, who was a prominent witness before the Police Investigating Committee, was committed on a charge of perjury preferred by Capt. McCullough.
The steam-ship Montana, for Liverpool and Queenstewn, yesterday, carried 31,000 letters and forty-six bags of newspapers.

There have been rumors in circulation to the effect that some dissatisfaction existed on the part of Treasurer New because of the manner of making appointments in his bureau, and that the Treasurer was not disposed to continue in his present office unless he could direct in all cases who should be appointed to positions in the bureau under his charge.

In olden times, persons engaged in certain pursuits were carefully excluded from serving upon juries, the supposition being that their occupations were of a kind that tended to make them incompetent judges. One of the most outrageous instances of an abuse of the law which we remember to have noticed has recently occurred in England.

About four months ago Messrs. Clarke Sons, money brokers at Chatham and Chambers streets, informed E.B. Wash burne, Chief of the United States Secret Service, that they had received in the course of their business a counterfeit of the new trade dollar. When the counterfeit was examined it was found to be of the first class, being finely cut, with clear and sharp raised work and perfect size, weight, and ring.

The Newburg Journal says that at 2:30 o'clock on Monday morning five burglars attempted to enter the residence of Mr. Powers, on Cornwall Heights, but were driven away by the colored coachman, Mr. Jackson, who fired on them with a double-barreled shot-gun, and wounded at least one of the would-be robbers.

There is so slight an apparent foundation for the romance of the castaways of the schooner Florinda, that most people will hesitate a long time before believing it. The story runs that the Florinda, bound to California from New-Orleans, in 1849, was wrecked on one of the unfrequently-visited islands of the South Pacific.

Hon. E.R. Smith, Commissioner of Indian Affairs: "I have discovered gold in paying quantities in gravel bars, both on Spring and Rapid Creeks, from twenty to thirty miles north-east, of Harney's Peak. The deposits are the richest yet found in the Hills, and are favorably situated. There is a good head of water in the streams, amply sufficient for working purposes.

The rumor of the failure of Duncan, Sherman Co. was not generally credited at first, but its authentication became apparent at a little after 11 o'clock in the forenoon, when the doors of the establishment, corner of Pine and Nassau streets, were closed in the faces of the hundreds of inquirers who were crowding up the steps and thronging the passageways.

Among the most memorable social events of the London season, for us, at least, was an excursion to "The Banks." Mountfield, Sussex, the lovely country seat of Sir John Bennett, who invited his 500 friends and more to meet and do honor to the Lord Mayor and Sheriffs of London, and the Mayor and corporation of Hastings.

A much, calmer feeling prevailed yesterday in the commercial line than had been anticipated as likely to result from the failure of Messrs. Duncan, Sherman Co. It was generally believed that their strictly commercial obligations, at least in this market, were not of very great magnitude. The cotton dealings of the firm were viewed as only the immediate cause of their more recent embarrassments.

A meeting of business men was held last evening at the rooms of the Association of Political Reform at No. 43 South Washington square, to consider the question of sending delegates to a convention which is to meet in Cincinnati, Ohio, on the 25th of October next respecting the currency and the internal taxes, and to devise the best method for a return to specie payments.

The suspension of the baking firm of Messrs. Duncan, Sherman Co. was the principal topic of discussion in business circles yesterday. It is said that it will take fully six months to get the accounts of the firm in such shape as to permit of a clear statement, although it is by no means certain that they will be adjusted that time.

Further testimony was taken yesterday at Police trials in the case of Sergt. John F. Buckley, of the Seventeenth Precinct, who is charged with being drunk and disorderly in the saloon No. 26 First street, on the 17th of June. Three witnesses were examined, but their evidence was neither important nor conclusive.

It would be strange if, in a time of business depression like the present, men's minds were not peculiarly open to the necessity of placing some limit to extravagance in local government. The bonded debt of the City continues to increase at the rate of about six millions a year, while the assessed valuation of the City has begun to decrease.

About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon James E. Coyne saw his wife walking in Fulton street, Brooklyn, with a young man named Henry Lee, who resides in East New-York. Coyne, although he has not lived with his wife for some time, became infuriated at her walking with another man, and immediately commenced to assault her with his fists. Lee, seeing that he had got in trouble, fled.

There are some men of wealth and influence who have a wonderful incapacity for administering their own property. Their ability for making close bargains may be proverbial. They may have attained such high positions in their professions that money comes to them as freely as rain from heaven. Their judgement in their pursuits may also have been astonishingly clear. Yet, when it comes to spending money, they betray the guilelessness of infancy.
LONDON, July 28.--The suspension of Messrs. Duncan, Sherman Co., of New-York, has no appreciable effect on the general market here.

Below is the deed of assignment of Messrs. Duncan, Sherman Co., appointing Judge Shipman their Assignee, and transferring their books, property, ,c., to him, to be used in effecting settlement. Accompanying the first assignment is a second one, by which A. Foster Elliot, of New-Orleans, a junior partner of the house, assigns his share in the concern to Judge Shipman.

The near approach of the election for Governor of this State gives an uncommon interest to matters political here at this time. In fact, there has not been since the war more interest taken in the canvass for Governor. The Democrats did, for a few weeks after the work of canvassing the State began, affect an indifference that amounted almost to contempt for the opposition party.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 28.--The Globe has fifteen columns of special reports, second series, about the crops, from different places in Ontario, Quebec, New-Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, and Nova Scotia.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 28.--This was the second day of the Cleveland Club races. Fully 12,000 people were on the grounds to-day. The track was in magnificent condition, notwithstanding the drenching rain of last night, and to-day proved, beyond question, among the fastest race courses in the country, Fullerton making his best record, 2:18, in the second heat. The sport was excellent, although not as exciting as yesterday, nor as good as is anticipated for to-morrow.

Denison, who refused to produce his books and papers as a witness before the Canal Fraud Investigating Commission. Bishop Simpson, of the Methodist Episcopal Church, has just held a conference at Milan of the Methodist mission force in Italy. Reports were received from the missionaries representing that there were great hindrances to the progress of evangelism. Priestly opposition, general indifference, and popular ignorance were encountered, and in some instances personal violence was offered.

The first of the free excursions on board the new Floating Hospital for the benefit of the destitute sick children of the City was given on Tuesday, and the second occurs to-day. The opinion among medical men is unanimous that the treatment of Summer epidemics among the little ones of the tenements requires a plentiful supply of pure air.

The races which are announced to take place at Saratoga this afternoon have created a great deal of interest among the sporting men of this City, and a great deal of money has been wagered on the result of each of the three events on the programme.

In reply to correspondents, we have to state that the republication from these columns of the review of the evidence of the Beecher trial, revised and corrected, will be ready, in pamphlet form, next week. It will be issued at twenty-five cents a copy, and orders may be sent to THE TIMES Office, or to Mr. Brentano, No. 39 Union square.

On Wednesday last I went to Versailles to hear M. Rouher's defense, and must confess that it made a very strong impression upon my mind. It seemed to me that he left nothing at all of the Savary report, but as this is a personal appreciation, I must say that hostile journals affirm that he did not meet a single one of the accusations brought against him and his party.

The excitement attending the ousting of Morrissey, Kelly, and Hayes from the Tammany Hall General Committee had yesterday greatly subsided, but there were no symptoms of a cooling of the factious spirit which the action has aroused. On the contrary there was more talk about the organization of Anti-Tammany forces than there has been at any previous time.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 28.--Additional dispatches to-night from Southern Ohio and Indiana state that the continuous rains of the past two days have in many localities utterly ruined the wheat shock, and caused great damage to other crops, and in some instances land sides are reported.

RUTLAND, Vt., July 28.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Rutland Railroad was held here this afternoon. The Directors' report, presented at the meeting, deprecates in general terms the jeopardizing of the interests of the stockholders of the road by the personal quarrel between Messrs. Smith and Page, and urges that the control of the Rutland Railroad revert to the original managers, cutting loose from the Central Vermont Railroad.
BEAVER, Utah, July 28.--Several witnesses were sworn and testified at the Mountain Meadow massacre trial today. Their evidence was confirmatory of the preceding witnesses.

Charles R. Thompson, indicted under the name of Charles R. Walker, a prisoner sentenced for forgery, who escaped from the custody of Officer Patrick Grennan, of the General Sessions Court squad, while being conveyed to the Tombs some ten days since, is still at large, and not the slightest clue to his whereabouts has been obtained.

Wall street seemed yesterday to have recovered almost entirely from the shock of the failure of Duncan, Sherman Co. on Tuesday. The suspension continued to be, however, the chief topic of conversation among bankers and business men in general, and scores of false rumors were circulated from the opening to the closing of the day's business.
John O'Connor was held at the Tombs Police Court yesterday on the charge of stealing $51 worth of clothing from Catherine Doyle, of No. 129 West Twenty-fifth street.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, July 28, 1875. About noon it was whispered on the floor of the Commercial Exchange that the house of John Mason Co., one of Philadelphia's old landmarks in the West India Commission business had failed. To confirm the rumor your correspondent waited upon one of the firm, and though a statement of the assets and liabilities was refused, he was assured that the firm had failed.

The fashion of advertising all sorts of wares to all sorts of persons sometimes produces curious reading in the pages of the most staid of newspapers. The London Economist is probably the last publication which any of its readers would take up in the hope of raising a ripple of amusement in minds dull and stagnant with Midsummer idleness.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Wednesday, July 28, 1875. The second annual regatta of the Newburg Bay Yacht Association will come off on Wednesday, Aug. 4. The list of entries will not close until the 2d proximo, but already twenty-two entries have been made, nine in the first class and thirteen in the second. Among these are boats from Staten Island, New-York, Jersey City, Albany, and nearly all the intermediate points along the Hudson.

To-morrow is the all-important day of the meeting and people are collecting in large numbers. The trains to-day were all crowded, and these fresh arrivals find great difficulty in obtaining shelter, all the hotels being overcrowded. The thousands who are expected to arrive late to-night and to-morrow morning will be obliged to content themselves with outside quarters.

Controller Green has directed Mr. Wm. Gray to act as Collector of the Bureau of City Revenue, in place of Col. Thomas Dankap, who was appointed Commissioner of Jurors. It is said that the office of Collector will not be permanently filled for some time. There are many applicants for it. Mr. Gray is chief clerk of the Bureau.

Mr. Pyburn, who prefers the charges, and also assumes the role of Judge, has been a Police Commissioner for three weeks. PARIS, July 29. Many telegrams have been received here from Americans in various parts of the Continent holding letters of credit issued by Duncan, Sherman Co., which have been dishonored, inquiring about them. It was rumored here to-day that the English and American bankers would accept Duncan. Sherman Co.'s circular notes, and there was much disappointment when the report was found to be untrue.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 29. At the races today, being the third day of the Cleveland Club races, the attendance was the largest of the season, it being estimated at 15,000 people.

The death, a year ago last May, of a wellknown and prominent Board of Trade man, M. De Belloy, is well remembered by many people in Chicago, especially by those who were acquainted with the history of the unfortunate man. He was a Frenchman, and seion of one of the oldest and first families of France. His name and title in full were the Marquis Aymar de Belloy.
Count Valmaseda returned somewhat unexpectedly to Havana from his head-quarters at Las Cruces yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 30.--At about 2 o'clock this afternoon Thomas Donohue, proprietor of a boarding-house in the lower part of Carondelet street, near the Vulcan Iron Works, was drowned in a vault on his premises. Charles Prunty, James Henry, and Joseph Schlichtig, who successively descended into the vault to recover the body of Donohue, were overcome by foul air and died before they could be rescued.

The investigation into the causes of the increase of crime in the City of New-York, was resumed yesterday. The members of the Legislative Committee present, were Messrs. Campbell, Hess, Dessar, and McGowan. The investigation first turned on a burglary, in respect to which the conduct of Capt. Kennedy, then of the Sixth Precinct, was brought in question.

George E. Pickett, Major General in the Confederate service during the late rebellion, died last evening at Norfolk, Va. He was born in Virginia, and July 1, 1842, was appointed from Illinois to a cadetship at the United States Military Academy graduating July 1, 1846, when he was promoted in the army to Brevet Second Lieutenant in the Eighth Infantry.

The State of Kentucky will hold an important election on the first Monday (the second day) of August. The full list of State officers is to be chosen, and also a Legislature to which will fall the duty of electing a United States Senator. The Republican and Democratic Parties have nominated candidates for State officers as follows:

The second game of the championship series, between the Chicago Club and the Atlantics, of Brooklyn, was played yesterday afternoon on the Union Grounds, in the presence of about 300 persons. The Chicago Club went first to the bat, and secured runs in each of the first four innings. After that point they were less successful, making only one run during the remainder of the game.

One morning about two weeks ago, Mrs. McGoochen beamed blandly across the breakfast, table on her husband, and informed him that she had concluded to discharge the hired girl and do her own work. This announcement startled Mr. McGoochen almost as much as if she had declared her determination to commit suicide.

Mr. Cheever, though having an office and doing business in this city, lives in Ypsilanti; hence the proceedings are had in Washtenaw county.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 1. Another heavy rain-fall occurred this afternoon, doing some damage to the streets and sidewalks on the hillsides and flooding cellars to some extent.

Scarcity of labor in this and other countries has doubtless done much toward stimulating the progress of invention. A large proportion of the patents that are recorded in the office at Washington are due to the necessity which has constantly been apparent in our history of doing by machinery what had hitherto been done, when done at all, by manual labor.

A neat pamphlet, printed at Lawrence, Kansas, contains the official report of the proceedings of the sixth annual session of the General Council of the Indian Territory. That assemblage was composed of delegates duly elected from the Indian tribes legally resident in said Territory.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2. The investigation into the charges preferred against Bishop Whittingham came to an end to-day, and his friends and the High Church party generally are happy over the fact that the preliminary court of inquiry has decided that he shall not be presented for trial before an ecclesiastical court.

To-morrow the first meeting of the Saratoga Racing Association will be closed. There are three events on the card, which will afford an excellent day's entertainment. LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 2.--The results of the election as far as known, at midnight, show a healthy growth of Republican sentiment all through the State.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 3. A special dispatch to the Appeal from Jackson, Miss., says: The Democratic State Convention assembled at the Capitol to-day, and was the largest assemblage of the kind since 1861. All the prominent men of the State were present.

Suit has been brought against the city by Josiah W. Kemble and Zorah Todd to recover $3,600 for work done on the Hamilton Avenue Bridge. There is a balance to the credit of the City Treasury of $979,840.71 deposited in twelve city banks.

A brief advertisement in a morning journal invited the creditors of Duncan, Sherman Co. to meet at noon yesterday, at Mr. John Townshend's office; in the Bennett Building. A reporter of THE TIMES called at 12:15 o'clock and found two creditors present, one of them being Mr. Townshend himself. Mr. Townshend did not wish to proceed to business with so small an audience, and having waited until 12:40 he adjourned the meeting sine die.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 3. Minute guns were fired here to-day between 12 and 1 o'clock as a mark of respect to the late ex-President. The flags on public buildings are at half-mast.

The London Daily News of July 24 says: Yesterday afternoon Jane, Lady Franklin, the venerable widow of Sir John Franklin, the Arctic explorer, was interred in Kensal-green Cemetery. The funeral procession, which consisted of a hearse, followed by ten mourning coaches, and nearly the same number of private carriages, started from Phillimore Gardens, where her ladyship died, shortly after 1 o'clock, for the cemetery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. During the past twenty-four hours the Ohio River has risen rapidly at Pittsburg, Cincinnati, and Louisville, and is now one foot above the "danger line" at Pittsburg and one foot below at Cincinnati and Louisville.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 3. The Times Louisville special dispatch says the election returns from the State come in slowly. The indications are that the vote will not be materially different from the Leslie-Harlan vote in 1871.

Ireland is going to commemorate tomorrow the memory of O'CONNELL, and more than usual efforts have been made to make the anniversary in Dublin worthy of the occasion. In our own City, too, and throughout the United States, the day will, to a certain extent, be commemorated by Irishmen, and "the memory of the Liberator" will be toasted at many a festive board.

The observations of the transit of Venus for the purpose of determining the true distance of the sun from the earth for which costly expeditions were last year equipped and sent out by most of the civilized nations on the globe, do not now promise to correct materially the information before possessed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 4. During the thunder-storm early this morning the Centenary Methodist Episcopal Church in this village was struck by lightning and damaged to the extent of $500. Mrs. Kingsland, living next door to the church, was knocked down by the shock and seriously injured.

Graham, of North Carolina, and ex-Gov. Jenkins, of Maryland. About forty guests were present. Among them were Govs. Hoffman, Hendricks, and Curtis.

Patrick Murphy, who fell into the canal at New-Brunswick last Saturday, while in an epileptic fit, died from the effects yesterday.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 5. Excepting a small amount of driftwood in the river, everything was most favorable for the races of the North-western Amateur Rowing Association to-day.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 5. The August trotting meeting opened to-day. The track, considering the late heavy rains, was in very fine condition, and the attendance exceeded all expectation, fully 12,000 people being present. The weather was delightful.
Newspapers printed in Syracuse, Utica, Schenectady, and Troy, in this State, in Rutland, Vt., and Laconia, N.H., make mention of a remarkable halo around the sun which was seen on Sunday last.

The London and Westminster Bank is one of the largest and most successful of the joint stock banking institutions in the world. Its paid up capital amounts to ten millions of dollars, and the volume of its annual business reaches the aggregate of $1,500,000,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 5. No very reliable estimate of the aggregate loss to the wheat, corn, and other crops in the State can be made at present. In some sections the estimated damage is fifty per cent., in others a much greater percentage, and in many localities the entire crop is destroyed.

LONDON, Aug. 5.--Sld. for the United States-Liefjeld, Clydesdale, Annie Goudey Viggillate, Brothers and Sisters, Yarmouth, Battaglia, Success, John L. Dimmock, Helene, Minnie Allen, Albion, Capt. Larsen, Chestina Redman, Joseph Nickerson, and Matteo.

R. Livermore, Chairman; S.A. Sawyer, James McGee, S.D. Harrison, John G. Dale.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. A cable dispatch was received by Postmaster General Jewell from the postal authorities of Switzerland, July 28, requesting the return, unopened, of two registered letters forwarded from Switzerland on July 20 and 27, addressed to Duncan, Sherman Co., New-York.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 6. The races today attracted a large concourse of people. The weather was fine and the track in excellent condition. Both races were won easily in three straight heats by the favorites.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 6. Was there ever a yachting cruise in which the familiar painted ship and painted ocean did not play a part? Long before Coleridge's Ancient Mariner became acquainted with dull stagnation, kindred mishaps have befallen all seafarers, and of course the fact that one is a yacht-owner does not exempt him from a common misfortune.

LONDON, Aug. 6. Numerous amendments have been made in committee to the Shipping bill introduced in the House of Commons by Sir Charles Adderly. The bill finally passed this evening without a division of the House.
Nothing has yet been done toward paying the August coupons of the Long Island City bonds.

The Assembly having settled the question of dissolution for the present, by voting an adjournment to the 4th of November, a number of Deputies who were silent when there was yet time are now very much concerned about the dissolution.

The centenary memorial last night in honor of Daniel O'Connell, "the Liberator of Ireland," at Cooper institute was, numerically considered, a successful affair, and passed off in a manner highly gratifying to its projectors.
One hundred policemen enjoyed, with their wives and children a trip to Rockaway Beach yesterday. The excursion was the last which the Police will enjoy this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. The report of the committee appointed by Secretary Bristow to examine the books, accounts, and moneys in the office of the Treasurer of the United States shows that the count of the moneys in the cash vault was commenced on the evening of June 30, and closed in the reserve vault on the 15th of July.
DUBLIN, Aug. 6. The O'Connell centenary celebration is continued to-day. The ceremonies began this morning with a grand procession through the various streets.

Complaints are constantly being received at Washington from American travelers abroad concerning the inconveniences, and sometimes the annoyances, they undergo from not having passports. This is nothing more than we anticipated before the season for European travel began.

Yesterday THE TIMES accused the Tribune of an attempt to black-mail President Gowen, of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad; of debauching public morals by harboring a "common gin-mill," open on Sunday, in the basement of its new building, and of printing lies about its circulation with intent to deceive.

There is an old saw that one often hears repeated in a New-England farm-house, "No great loss without some small gain." The Cincinnati Enquirer, the inflation organ of Ohio, makes an atrocious and cruel application of the trivial spirit of the saw to the devastating floods of the last three days, and figures out a political gain to the rag-money party.
A young man named Tolen, while examining some machinery, yesterday, in a box factory in Newark, belonging to John H. Holt Co., had his thumb and forefinger cut off.

The Hartford Club and the Atlantics of Brooklyn played the eighth game of their championship series yesterday afternoon, on the Union Grounds, in Brooklyn. The Hartford Club was first at the bat, and during the first three innings the game was closely contested, no runs being made by either club, and hopes were entertained that it would be a fine and interesting game throughout.

The motion to be argued in Tweed's case yesterday, to vacate a stay of proceedings against him, the particulars of which appeared in yesterday's TIMES, has been disposed of by the opposing counsel without argument in court.

The case in which Officer Terence Finnerty, of the First Precinct, is charged with assaulting Maggie Igoe on the Battery, on the night of Friday, the 30th ult., was resumed before Justice Otterbourg, at the Tombs Police Court, yesterday morning.

No. 126. W. Basey et al. vs. John Gallagher et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of the Territory of Montana. This was a suit for an injunction to restrain the defendants from diverting the water of a stream known as Avalanche Creek, in the Territory of Montana, to which the plaintiffs assert a right by prior appropriation for the purposes of irrigation.

The report of the career of Henry and Hall, the English diamond smugglers, thieves, and swindlers, published in THE TIMES yesterday, created a profound sensation in the City. A relative of Mrs. Paran Stevons called upon Capt. Chalker yesterday morning, and was permitted to see the jewelry captured. He thought that several of the diamond rings were the property of that lady, but could not positively identify them.

ALBANY, Aug. 6. Daniel Smith, who was sentenced on Feb. 4, 1867, in the County of Erie, to two years' imprisonment in Auburn Prison, on a charge of burglary in the second degree, has been restored to citizenship by the Governor.

John L. Brown, Jr., has commenced a suit against what he terms the Street-cleaning Association, (a voluntary association,) to have its affairs wound up and its debts paid, and in his complaint, which is filed in the office of the County Clerk, asks for the appointment of a Receiver of the property of the company.

Mr. Moss has abandoned his intention of leasing the theatre lately occupied by Mrs. Conway. It is understood, however, a large sum of money having been deposited as an earnest of Mr. Moss' intention to secure the house, that the proprietors of the place lay claim to the deposit, and will resist in the courts any demand for its return.

Among the books in the library of the late Andrew Johnson, says the Nashville Union, is a small volume entitled "The American Speaker. Philadelphia printed and published by Abraham Small, No. 142 Chestnut street, two doors below the Post Office, 1818."

In one of GAVARNI'S series of caricatures of Parisian life, we see a very small and very dilapidated boy gormandizing fruit with that voracity which the infant of the man-animal only exhibits, while to him enters a very large but also very dilapidated woman, who seems to stand to him in the maternal relation, and who berates her Anatole or Alphonse for thus "bringing the cholera into Paris."

Forty years ago the annual export of corn, wheat, and other grain from the United States amounted to but little more than one-half per cent, of the total export trade of the country. At that time the only important items of our exports which came under the head of "breadstuffs" were wheat and corn flour.

Every Summer a number of persons are drowned in the surf at our sea-side resorts. Usually they die in couples, and sometimes by threes. A bather ventures out too far and is unable to return. Another goes to his aid, and perhaps a third goes to help the second.

The meeting of the Board of Police yesterday, a special one, was marked by a very heated debate between Gen.Smith and Mr.Matsell. Since his appointment as Commissioner, Gen.Smith has participated very little in the debates of the Board meetings. It has been well understood in certain circles, however, that he was gradually collecting facts and figures regarding the members of the Police force, with a view to introducing measures for the improvement of the department.

The speech of Senator MORTON at Urbana, Ohio, last evening, was one of his best, and we direct the special attention of our readers to it. Mr. MORTON is a man to whom the country owes a great deal, a fact which we acknowledge the more freely because, as our readers know, we have frequently had occasion to differ from him.

The Mutuals, of this City, and the Hartford Club played an exciting game in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, in which eleven innings were played. The fielding on both sides was exceedingly effective, Burdock, Ferguson; and Remson, of the Hartfords, playing very finely at their respective positions, and Holdsworth, Nelson, Booth, and Gedney excelling on the Mutual side. Remson, of the Hartfords, made a splendid fly-catch in the eleventh inning.

The arrested parties are B.B.Hallock, a clerk in the cash-room; Theodore W.Brown, a notorious gambler, and William Ottman, keeper of drinking saloon. Hallock is from New-York, where his family resides.

A farewell missionary meeting was held in the Congregational House, Boston, Wednesday afternoon, the exercises being conducted by Rev.Dr. W.G.Clark, Secretary of the American Board. There were present twenty-seven missionaries, with ten or twelve of their children, representing thirteen different fields of labor in foreign lands, and twenty States of our own country.

In 1703 three malefactors of the then small town of Chihuahua, Mexico, flying from justice, betook themselves to the surrounding mountains, and there for several weeks lived a life of terror, moving about from fastness to fastness in constant dread of the fierce Apaches who occupied the Territory on the one hand, and of their pursuing white brethren on the other.

At 9:35 o'clock this morning there was a loud rumbling noise heard at the Frankford Arsenal, near Bridesburg, five miles from Philadelphia. This was succeeded by three or four loud reports, which told at once that there was an explosion. Unfortunately it proved the case, and one of the wood and iron frame buildings situated in the north-eastern end of the arsenal grounds had been blown apart by the force of the explosion.

The Sunday-school Assembly now in session here is the greatest gathering of Sunday-school people ever massed on this continent for more than the service of a single day. Several thousand people are encamped here, and not withstanding the heavy rains of the last few days and nights the camp is not drowned out.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Aug. 8.--Returns received during the past two days leave the result of the election still in doubt. Both parties claim a majority of the delegates, and it may be several days before the result is definitely known, as several extreme western counties are yet to be heard from. It is not probable that the majority will exceed two either way.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 8. One hundred years ago to-day this ancient town bore a conspicuous part in the revolutionary struggle in successfully rapelling the attempt of the British ship-of war Falcon to burn the town, and in capturing two schooners, two barges, a cutter, and some five British soldiers and sailors.

Rome is now settled down into the almost stupid quiet of the long Summer vacation. In our foreign quarter of the Piazza di Spagna and the Trinita dei Monti not a single straggling tourist is left, and the streets and squares are quite deserted, or are given over to the garzoni of the bakers, butchers, and wine merchants, who go and come making their domiciliary calls.

Commissioner Pratt is devising a new system for paying gaugers, who are now paid one cent per gallon for the first 5,000 gallons, the rate decreasing for each subsequent 5,000 gallons. The maximum day's work is 70,000 gallons. Under the present system two gaugers frequently measure spirits at the same distillery, thus obtaining the largest rate for measuring the first 10,000 gallons, and increasing the rate on the balance.

The season at the most popular of NewYork watering-places, Long Branch, seems to have been affected neither by the economical spirit of the times, nor by the atmospheric conditions of the past fortnight. Nobody seems to have been deterred from coming here by the high prices of the hotels, or driven away by the almost incessant rains.

Police Commissioner Smith stated to a TIMES reporter last evening that in all probability there would be a joint effort on the part of the Mayor and the Governor to reform the Police Department. The precise method to be taken the Commissioner did not think himself justified in stating but he hinted somewhat broadly that an attempt would be made to remove Matsell, and added that abundant evidence of the latter's shortcomings was accessible.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning repeats the accusation it made against the Tribune on Thursday of trying to deceive the public with regard to circulation. THE TIMES asserts that its own circulation is much larger than the Tribune's "very often from 10,000 to 15,000 a day larger."

A game of base ball was arranged to be played on the Capitoline Grounds, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, between the Madison Club, of Brooklyn, and the Lexington Club, of Jamaica, Long Island. The Madison Club was on hand, with full numbers, ready for the game, out the Lexington Club, for some unexplained reason, failed to make their appearance, and the game was declared against them.

Some ten days ago the English High Court of Chancery held its last sitting, and ceased to exist as an independent court. The Judicature Act of 1873 thus came into full operation, and the distinction between courts of law and equity is as completely abolished in England as it is in the State of New-York. The Court of Chancery is probably a thousand years old.

The R.W. Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Odd-fellows of the State of New-York, met yesterday at 9 o'clock A.M., in Tammany Hall, pursuant to adjournment. After the regular opening, the Committee on Election of Grand Officers made their report. For Grand Master 2,571 votes were cast, of which John G. Stebbins, of Genesee Lodge, No. 5, received 2,092; W.L. Voorhis 418, and William Dunscomb 61.

This has been another gloomy day for Saratoga. It began raining at daylight this morning and continued throughout the day, making people feel homesick and dejected. As the day grew older the storm increased in violence and the streets were turned into miniature rivers. Now and then it would lighten up and the visitors would hug the delusion that it was about to clear up, but the water only poured down in increased volume.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. Our cruise was practically brought to a termination to-day with a splendid sail over the triangular course from Newport to the light-ship off Cuttyhunk, thence round the buoy off Block Island and back to Newport. The course is about sixty miles long, and it was therefore desirable that there should be an early departure from the harbor, more particularly as the start was from the light-ship outside.

There is a great deal of excitement to-day in this section of Georgia on account of the report of an attempted insurrection by negroes in the counties about fifty miles from this city. Ross, Gen. McCandless. Considerable caucusing was indulged in as to what should be done at the State Convention, which meets at Erie on Sept. 8. ExGov. Bigler appeared to have but little show among the leaders.

The third annual regatta of the Long Island Yacht Club took place under unfavorable auspices yesterday. At a special meeting of the club, held at the Short Branch House, at the foot of Thirtyeighth street, Brooklyn, on Tuesday evening, it was decided to assemble the yachts at the foot of Thirty-fourth; street at 12 o'clock yesterday, but the severe rain-storm which prevailed from 11 A.M. until 1 P.M. prevented the carrying out of this programme.

In accordance with a previous announcement, Mr. John D. Townsend, who appeared as counsel before the Legislative Committee on Crime, preferred charges yesterday against Police Commissioners Matsell, Disbecker, and Voorhis. The charges are based on the evidence taken before the committee in relation to the alleged immunity which gamblers and the keepers of the more disreputable houses enjoyed at the hands of the Police.

The Hartford and Atlantic Clubs played the ninth game of their series yesterday afternoon on the Union Grounds. It began at 3:45 P.M., with the Hartfords first at the bat, and proved to be a very fine and interesting game throughout, the best, by far, that the Atlantics have played this season.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20.--The morning session of the Colored Convention to-day was quite disorderly, and a decided tumult ensued on the reading of resolutions denouncing the Conservative Party and holding it responsible for all the evils in Virginia since the war. A delegate desired to know how about the Freedman's Bank. The reading was stopped and the resolutions referred.

Mr. NELSON MAGEE was confined in the Kings County Lunatic Asylum several weeks, beginning with June 7, 1875. He has testified before the Kings County Commissioners of Charities, and his statement, published in THE TIMES, yesterday, unless set aside for sufficient cause, is enough to consign the managers of the asylum to infamy.

The investigation into the abuses at the Kings County Lunatic Asylum was resumed yesterday morning at the asylum building in Flat bush. Commissioner Norris occupied the chair, and Commissioners Raber and Midas, together with several friends of the complainant and officials of the asylum, were present.

The Saratoga racing season of 1875 will close to-morrow with a fine day's sport, there being five races on the programme. The meetings here have been more successful than in preceding years, both in a racing and pecuniary point of view, for as the turf increases in popularity, Saratoga as a great racing centre derives accumulating benefits.

A perfect Summer day, with a track in capital condition, proved insufficient to attract any considerable crowd to Fleetwood yesterday to witness the four races announced. The first was a match for $500, between John Murphy's brown mare Katie S. and R. Thornton's bay mare Vesta. It was for the best three in five, mile heats, in harness.

The Police Commissioners received the papers from Mayor Wickham late yesterday afternoon containing the charges preferred against them by Mr. Townsend. A TIMES reporter called at Police Headquarters soon afterward and had an interview with Commissioners Voorhie and Disbecker in relation to the subject, and both expressed themselves as having in no way been guilty of any neglect of duty during the term they have been connected with the board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. The Treasury officials appointed to investigate the charges made against the Quartermaster's Department of the Marine Corps concerning the purchase of material and manufacture of uniforms have reported that nearly $10,000 were paid for materials not purchased, and $14,000 for garments not manufactured.
Annie McKay was held for trial yesterday for stealing $38 from Peter Anderson, Captain of a canal-boat.

John McCarthy and Andrew Miller forged the signatures of Schappert Schlachter, No. 20 Second avenue, to two checks on the Mechanics' and Traders' National Bank, and obtained thereon $1,500. Miller pleaded guilty and was remanded for sentence; McCarthy furnished $3,000 bail at the District Attorney's office yesterday, and was released.

The dispute which is now going on in England about the use of this word needs to be more clearly defined. The question is not as to whether a Dissenting minister may, under the English law, adopt it as a prefix to his name, but whether an Anglican Rector has the right to forbid such use of it in an inscription upon a tombstone in his own churchyard.

The last race of the season has been run over the Saratoga course, and the turfmen have packed their trunks and departed for other fields of speculation. The trainers and stable boys silently move about preparing for the hegira to Metropolitan quarters, there to prepare for the Fall campaign.

The opening regatta of the Sea Cliff Amateur Boating Club took place yesterday afternoon, on the waters of Hempstead Bay, and a very successful and enjoyable affair it proved to be. The day was as fine as the most fastidious lover of aquatic sports could have asked for, and everything passed off to the entire satisfaction of all concerned.

The Hartford Club and the Mutuals, of this City, played the tenth game of their championship series on the Union Grounds, yesterday afternoon, in the presence of about one thousand spectators. The Mutuals went first to the bat, and scored 1 run in the first inning, after which they had a succession of blank innings up to the ninth, when they succeeded in getting in 2 more runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 1 A.M. Rain has prevailed in the lake region and in the southern portion of the South Atlantic and Gulf States. Clear and cool weather prevails in the upper lake region and North-west, with northerly to easterly winds, and decidedly high barometer. Clear weather continues over the middle and eastern Atlantic coasts, with no decided change in temperature, and south-west winds and high barometer.
The census of the City of Hoboken, completed yesterday, fixes the population of that city at 24,776.

The San Francisco Morning Chronicle of Aug. 12 has the following: San Francisco seems destined to be the scene upon which more than one theatrical celebrity is compelled to appear in an unstudied part. Hull, who is now actively engaged in making arrangements for the forty-fourth annual fair of the institute, which will be formally opened on Wednesday, Sept. 8.

The Harlem River presented a very animated appearance yesterday afternoon, good water, fair wind, and vacation time combining to bring the rowers out in full force. Barges, gigs, four-oared shells, pairs, doubles and singles crowded the course until it resembled Broadway in the height of traffic while from every boat-house "float" swimmers started in merry confusion.

The second international swimming match between Messrs. Coyle, of Chester, Penn., and J.B. Johnson, the English champion, took place on the Delaware to-day. In the previous match, which occurred on the 22d of July, Johnson won, Coyle being overcome and declaring that he was drugged. Several contests of a minor nature have since transpired, in which the Englishman has showed that he possesses superior abilities.

Fire insurance is a subject which is gradually receiving more and more attention on the part of the public, and the desire to insure is much greater now than it was some years ago. This increased anxiety to guard against loss by fire has been met by the establishment of insurance companies throughout the country, who charge their patrons a premium proportionate to the amount insured and the risk incurred.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 27. The Canadian steamer Manitoba came into collision with the propeller Comet above White Fish Point, Lake Superior, at 8:30 o'clock last evening, and sunk her almost instantly. The celebrated trotting stallion Smuggler and the bay mare Nottie have been matched to trot mile heats, best three in five, in harness, for $2,000 a side. NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 2. Last night a heavily loaded train from the national camp-meeting at Wesley Grove, near Goshen, while on the way to Kingston, broke through a rotten bridge near Shawangunk station. Five of the cars went down an embankment and twenty-five persons were injured, a few seriously.

A convention of Virginians interested in the improvement and development of the Eastern or tide-water section of Virginia, especially in the vicinity of Fredericksburg and the counties adjacent thereto, in the Rappahannock Valley, was held yesterday at Barnum's Hotel, corner of Broadway and Twentieth street, and was attended by some of the representative men of the North and South.

LONDON, Sept. 3.--A dispatch to the London Times, from Therapia, a suburb of Constantinople, in which the Foreign Ministers reside, says the Turks in Herzegovina have gained a victory. Ten thousand insurgents have been driven across the frontier into Dalmatia, where they have been disarmed by the Austrians. Neversigne, the focus of the insurrection, has been destroyed. Communications by way of Kleck have been re-established.

The London season being at its height, with all its turmoil and its witchery, can any one spare a moment to notice a sad little face peeping out of the window of a railway cab just driving into Paddington Station? SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4.--D. O. Mills authorizes the statement that the defalcation of the late President of the Bank of California will amount to between three and four millions of dollars, and that an overissue of stock has been discovered. Additional particulars will be furnished later. It is not supposed that this will in any way prejudice the arrangements now being made to rehabilitate the bank.

Although JOSEPH GUIBORD, late of Montreal, died in 1869, his mortal remains are yet unburied. Moreover, although said GUIBORD cannot be supposed to have the least concern as to what becomes of his bones, being now some six years in another world, his relies are causing infinite trouble to surviving friends and townsmen.

At 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning a fire occurred in the basement of the two-story frame dwelling at Ninety-seventh street and Riverside Drive, owned and occupied by George Jay and Margaret Seeley. The homeopathic physicians of this City have induced the Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction to set apart the building on Ward's Island heretofore known as the Inebriate Asylum, to be used as a homeopathic hospital. SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 5. At the Republican Assembly District Convention held at this place yesterday, William A. Sackett, G.W. Town, and John A. Vrathan were chosen delegates to the State Convention. John T.Carr was chosen delegate to the Judicial Convention, and J.P. Butler, N.W. Houghton, and Douw Winne delegates to the Senatorial Convention. The convention indorsed the name of Hon. Charles S. Lester for Supreme Court Judge, and of Hon. George West for Senator.

The new, Professor is a son of Rev. Dr. J.J. Porter, of Watertown.

Kelley Co. and Emanuel Hoffman Son, of New-York City, imported from Havana twelve bales of cigar cuttings, known to the trade as "shorts," a decision having first been obtained from the Secretary of the Treasury that such cuttings could be imported as unmanufactured tobacco, subject to duty at the rate of thirty cents per pound.

The action of the Democrats of Hamilton County yesterday will have considerable influence in the whole State. If a sober, decorous convention had nominated a fairly good ticket for the Legislature and the county officers, the Democrats would have gained by it in this city only; but having made bad nominations, after a disgraceful and riotous meeting of nearly twelve hours, they will lose everywhere. Of course Republicans are greatly pleased at the event.

Commissioner Mott and Secretary Harrison remained for some little time during the evening debate upon the report of the Rapid-transit Commissioners.

The address of Prof. TYNDALL'S successor at the meeting of the British Association this year will stir up none of the dissensions and controversies which arose and soon died away again after the address on evolution last year at Belfast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. The correspondence between Minister Schenck and Eart Derby touching the ship Trufant is said to be sharp and piquant. It appears the Trufant was debtor to her American crew for wages, and to the United States for marina hospital and other fees, which the United States law requires shall be paid before the sale and transfer can be ratified by the American authorities.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 6. The Alabama Constitutional Convention met here to-day. Gen. L.P. Walker was chosen President by acclamation, the Republicans and Democrats all voting for him. Primaries were held last evening in the various Assembly districts throughout the City by the Tammany Hall Party to elect delegates and alternates to the Democratic State Convention which is to be held at Syracuse on the 16th inst. The delegates and alternates in the Fifteenth Assembly District were not elected, as they were chosen last week.

The Mayor yesterday transmitted to the Common Council a communication from Commissioner Porter urging the necessity of laying water pipes across the Harlem River to Randall's Island. The document was accompanied by a communication from Assistant Engineer Thompson, certifying his personal examination of the various defects alluded to in the Commissioner's letter, and alleging that there was a diminished water pressure in the reservoir on the island.

In a match between the Manhattan Club, of New-York, and the Staten Island Club, yesterday, on the Camp Washington grounds, the Manhattanas on the game by six wickets, after playing about five hours. The individual play of Messrs. Jenkins and Greig, on behalf of the Manhattans, and Donald and Duer for the Staten Islanders, was particularly fine. The umpiring of Mr. Gilbert was all that could be desired.
LONDON,Sept. 7.--The Carlist General, Dorregaray, pursued by the royal forces, has passed through Roncal with 1,500 men. He had lost his war material. Subsequently he reached Burguete.

The arrest of Ludwig S. Von Trier by Detectives Rielly and Williamson, of the Central Office, on Monday night develops a criminal case of more than ordinary interest. Von Trier is a man of fine appearance and aristocratic habits. His father is a resident of Frankfort, and a member of the German Reichstag.

The third annual running meeting of the Prospect Park Fair Ground Association was opened yesterday. About 2,000 persons took advantage of the fine weather to become spectators of the several events to be decided. The card presented three races, the first of which was a hurdle race of two miles, over eight hurdles, which brought out five contestants.

To the Editor of the Chicago Tribune. In the issue of Sept. 2 of the Post and Mail is an extract from the new volume of the Count do Paris, describing the manner in which McClellan was relieved from the command of the Army of the Potomac. The Count's description of the transaction contains probably as many inaccuracies as could well be crowded into the same space.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. The first witness examined this morning in the Westervelt trial was Sarah Kerr, who, at the time of the abduction, was child's nurse in the family of Mr. Ross. Her testimony consists entirely of a description of the manner in which Charlie was dressed on the morning of his abduction. She described particularly the ribbon that bound the child's hair. There was no cross-examination.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. The Commissioner of Pensions, in his annual report, will recommend Congress to abolish the present system of medical examination of pensioners, and establish districts to which competent surgeons, with prescribed salaries, may be assigned from time to time. Examiners are now paid a fixed sum for each examination made.

As might have been expected, the report of the Rapid-transit Commissioners has been too imperfectly understood to clicit anything like appreciative criticism. The Commissioners themselves are somewhat doubtful whether the NewYork Elevated Railroad Company can dispense with the consent of half the property-owners or the constitutional substitute for it, before operating or constructing their connecting railroads along the new routes allotted to them.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 7. The number of people who have come here to attend the convention cannot be less than twelve or fifteen hundred, and the two small hotels are full to overflowing. People of the city have opened their houses very generally to receive strangers who cannot get a cover and a cot in the public houses.

This afternoon a telegram was received here from Liverpool which stated that the experiment of shipping peaches to England has proved a failure. The Ohio sailed from here twelve days ago with 2,450 crates of the fruit, sent out under a refrigerating process as a test. The steam-ship company did not send ice enough, and the supply gave out in three days after the vessel had left here.
The sale of property for unpaid taxes and assessments was commenced yesterday, and was largely attended.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 7.--The Canal Board held a special meeting to-day. There were present Lieut. Gov. Dorsheimer, Attorney General Pratt, Secretary of State Willers, Canal Commissioner Stroud, Treasurer Raines, and Controller Hopkins.

Joseph Seiger, aged thirty-two years, residing at No. 78 Frankfort street, was assaulted yesterday morning by John Gartmann, who struck him on the head with a cart-rung, inflicting injuries which it is feared will prove fatal. The assault occurred in the alley-way adjoining the premises No. 38 Ferry street, where both men were employed.

The Republicans of New-York State held a most satisfactory meeting yesterday at Saratoga. They nominated good candidates, announced their principles in a short and excellent platform, and began the work of the canvass in an earnest and businesslike spirit. Win or lose next November, we shall never have anything to be ashamed of in what was done yesterday at Saratoga.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 8.--The Republican State Convention was called to order at 11:15 by Hon. E.D. Morgan, Chairman of the State Committee.

At about 5:50 o'clock last evening a fire and explosion occurred in the Celluloid Manufacturing Company's building, Nos. 45 and 47 Mechanic street, Newark, N.J., resulting in loss of life and the destruction of property valued at $200,000. About forty men and boys were engaged in the building.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 8. The Democratic State Convention met at the Opera-house in this city at noon to-day. Hon. D.W. Moxon was chosen temporary chairman. After the appointment of committees the convention took a recess until 3 o'clock.

A convention of the Queens County Prohibitionists is called to meet in Hempstead on Friday the 17th inst., at 2 o'clock P.M., for the purpose of nominating candidates for county officers and taking other preliminary measures for prosecuting the campaign in favor of temperance, in politics, this Fall.
Thomas Card, aged 100 years, of Dover Point, N.H., died on Wednesday night. He was probably the oldest man in the State.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 9. At a special term of the Johnson Court convened at Wrightsville for the trial of negroes, bills of indictment were found against eleven persons. Jake Hicks was put on trial first. After exhausting nearly three panels a jury was obtained.
Owen Wheeler, residing at West and Christopher streets, was held yesterday, by Justice Wandell, in $100 bail, for violation of the Excise law.

PANAMA, Aug. 31. The latest dates from Central America state that tranquillity prevailed throughout. Honduras was quiet. Nicaragua had agreed to pay a subsidy of $6,000 a year to the Pa cific Mail Company, in order that their steamers should touch at the ports of San Juan del Sur and Corinto. The navigation of the lakes by steam was to be re-established.

The only question considered was whether the meetings in this city shall be open to newspaper representatives. The decision was postponed until to-morrow. The feeling of a majority of the commission seems averse to open meetings. All the previous sessions have been secret.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 9. Three accidents occurred on the Chicago and North-western Railroad last night, resulting fatally in each case. The severe rain-storm which prevailed in this section was the cause.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company will on Monday next, the 13th inst., begin running a regular daily fast mail train to Pittsburg, Cincinnati, Chicago, St. Louis, and the South-west. It appears that the company some months ago advised the Post Office Department of its readiness to run a fast postal train, not only to Chicago, but to St. Louis and Cincinnati, thus affording the same postal facilities to the South-west as to Chicago and the North-west.

In the case of young CONNOLLY, who lately died in the Penitentiary on Blackwell's Island, the Coroner's Jury have returned a verdict to the effect that the man's death was hastened by the ill-treatment he received at the hands of certain keepers.

DEEP CREEK, Utah, Sept. 9. The account of a rumored general uprising of the Indians in the eastern part of Nevada, which caused much alarm at the first reports, has been corroborated by Indians who have been out for the past three days, and who arrived this morning from the vicinity of Cleveland's ranche.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--Accounts of accidents caused by the terrific thunder and rain storms which have prevailed in the North-west for the past forty-eight hours are numerous. The Illinois Protestant Episcopal Diocesan Convention will meet at Chicago next Tuesday to elect a Bishop. This will be the third meeting of the convention for this purpose. The barometer has risen, with clear or partly cloudy weather, northerly to westerly winds, and lower temperature in the Southern, Middle, and New-England States and the Ohio Valley; it is highest in the Mississippi Valley, and has fallen in the North-west, with southerly winds and generally clear and slightly warmer weather. YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 21. Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, by special requrest, returned to Youngstown to-night, where he made his first speech in Ohio two weeks ago. He is addressing an audience of 600 or 700 in the opera-house, and is evidently making a deep impression. His first speech here did great good, turning back to hard-money principles many who were wavering. The prospects in this county have improved greatly during the last two weeks.

The Times in its evening edition publishes a special telegram, in which it is said that Dervish Pasha, with nine battalions of troops, has entered the village of Piva, near Travnick, unresisted. There are 1,000 refugees at Grahovo without sustenance, Flocks, perishing from drought, are arriving there.

QUEBEC, Sept. 23. The British ship Abeona, from Glasgow, which arrived yesterday, reports, 18th inst., saw a large full-rigged ship ashore on Anticosti, twenty miles to castward of South-west Point. The vessel is painted black outside, white inside, and has light-colored lower masts. She has three royal yards across, and from appearances has been a long time ashore. She appears to have been outward bound.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 23. The following special was received to-night from Jackson, Miss.: One company of whites were mustered into the service of the State to-night. It is composed of and controlled by well-known Democrats. They had adjourned to select officers. Two colored companies presented themselves this morning. The rolls not being made out they were not mustered in.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 24. Capt. Eber B. Ward, the leading millionaire and capitalist of this State, and a man interested in manufacturing, min- ing and limbering operation throughout the Northwest, fell dead from apoplexy upon our streets in January last, at the age of sixty-three. John H. Reynolds died at his home in Kinderhook yesterday morning. Mr. Reynolds' life had been one of activity and usefulness in public and private capacities. He was a lawyer of much ability, and ranked among the foremost of his profession in the State. He studied law in the office Of Mr., Beekman, of Kinderhook, and went thence to Albany, where he was successively in partnership with Marcus T. Reynolds and Ira and Hamilton Harris.

A rather interesting forgery case was tried before Recorder Hackott, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday. The prisoner was a young and prepossessing German girl named caroline pells, alias Hoffman, alias Blank, who was charged with presenting a forged check for $19,400 to the Paying Teller of the Nassau Bank on the 17th of April last. She was tried in July last for the offense, but the jury could not agree upon a verdict.

The Rapid-transit Commissioners devoted their time yesterday afternoon to hearing counsel on a legal point lately brought to their notice. The point involved is whether the words "over, through, and along" can be so construed as to admit of the construction of a depressed railway. In other words, the commission have been assured that although their resolutions fixing the routes use only the words "thence over, through, and along Third avenue."

The Insurance Convention held its fifth day's session yesterday in the hall of the Fire Under- writers, No.156 Broadway, Mr. Chapman presiding. The minutes of the previous day having been read and approved, the Chairman announced that the Committee on Blanks and the Committee on Legislation were in session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He then called upon Mr. Heald, of the Home Insurance Company of this City, to address the Convention.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 24. Mrs. Herndon and family, reported lost at velasco are safe. Dr. Alexander and family, reported lost near Lynchburg, are saved. They lost everything excent what they had on. A special dispatch from San Antonio dated yesterday, says that the storm which plasted the coast did no damage there, and very little rain fell. The wind blew a perfect gale.

We publish this morning a verbatim report of Mr. CARL SCHURZ'S speech at Cincinnati last evening. We advise all of our readers to glance at the first column or two of the report. Yesterday was an unfortunate day for the Direct Cable Company. In the morning business was temporarily suspended, owing to the interruption to the land lines connecting the main office with the American end of the cable by the storm of Sunday. This was remedied at length, and business was resumed until about 2 P.M., when the wires suddenly stopped working.

Bradford Prince, who will this year doubtless run for the Senate in the First District on the Republican ticket.
In the surrogate's Court yesterday, the testimony of Dr. Cottin, in the John L. Brown will case, was concluded, and the further hearing was postponed until Friday.
LONDON, Sept. 28.--A Reuter telegram from Shanghai states that Vice Admiral A.P. Ryder, commanding the British fleet on the China station, is at Chee-Foo with four men-ofwar.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 28.--Advices from Brazoria, dated Sept. 23, confirm the reports first received from Matagorda. That town was wholly washed away excepting four houses. No lives were lost, the people saving themselves by clinging to the cedar-trees in the vicinity.

The first Fall meeting at Fleetwood Park for the season of 1875 was begun yesterday afternoon with two trotting contests, neither of which was in any degree remarkable. The weather was all that could be desired and the track was in splendid condition, but the contests, save for trifling incidents mentioned further on, were tame beyond comparison. The Commissioners of Emigration did not begin their regular meeting until nearly 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The previous hour was taken up with successive meetings of the Finance, Castle and Ward's Island Committees.

BOSTON, Sept. 28.--A meeting of the Labor Reformers was held at the Sherman House this evening, to consider the condition of the Fall River operatives. Speeches of a highly inflammatory nature were made by the Chairman and others. Two sets of resolutions introduced--the one of a more pacific character than the other--provoked each heated discussion and opposition that they were withdrawn. One speaker was glad that windows had been broken.

ROME, Sept. 28.--Cardinal McCloskey has received a letter from Cardinal Cullen announcing that the entire Irish Episcopate, assembled at Maynooth, has adopted a resolution congratulating him on his elevation to the Sacred College.

BUFFALO, Sept., 28.--The attendance at the afternoon session of the Criminal Term of the Superior Court was unusually large, as it was confidently expected that the decision of Judge Clinton, on the motion of District Attorney Lockwood to strike out the special plea of George D. Lord to the bribery indictment would be rendered. The Judge, however, was not prepared to decide the question to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28.--Payments on account of the assesement on the Syndicate fund of the Bank of California have been lively to-day, and a great portion of the amount is now in the vaults of the bank. The San Francisco Stock Board to-day authorized the payment of twenty per cent, of the subscription of $250,000. The bank will probably reopen on Saturday next, although no official action has as yet been taken to that effect.

LONDON, Sept. 28.--A destructive flood occurred yesterday during the great gale in the valley of the Lee, Ireland. The river rose several feet and inundated a portion of the City of Cork and the country for miles about, occasioning immense damage to property. Similar accounts have been received from other parts of Ireland and from Scotland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--The board of naval officers to examine the bids opened a few days ago for the construction of a sectional iron dry dock at the Pensacola Navy-yard met at the Navy Department this morning. The board consisted of Commodore J.W.A. Nicholson, President; Chief Engineer Alexander Henderson and Naval Constructor, William L. Mintonye. To-day they addressed letters to the several bidders, making inquiry as to their facilities for constructing the dock.

The Assembly Committee charged with the investigation of the administration of criminal law in this City resumed its inquiry yesterday in the Chamber of the Board of Aldermen. Assemblymen Campbell, Hose, McGowan, and Deasar were present, and Messrs. Townsend and Aub, as counsel, conducted the examination.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 28.--The joint discussions between Gen. Woodford and Gen. Ewing have been arranged. The first meeting will be at Shawnee, in Perry County. PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--There will probably be a suit for damages, growing out of the alleged refusal of the Mount Morish Cemetery Association to receive for burial the remains of Henry Jones, colored, the well-known caterer of this city, who died on Friday last. Mrs. Jones bought a lot in the cemetery in Apri1 last, and buried a sister in it a month later, and last Summer her husband inclosed the lot with an ornamental railing.

The Arbitration Committee of the Produce Exchange have just rendered a decision which has caused more than usual excitement among provision men. Thorp "for cash" at $20.85 per barrel, and in accordance with the usual custom paid for them on the same day on tender of two "warehouse receipts" for 250 barrels each.

Thomas Scanlon, aged three years, fell into a cistern in the rear of his parents' residence on Germania avenue, Jersey City, on Tuesday night and was drowned.

LONDON, Sept. 29.?The damage done to the crops by the floods is reported to be enormous in Longford, Kerry, and Tipperary, Ireland. At Cork the floods have subsided, but it is believed that several persons were drowned.

LONDON, Sept. 29. A dispatch from Gibraltar announces the arrival there of the German brig Hinrich, Capt. Brane, from New-York Aug. 25, with a cargo of 88,000 gallons of petroleum. The Hinrich had been in collision, and had hull, rigging, and sails damaged. She will be obliged to discharge partially before proceeding to her destination. She was bound for Genoa.
One firm in California will ship 800 tons of pears to the Eastern markets this season.
Among those who called upon Mayor Wickham yesterday were Judge Noah Davis, James Watson Webb, and Thurlow Weed.
Judge Benedict will impanel a Grand Jury in the United States Court next week. There are twelve jail cases on the calendar.

The regatta of the New-York Yacht Club to be sailed to-day for prizes offered by Rear Commodore Kane will bring out ten schooners, six of the first and four of the second class, and seven sloops, which are also divided into two classes. The most interesting feature of it will probably be the meeting of the Palmer and the Mohawk, which have not yet sailed together.

A long and bitter contest was naturally expected in the Convention of the Massachusetts Republicans at Worcester yesterday; but Hon. ALEXANDER H. RICE was nominated for Governor on the third ballot. The remainder of the ticket was filled up without serious difficulty, and an admirable platform was adopted without debate. Tha matches in the rifle tournaments at Creedmoor were continued yesterday, but not under such pleasant auspices as on the previous days. A fluctuating wind from the north-west disturbed the calculations of the marksmen in the opening contest the Mid-range match, and during the afternoon a succession of light showers, which terminated in a steady rain, materially hindered the progress of the sport.

The fast postal trains which have recently been placed on two of the great trunk lines connecting this City with Chicago have thus far met with no accident. The success of the experiment has led people to ask why the New-York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads did not try it long ago.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1. The official announcement is made that the San Francisco Stock Board will open for regular business next Tuesday at 11 A.M. The Pacific Exchange will open at the same time.

All the advices from the interior of the State point to the conclusion that there is an excellent prospect of retaining a Republican majority in the next Senate. We have already endeavored to indicate the quarters in which our friends must make extra exertions to secure this result.

The funeral of Rev. Dr. Porteous, Pastor of All Souls' Church, Brooklyn, who was drowned at Sea Cliff on Tuesday last, took place in the church named yesterday afternoon. The religious services at 2 o'clock were participated in by a large audience, the church being crowded to its utmost capacity.

Since my last we have been, as it were, "laying up," awaiting the resumption of the Bank of California. So intimately and generally were the business connections of individuals and enterprises associated with the bank or its ramifying branches and correspondents that it is almost impossible for the community to make a move toward restoration of business until the bank opens its doors.

About midnight it Thursday night the extensive barn of Nathan Decou, in Hamilton Township, N.J., was destroyed by fire, together with a horse valued at $200, a cow, two wagons, a mowing and threshing-machine, 300 bushels of wheat, 50 tons of hay, and 800 bushels of potatoes, valued at $2,000. Total loss, $10,000; insurance, $4,000.

Long, tight-fitting redingotes of cloth, velvet, woolen, and silk damasse are announced to be the style this Autumn. It is difficult to realize that the pretty garments ornamented with plaitings, and sashes in cascades, which are worn at present, will be replaced by these long plain garments, except it be for morning wear. Time will show, however, whether they are to be generally adopted or not.

LONDON, Oct. 2. The election for a mem- ber of Parliament to fill the vacancy in West Suffolk occasioned by the death of Col. Wilson occurred to-day. Mr. T. Thornhill, Jr., Con- servative, was nominated, and there being no opposition no polling occurred, and that gentleman was duly returned.

No one can say that there was not variety enough in Thursday's regatta. There was a light breeze off the club-house, a dead calm inside the Hook, and a fresh breeze outside. The yachts did nearly everything that an inventive yachtsman could have suggested.

A horse belonging to John P. Benjamin, of Elizabeth, died on Saturday from epizootic. Thomas Bolton, an aged resident of Bloomfield, was found dead in bed Friday morning. Apoplexy is the supposed cause of death.

Within recent years the Republican Party in Kings County has never been so united as it is at present. Last year's reverses taught a lesson to some of the ward managers in regard to the danger attendant on a division in the ranks which they are not likely soon to forget.
John R. Fellows and John D. Townsend are being pushed by their friends for the Tammany nomination for District Attorney.
Mr. W.R. Babcock has bought the b.c. Egypt, 4 years, by Planet, out of Lady Barry, for $1,500. Egypt won several races at Louisville, and will be at Jerome Park this week.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 3. And imperial decree is published, ordering that agricultural populations which peacefully follow their avocations be exempted from a fourth of the recently-imposed tithes, and that they be relieved from the payment of arrears of taxes up to the financial year 1873-4, the latter exemption not to apply to well-to-do classes who are indebted to the Treasury.
