CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 2. The diplo- matic agent of Servia has presented to the Porte and the foreign Ambassadors a dispatch complaining of fresh violations of the Servian frontier, and specifying among other acts an incursion of marauders accompanied by Turkish troops, in which several persons were killed, and a church was sacked and burned.
An unknown man, about sixty years old, was found sick and apparently insane in Chatham street last night, and was sent to the Park Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. Mr. Tomey, a clerk in the Fourth Auditor's Office, has returned from Colorado, whither he went to investigate charges of fraud and embezzlement preferred against ex-Marshal Schaffenberg.
Rev. Dr. Foss, President of Wesleyan College, preached yesterday forenoon in St. James' Methodist Episcopal Church, in One Hundred and Twenty-sixth street, choosing for his text the following:
The Constitutional Convention in Alabama has nearly completed its labors. The Democrats of the Twenty-fifth District of this State have nominated Charles F. Durston for Senator.

The revival services held at the Fifty-third Street Baptist Church, yesterday morning and evening under the direction of Rev. A.P. Graves, Evangelist, of Michigan, assisted by the well-known revival singer George S. Weeks, were attended with much success, the church being well crowded as each service.

The French correspondent of the London Times, in some extended comments on Spanish politics, weaves in a sketch of Princess Mercedes, the youngest of the two daughters of the Duc de Montpensier, whose engagement to King Alfonso was recently announced:
An examination of Ohio election statistics reveals some curious facts. The largest aggregate vote ever cast in the State for Governor was in 1867, when Thurman ran against Hayes.
A.P. Taylor, of No. 86 Cambridge place, who attempted suicide about a week ago, died yesterday at his residence.

Great emotion was caused here on the reception of the address sent to the Spanish Bishops by Mgr. Simeoni, the Papal Nuncio, and the Bourse was immediately affected. The Saragossa Railway suffered greatly from the rumors, and all Spanish funds fell rapidly for two days.
Ex-Congressman John C. Churchill, of Oswego, is at the Astor House. Hon. Robert McLane, of Baltimore, is at the Windsor Hotel.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 3. The inaugural meeting of the Elmira Driving Park Association closed yesterday afternoon with three races.

Capt. A.S. Grant has handed us a letter from his friend, Dr. George McKinstry of this city, which will prove exceedingly interesting to the readers of the Union, containing as it done some graphic reminiscences of the early days of California, Dr. McKinstry says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. Information received, here from Havana shows that there is a great deals of dissatisfaction and uneasiness in Cuba among the wealthy Spaniards at the prolongation of the insurrection, by which immense damage has resulted to all material interests in the island, the injury being incalculable.

A Parisian journalist claims to have interviewed "M. Marwood," the English hangman and the successor of Calcraft. "Calcraft," he says, was a gentleman, "Marwood est beaucoup moins 'bien.' Short in stature, scanty in vestments, his figure humble as a beaten dog, M. Marwood has the air of a badly-paid solicitor's clerk.

There was a pretty good attendance at the great auction sale of Gen. Grant's blooded stock, crops, and farming implements at his farm, near St. Louis, on Thursday. As a general thing the blooded stock sold low, but the mules and work horses brought fair prices.

If there is any considerable portion of the people of this country whose views, whatever they may be, are not met by the promises of some section of the Democratic Party, they had better make themselves known immediately.

A Large audience assembled in Tammany Hall last evening to witness some manifestations of spirit-power, which had been announced to take place there at that time under the mediumisti auspices of Mr. George Willis, who claimed to act under the spiritual influence of the Indian Chief King Philip.

The Board of Education of Chicago took up a subject at its meeting last night that required the utmost nicety of handling. I refer to the question of excluding the Bible from the public schools.

Whatever may be the true purpose of the present legislative inquiry into the causes and punishment of crime, it may have a good effect in calling public attention to the condition of our penal institutions.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 3. A serious riot occurred here to-day between Orange "Young Britons," and a Roman Catholic pilgrimage procession. Eight police- men were badly hurt, one it is feared fatally, and twenty slightly, injured. Several arrests have been made.
People in Syracuse are greatly alarmed by the prevalence of small-pox. A Minnesota hotel boasts of six guests whose average weight is 221 pounds each.

The Oyer and Terminer Court room was crowded yesterday by curious spectators anxious to see John Scannell and a half a score of other alleged murderers who were brought down from the Tombs to have days set for their trial. Judge Barrett was on the bench, and District Attorney Phelps appeared on behalf of the people. Scannell seemed to be in good health, was neatly attired, and apparently enjoyed the excitement his presence created.
LONDON, Oct. 4. A special dispatch from Ragusa to the Times reports that the Turks have been reinforced at Trebinje and Klek, and the insurgents are retiring toward Gasgnko.
The First Ward of Long Island City is to be lighted with oil, and the Common Council have awarded the contract for doing so to Charles Sheriden, at $1.30 for each lamp per month.
Virginia L. Minor and Francis Minor, her husband, plaintiffs in error, vs. Reese Happersett. In error to the Supreme Court of Missouri. Mr. Chief Justice Waite delivered the opinion of the court.

A very fine and closely-contested game of base-ball was played on the Union Grounds, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, between the Flyaways of this City, and the Confidence Club, of NewRochelle, N.Y. It began with the Confidence Club first at the bat, who were "blanked" up to the fifth inning, when they made four runs.
Capt. EBER B. WARD was a man who would have been ranked by any one who knew him in his public relations only, as an excellent type of the enterprising, entergetic, and successful American capitalist.
Albert Bierstadt, the artist, is at the Brevoort House.

The Assembly Committee on Crime resumed its work yesterday at the Tombs. Messrs. Thomas, Cooper, Campbell, and Jacob Hess were the only members of the committee in attendance. The session was devoted to an examination of the condition and general workings of the institution, and the Warden, Mr. John Quinn, was the first witness examined.
The corner stone of the University of Colorado was laid at Boulder, on Sept. 20. The annual meeting of the State Teachers' Association of New-Hampshire will be held at Wolfeboro, Oct. 14 and 15.

James Willet was found in the cellar of Martin Reilly, of No. 42 Market street, trying to escape through a vault opening. He was arrested and held yesterday in Essex Market Court in default of $1,000 bail to answer.

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 4. Another horrible murder to be added to the long list in this State occurred at Suncook to-day. The victim was Miss. Josie Langmade, a daughter of James F. Langmade, a highly respectable citizen of Suncook.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 4. The town elections for town officers occurred in this State to-day. Local questions entered largely into the election of the officials, consequently the elections have no particular political significance beyond the fact that the Selectmen and Town Clerk constitute a Board of Registration of Elections. So far as heard from there are no very marked changes from last year.

In response to an order to show cause why Otis F. Hall and George P. Webster, composing the law firm of Hall Webster, should not be disbarred for alleged disgraceful misconduct in their professional capaicty, Mr. Yeaman appeared yesterday, in the General Term of the Supreme Court, on the part of the firm, and Mr. Richard G. Bustced in support of the petitioner, John F. Dawson, who had obtained the order to show cause.
Rev. George F. Pentecost, of the Warren Street Baptist Church, Boston, has received a call from the Adelphi Street Baptist Church of this city.

A proposition more utterly unwise and improper it is impossible to im- agine, or one which would work more serious mischief.

PORT COLBORNE, Ontario, Oct. 4. The schooner St. Andrew, with corn from Toledo for Kingston, sank this morning near Ranney's Bend, about two miles down the canal.

Judge Blatchford rendered a decision yesterday in the suit brought by the owners of the lighter Ohio against the ferry-boat Winona. On June 13, 1874, the Winona, on the passage from Fulton Ferry slip, Brooklyn, to New-York, came in collision with the lighter Ohio, owned by the New-Jersey Lighterage Company, and laden with tobacco in hogsheads, capsizing the lighter and damaging the cargo. The lighter was bound up the river.

A preliminary session of the third annual Convention of the Engineers of the Fire Departments of the United States was held yesterday at Fireman's Hall, Mercer street. Chief Henry Clay Sexton, of St. Louis, called the delegates to order at noon, in a brief address, in which he expressed his regret at the absence of some who had taken a prominent part in the deliberations of the last convention, held at St. Louis.

To-day was the first day of the fall meeting of the Nashville Bloodhorse Association. The weather was splendid, the track in fine condition, and the attendance large. Kentucky stables were well represented. The first race was the Young America State, dash one mile.

The visit of Marshal de MacMahon to the districts that suffered from the second inundation has furnished occasion for a fresh lot of political speeches, but none of those that have been thus far reported are worthy a moment's attention.
The Rhode Island State Fair commences at Narragansett Park and Howard Hall to-day.
The announcement of the death of Ex. Governor Olden is without foundation. There has been a slight improvement in his condition.

The first regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen after their Summer recess was held yesterday, Alderman Bergen in the chair. After the minutes of the last meeting had been read and approved Alderman Ropes presented a detailed statement of the city debt. WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. The report of the Bureau of Statistics shows that during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1875, there arrived in the United States 227,498 immigrants, which is 180,149 below the number that arrived in 1874, and less than one-half the number that arrived in 1873.

The very interesting and rather novel joint debates between Gen. Stewart L. Woodford and Gen. Thomas Ewing began last night at a little out-of-the-way town called Shawnee, and were continued to-day at Lancaster. The disputants meet again to-morrow at Circleville, and except for some unforeseen accident, they will meet daily to the end of the campaign.
James Keenan, a server of notices under Mr. McGregor, former Superintendent of Buildings, obtained a verdict in Part I, of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, for $155.54, salary due him.

Two accidents in the coal mines is this vicinity this week have reminded the mining population of the uncertainty and peril of their every-day work. On Wednesday a young man named Murphy, a miner working at Bear Ridge Colliery, No. 2, at Mahanoy Plane, failed to come home from his work at the usual time.

The assertion that the Pope is nearly out of patience with the liberalism of the Alfonsist Government in Spain, and only awaits some more flagrant act of tolerance and disobedience on its part to declare openly for Don Carlos, does not seem improbable when it is known how zealous a churchman Don Carlos is.

At the race meetings of Jerome Park, both in the Summer and the Fall, Saturday is the great day, and other occasions are called off-days. Certain it is, however, that yesterday this hitherto invariable law did not hold good, for there were about as many people as were present last Saturday.

The Rapid-transit Commissioners were in session yesterday. At Monday's session they agreed to authorize the construction of rapid-transit railways by one or more of three plans, at the option of the companies having the right to construct the same.

The Senate committee charged with the investigation of the various departments and bureaus of the City and County Government held another session yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Senator Booth, the Chairman, only was present, and ex-Commissioner John I. Davenport conducted the examination of the witnesses.

THE Canal Investigating Commissioners have presented their fifth report. It refers to the somewhat well-worn subject of GEORGE D. LORD'S repair contract on Section 14 of the Erie Canal, and the fraudulent awards made to LEWIS J. BENNETT and JOHN HAND for work which ought to have been done by LORD under his bargain with the State.

MONTREAL, Oct. 5. It is reported that the authorities of the Institut Canadien have been in communication with the Navy Department at Washington in reference to the use of the most efficent self-explosives, to be used in Guibord's grave to prevent its being tampered with after the burial.

Two more political conventions are to be held in this State before the campaign can be said to be fairly opened. In ordinary times these would excite little attention, they being of factions whose influence is not generally very strong; but this year, owing to the peculiar standing of the two great parties, and the turnover on the last election day, they are awaited with considerable concern.
An entirely new kind of baby has been discovered near Erie, Penn. This interesting phenomenon is a poor but honest infant, of a little more than one year of age, and apparently of the female sex.
The most useful political organization which has been seen for some years, in this or any other country, is that which has been devised by the Democratic Party. It is made to suit everybody's taste.
The opening of the Winter season of the New-York Homeopathic Medical College took place yesterday at the college building, corner of Third avenue and Twenty-third street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. Lieut. George A. Nor- ris is ordered to the Hydrographic Office. Assistant Engineer George C. Neilson and Cadet Engineer R. G. Denig are ordered to examination for promotion. Gunner William E. Webbe is ordered to the New- York Navy-yard.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 5. The Canal Board met this morning at 10:30 o'clock. Lieut. Gov. Dorsheimer, Treasurer Raines, Secretary of State Willers, Attorney General Pratt State Engineer Sweet, Controller Hopkins, and Commissioners Stroud, Jackson, and Thayer were present.

As will be at once seen, it seriously implicates a number of individuals who have heretofore escaped unscathed, among them Franklin A. Alberger, of Buffalo, and W. W. Jerome.

Recently a motion was made before Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, on behalf of Mrs. Laura S. Taylor, widow of James B. Taylor, to substitute Wingate Callen as her counsel, in place of Rufus F. Andrews, who has acted as her legal adviser in the litigations which have continued since 1871 respecting the will and estate of Mr. Taylor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 5. The stock- holders of the Bank of California met to-day at 11 A.M. to hear the report of the Directors and elect new Trustees. Thirty thousand shares of stock were represented, and out of these Mr. Sharon, as President of the syndicate, voted 28,000 the balance being in the hands of individual holders.
The Democratic leaders of Albany County are just now engaged in a quarrel which promises to result in the great discomfiture, if not the complete overthrow, of their party.
The annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Peabody Educational Fund, will be held today at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

The mysterious disappearance of little Josey Sullivan, the infant child of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Sullivan, of No. 412 Greenwich street, on Sept. 16, the publication of which will be remembered by the readers of THE TIMES, presented a problem which the Police were unable to solve, but which was made clear yesterday by a most painful discovery.

The National Association of Fire Engineers reassembled yesterday morning at Firemen's Hall, President Hendrick, in the chair. Communications from inventors of fire extinguishing apparatus and appliances, requesting permission to exhibit their inventions, were read.
According to the Cologne Gazette, the Jesuits are again urging the canonization of CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS a proposal which was first made at the time of the Ecumenical Council in 1870.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct, 5. The Journal de St. Petersbourg, with reference to the reforms proffered to the insurgents by the Sublime Porte, regards the concession of provincial representation as the best that could have been made to settle the present difficulty. It is certain to meet general approval. The Journal adds that not only ought the insurgents to accept it, but the Great Powers ought to see that it is carried out.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 5. At the session of the Circuit Court to-day a motion was made for the approval of the bond of William S. Carman, appointed by Judge Osborne Receiver of the Third Avenue Savings Bank of New-York City, which failed recently. Ex-Gov. Hoffman and M. H. Hun appeared for the motion, and Deputy Attorney General Fairchild for the people and the Superintendent of the Bank Department.
A number of steam-boats and other craft at Montreal have already gone into Winter quarters. A meeting of the creditors of the late L.W. Pond, of Worcester, Mass., has been called for this morning.
An unknown sneak-thief entered the store of A.D. Grief Co., No. 469 Broome street, on Tuesday afternoon last, and stole a piece of black silk valued at $250.

Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS has addressed a letter to the "Legal-tender Club" of this City and "to the country at large," in response, apparently, to an invitation from the club to answer Mr. SCHURZ'S speech at Cincinnati.
The renomination of District Attorney Phelps by the Republicans and anti-Tammany organization is daily growing in favor.
According to the evidence given by Warden QUINN before the Committee of the Legislative Assembly, the Tombs is one of the best-ordered prisons in the country. This was not the case a few months ago.
James Lysaght Plunkett died yesterday morning, of consumption, at his late residence, No 85 Summit street, Brooklyn. Mr. Plunkett was born, thirty five years ago, at Riding, Berkshire,...

The closing sessions of the Southern NewYork Baptist Association were held yesterday morning and evening in the Trinity Baptist Church, at Fifty-fifth street, near Lexington avenue, the Moderator, Rev. J.F. Elder, D.D., presiding.

The wharves of Stapleton, Staten Island, were the scene of an exciting contest yesterday between the employes of the Harbor Commissioners on the one side and the North Shore Ferry Company, assisted by the sailors of the New-York Yacht Club and the Police and citizens of Stapleton generally, on the other.

WORCESTER, Oct. 6. The convention of the representatives of the labor reformers of the State, held here to-day, was a very small affair. Only about forty persons were present, representing no particular constituency, except a few who had come to act for the strikers in Fall River, and these found it very difficult to harmonize, so that more than once there was a fair prospect of the convention breaking up in a row.

A meeting of depositors of the suspended Third Avenue Savings Bank was held last evening in Hitchcock's Hall, No. 355 Third avenue, directly opposite the bank. The hall was crowded, and the excitement was such that that little was gained by the meeting.

The Republican State Committee was employed yesterday in attending to business of a routine nature. Mr. Henry A. Glidden, the Secretary of the committee, is very sanguine of the success of the State ticket. The reports from all quarters are satisfactory. Letters from the various counties speak of Democratic disorganization and Republican harmony.

The trial of Joseph Frangi, an Italian, on an indictment charging him with murdering Giovanni Morelli by stabbing him, at No. 215 Hester street, on July 17, was begun yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Barrett, Assistant District Attorneys Bell and Lyon appearing for the prosecution,...

The Montreal authorities probably feel confident that there never was a more annoying corpse than that of the late Mr. GUIBORD. Since the mob barricaded the cemetery and drove away the funeral procession, a few weeks since, the authorities have not renewed the attempt at burial, but have apparently waited, in hopes that some one would succeed in stealing the corpse, and thus extricate them from their unpleasant dilemma.
Mrs. Elizabeth Wright was convicted in the Court of Sessions yesterday of killing her own infant by throwing it in a sink. She was remanded for sentence.
LONDON, Oct. 6. It now seems that the sea stove in the Montana's forecastle deck. She is otherwise uninjured. Her return was merely a precautionary measure.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 6. The following to the Associated Press is just received: FRIAR'S POINT, Miss., Oct. 5, via HELENA, 3. A.M., Oct. 6. The Sheriff of Coahoma County caused our town to be invaded this morning by an armed mob of negroes. We drove them back.
As this extraordinary campaign approaches its close the absorbing interest with which it overshadows everything else seems to grow more marked day by day.

The third day of the meeting of the American Jockey Club may be attended to-day, and, if the weather is propitious, there will be a series of excellent races. The horses stationed at Jerome Park are so numerous that the sport will be kept up to a high standard of excellence throughout the present meeting.

It is as nearly as possible four years ago since a deputation from the Committee of Seventy proceeded to Albany and obtained Gov. HOFFMAN'S sanction to the instituting of civil suits in the name of the people of the State against the Ring thieves of NewYork City.

The yacht race par excellence of the season was that of yesterday between the Resolute and Estelle. It was altogether romoved from the pleasant surroundings of delicious Summer calms, or gentle flaws of wind, or nice exacting breezes that want every stitch of canvas a yacht can carry, and a great deal more.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. The extremists controlled the Prohibitory Convention held here to-day, as was expected, and secured the nomination of a Prohibitory candidate for Governor on a cold water platform, declaring war against Mr. Rice and the Republican party of the State.
PARIS, Oct. 6. A dispatch to the Liberte says the Turkish Army has received orders to confine itself to the defensive.
The Democrats of the Eleventh District have nominated James Mackin for State Senator.

The Board of Rapid Transit have at length concluded the two most onerous and difficult branches of their labors the fixing and locating of the route and the determination of the plans on which the Rapid-transit Railway of New-York City must be constructed, with the naming of the conditions on which it shall be operated when completed, and the rates of fare to be charged.

The trial of Capt. McCullagh, of the Seventeenth Precinct, was resumed before the Police Commissioners yesterday. The charges are improper conduct and corrupt practices while he was in command of the Twenty-ninth Precinct. A large number of witnesses were examined, but their testimony did not develop any new facts. Mrs. Sophia Morice testified that she was arrested without cause on April 17, 1874, with Mrs. Jane Stephens and Mr. Tuohey.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8. The Ohio canvass closes to-morrow night with several large meetings of both parties at the most important centres of the State. The Woodford-Ewing joint debates will close at this city. At Cincinnati there will be the closing Republican rally for Hamilton County. The Democrats announce a great mass meeting at Youngstown. At Cincinnati. Senators Dawes and Morton will speak.
During the past week 239 deaths were reported in Brooklyn. Of these 9 deaths resulted from small-pox and 26 from diphtheria.

The Jewish feast of Yom Kippur was strictly observed throughout the State yesterday.

The case in which Henry Rix was indicted for murder in the first degree for fatally shooting the boy John McKenna on May 26 was resumed yesterday morning in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Barrett. Assistant District Attorney Bell, in opening the case, recited the facts already published and characterized the shooting as a brutal act of deliberate murder.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 8. Three incendiary fires on three successive nights, at collieries located in widely-separated sections of this coal region, have aroused public apprehensions of the existence of a new and dangerous course of action on the part of the secret band of desperadoes known as "Molly Maguires."

The National Association of Fire Engineers of the United States concluded its deliberations yesterday morning. President Hendricks, after calling the convention to order, thanked the members for their prompt and constant attendance at the sessions of the convention and their obedience to his rulings as Chairman.

The John L. Brown will case was again before Surrogate Hutchings yesterday. Further medical testimony was heard, and also that of a partner of the deceased, but them was little evidence of importance.
The Republicans of the Oneida, district, in common with their brethren in other parts of the State, are displaying a marked determination to ignore professional politicians and to nominate new men.

The complaint and affidavits in a second suit against William M. Tweed, involving the recovery, with interest, of over one million dollars of money plundered from the City, was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday, and Tweed was formally arrested and held to furnish $1,000,000 additional bail, making, with the bail required in the $6,000,000 suit, $4,000,000 in all.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. The new postal cards are being used at the rate of over a million per day, the aggregate number for the first eight days of issue being 11,185,000. The department is in daily receipt of complimentary notices of the quality of the cards.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. The inauguration of the Fast Mail trains between this city and New-York, and the natural competition which has been developed between the New-York Central and the Pennsylvania Road, has induced the latter to begin the transportation of passengers as well as mail in the same remarkable short time of transit.
The closing practice of the Fifth Brigade, Brooklyn, preceding the contest for the Marksman's Badge took place at Creedmoor yesterday.
There was a run upon two of the German savings banks of this City yesterday, and in both cases, it would seem, without the slightest reason.

William Thompson, of Limington, Me., celebrated his hundredth birthday on the 4th inst.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 9. To-day was the sixth and last day of the Fall meeting of the Nashville Blood Horse Association. The attendance was the largest of the week, the ladies' department being filled to overflowing.

Any one who will take the trouble to ramble over the swamps or through the woods in the neighborhood of New-York, will soon see evidence that the shooting season has begun. This period is not looked forward to with as much general interest here as it is in Europe, and it comes upon most of us almost unawares.

Rev. Mr. Pratt, of St. Mary's Church, on Castleton avenue, New-Brighton, has resigned his position as Rector, which he has held for fifteen years. The Vesiry are trying to induce him to reconsider the matter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. The Attorney General resumed his official duties to-day and was called upon by a large number of visitors.
There is a marked contrast between the art-galleries of 1875 in Cincinnati and Chicago. The difficulty is to find a single point of resemblance.

The last week of the Ohio canvass has be- gun. One week from to-day the verdict of the people will be rendered. The debaters will go to their homes or to other stages, and whether Allen or Hayes, hard money or inflation, Re- publicanism or Democracy is triumphant, the State will be relieved of an army of speechmakers and a wearying stream of talk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. Postmaster General Jewell and Acting Secretary Cowen to-day stated that the new Secretary of the Interior would probably arrive on Monday, and at once enter upon the discharge of his duties.
The number of arrests last week was 598. The evening schools will be opened to-day, and the attendance is expected to be much larger than last Fall.

The horse distemper is quite prevalent in Yonkers. Edward Connell has lost three within a short period.

The secret action of Mayor Wickham in relation to the Police Commissioners had an unexpected sequel yesterday. COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9. The joint debates between Gen. Woodford and Gen. Thomas Ewing were concluded this evening at the opera-house in this city. All available space was completely occupied, and it is said the audience numbered 2,000 people. Many were turned away from the doors.

The New-York Staats Zeitung says that it is probable there are some Democratic voters who may be disposed to "call in question the 'regularity' of Mr. BIGELOW'S nomination, and Democratic wire-pullers who do not take kindly to the 'new departure' of their party in this State, and who will gladly assist in making it a failure."
A dispatch from Belgrade received last evening contains a full summary of the address voted by the Skupochtizna, or Servian Parliament, sent to Prince Milan for his approval and signature.
The reports of the principal American and British Missionary Societies for 1875 show that the year has been on the whole a prosperous one for their work.

The expedition into the interior of Africa under Mr. Henry M. Stanley reached the shore of the Victoria Nyanza Feb. 27, 1875, after much of the suffering and peril inseparable from African explora- tion. The journey to this point from Bagamoyo was accomplished in 103 days.
LONDON, Oct. 11. The Carlist General, Saballs, goes to Switzerland. Spain intends to demand his surrender as a robber.
The Republicans of the First Assembly District of Albany County renominated Peter Slingerland yesterday.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 11. At Shenandoah up to noon to-day all was reported quiet, but affairs were in an unsettled condition, business being at a stand-still, and precautions being taken in every direction to prevent another outbreak. The situation this morning was unchanged. But one arrest was made last night by the Police, and that of a man who was out after 9 o'clock, heedless of the Deputy Sheriff's proclamation.

It will hardly be pretended that the nominations made at the Tammany Judiciary Convention last night represent the choice of the Democratic Party of this City. They are simply the names selected by one man for adoption by a packed convention elected by packed primaries and pledged to vote according to the orders of JOHN KELLY.

LONDON, Oct. 11. The English steamer Biseay, belonging to the port of Newcastle, has stranded off Jutland while on a voyage from Cronstadt to Bremerhaven. Eleven persons were drowned. The Biscay was an iron steamer built in 1872, and was owned in London.

A valuable contribution to our knowledge of the nature of Asiatic cholera has just been issued from the Government Printing Office at Washington in the shape of an exhaustive report on the epidemic which ran through several of the Southern and Western States in 1873.
Judge Wallace will open the October term of the United States Circuit Court, Civil Branch, next Monday.

During the Ohio campaign a great deal has been said about Mr. KELLEY'S system of bonds to be issued by the Government, bearing interest at 3.65 per cent., and "intercon- vertible" with greenbacks. So far as we have seen, this is the only definite scheme of finance which the opponents of the Republican Party have brought forward. Very much has been promised for it.
The Alaskas, of this City, and the Olympics. of Manhattanville, will play a game this afternoon in Melrose, and not on the Capitoline Grounds, as previously announced.

It would appear that Gen. "Baldy" Smith, while intending to help the Mayor to get rid of Commissioners Matsell and Disbecker, by offering himself as a nominal sacrifice, has actually vacated his office as a member of the Police Board. The General's blunder in this respect appears to be in keeping with the whole course of the Mayor.
Capt. Woerth and Detective Campbell closed last evening a policy shop at No. 17 Charles street, William Pickett, writer, and Thomas Glenn and Henry Small, players, were arrested.

The County Convention of the Queens County Republicans was held at the Court-house in North Hempstead yesterday afternoon. Henry W. Eastman, of Hempstead, was Chairman, with L.F. Coles, of Oyster Bay, and Andrew Manager, of Newtown, Secretaries. The nominations were made without hitch, and are as follows:
O'Connor Power, M.P., lectures this evening at Cooper Institute. Subject "Irish Members in the English Parliament."

The deep and general interest which is taken in the production of "Macbeth" at the Lyceam is a sufficient answer to the assertion that the English have lost their taste for theatrical amusements. "Macbeth " is one of the best known, and indeed hackneyed, of Shakespeare's plays.
Another Democratic County Treasurer in Ohio has run away. He stole $2,500 of the people's money.

A mass-meeting of the Republicans of the Seventh Assembly District was held last evening at the head-quarters, No. 12 University place. Early in the evening a large transparency, extending across the front of the building, and inscribed with the names of the nominees of the Regular Republicans, was lighted up for the first time and attracted much attention.
Collector Love, of Jersey City, reports the receipt of $10,529.37 in taxes and assessments last week.

State elections were held yesterday in Ohio, Iowa, and Nebraska. The indications from Ohio are of a heavy vote, in which the Republicans were large gainers on the vote of 1873, with which comparisons are made.

The Republicans have carried Ohio by at least a fair, and probably by a heavy majority. Its exact extent it is at this writing impossible to fix. That there has been some defection from the Republican ranks on the inflation issue it is impossible to deny.

At the meeting of the Board of Health yesterday Dr. Elisha Harris, Register of Vital Statistics, presented the following letter to accompany the weekly mortuary report: "The death-rate in this City was last week equal to 25.95 per 1,000 annually, and to 28.60 in the week ending Oct. 2.

A North Australian paper says that the Chinese are going in large numbers to that part of the country. There is, however, some hope that they may not become too numerous, as the native blacks have taken to eating them.

The Republican County Convention has renominated District Attorney PHELPS, and has selected JOHN K. HACKETT as its candidate for Recorder. No wiser choice could have been made than that of two candidates who can point to a record of honorable and effective service on which to base their claims for a renewal of public confidence.

PANAMA, Oct. 1. Since the arrangement was made between the Peruvian banks and the Government of that Republic affairs in general had taken on a more promising aspect. The great number of people depending on the National Treasury had ceased to complain, and the clamors of widows and orphans were hushed. Some trouble is expected to attend the elections for Presidential Electors, to be held on the l7th of October.

Hon. Joel W. Mason, Chairman of the Republican Central Committee, in calling the convention to order said: Gentlemen, in compliance with the rules governing the Republican Party in this City I have taken the liberty of calling this convention to order, and now await its pleasure.

The Senate Special Investigating Committee continued its session yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Senators Booth and Tobey being present. Commissioner Davenport conducted the examination of witnesses. During the proceedings Mr. Struble, member of Assembly from Yates County, and Miss Sands and Miss Ellen Collins, of the Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, visited the committee-room. The two ladies will appear to testify on Thursday morning.

Mr. STANLEY'S second letter is even more interesting than his first. It describes the cruise made by him in the Lady Alice along at least three quarters of the whole coast line of the Victoria Lake, and includes a map of the lake which approaches in completeness that which CAMERON has made of Tanganyika.
Mrs. Earling, a widow lady, fell down a flight of stairs in Dr. Gardiner's residence, in Bordentown, on Monday night, and broke her neck.
The Women's Congress begins its sessions in Syracuse this morning. The following is a list of the topics for papers and discussions:

A closely-contested game of base-ball was played on the Union Grounds, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, between two picked nines from the Atlantic Club, of Brooklyn, and the Mutuals, of this City. The proceeds were for the benefit of Mr. Nealy Phelps, the game-keeper.

On the morning we left Santa F the weather was clear and warm, the sky was a beautiful sapphire, with masses of immaculate white floating gently athwart it. A golden haze lay on the mountains. The people were dressed in cool linens and duck, and straw hats. The silver thread in the thermometer stretched itself into the eighties.
The following was posted in the Produce Exchange yesterday: Extract from the British Merchants' Shipping act of 1867, known as the Plimsoll act of last session of Parliament, viz.:
Senator Conkling will make his first speech of the campaign in Albany next Monday evening.
Postmaster James will have on hand to-day one million more of the new postal cards, and then will be able to fill any order for them.
It was currently rumored in well-informed political circles yesterday that mr. Frederick A. Schroeder would accept the Republican nomination for Mayor of Brooklyn.

During the week which preceded the Tilden ratification meeting, called by courtesy the Democratic State Convention, it was reported, and generally believed, in this section that the so-called Canal Ring would make a determined effort to defeat the plan of action which it was known had been arranged by the Governor.
The sale of seats for Herr Wachtel's representations at the Academy of Music, will commence to-day.

Superintendent Walling is succeeding almost beyond his most sanguine expectations in securing evidence to convict John Dolan, the man at present in the Tombs, charged with the murder of Mr. James H. Noe. Two very important links in the chain of circumstantial evidence which is slowly but surely encircling the prisoner, and which will tend strongly to secure-his conviction, were developed yesterday.
There is a balance in the City Treasury of $764,241,92, deposited in twelve city banks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. In the Court of Commissioners of Alabama Claims to-day the following business was transacted:
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12. The city election has resulted in immense Republican majorities.

United States Commissioner Shield's yesterday held for examination for alleged disobedience as sailors three of the crew of the American brig Isaac Webb. Their names are William Cunningham, James Garland, and Henry Phillips.

The State Executive Committee of the Republican Party of Mississippi has issued an address to the Republicans of that State. We make the following extract: "The mask being off, and there being no longer a motive to deceive, the present canvass opens up with unusual bitterness and severity.

The London Daily Standard of Sept. 30 prints the following: "The court-martial met again yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, and, after four hours' further deliberation, the accused and crews interested were summoned to the state cabin of the Royal Adelaide, in which the trial has taken place. On entering there were indications of the sentence about to be pronounced.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12. Scattering returns have been received from nearly every county in the State, but none are more than fragmentary. One hundred and twenty-five townships, precincts, and wards show a total majority for Hayes thus far of over 3,000. There is every indication of Hayes' election.
The Richmond (Va.) Whig is offered for sale. The Rochester Democrat has put on a new dress.

The Brussels correspondent of the Pall Mall Gazette writes to that journal on Sept. 25: "Yesterday an excursion to the lunatics' colony at Gheel was undertaken by about forty members of the International Medical Congress.

George B. Pratt, of Syracuse, residing at the St. Charles Hotel, had a pocket-book containing $100 stolen from his room. Lizzie Lester was accused of the theft, and was held to answer by Justice Bixby in the Washington Place Police Court in default of $1,000 bail.

The Republicans of the Eleventh Senatorial District, comprising the counties of Dutchess and Columbia, assembled in convention here to-day to nominate a candidate for Senator. The convention was called to order by Hon. Frank Sylvester, who nominated Perkins F. Cady, of Chatham, Columbia County, as Chairman, which was acceded to. The organization was completed, and there being no contesting delegates, the call of the roll was dispensed with.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 13. The Republican committee received the returns at the City Hall, which was crowded to its fullest capacity by 7:30. By 11 o'clock the more sanguine felt certain of the election of Hayes, and the number decreased at midnight, so that perhaps not more than six or seven hundred remained waiting for one more batch of returns.

From some points of view, it is unfortunate that there is so great an aggregation of population in the cities of the United States. According to the last census, there were seven cities with a united population exceeding 3,200,000, and fifty-three other cities each with a population at over 25,000; the whole number of persons residing in towns exceeding 25,000 inhabitants being nearly 6,200,000.

The Wilmington (N.C.) Journal prints the following letter from Gen. Stone, Secretary of War of Egypt, conveying intelligence of great improvement in the health of Gen. Colston and his probable early return to Cairo:

During the last day or two rumors have been in circulation around the City to the effect that the Governor had determined on suspending District Attorney Phelps, pending his decision on the charges preferred against that gentleman by George Wilkes. The rumors, however, could not be traced to any reliable source, and it was generally supposed that they had been put is circulation by Mr. Wilkes or his agents.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 12. At this hour (9 P.M.) a few positive figures of footings from some of the early-counted wards indicate such Republican gains as to justify the belief that even this county has gone Republican, for the Governor at least. There is a report now, and some Democrats believe it, that the Democrats have lost the county entirely.
Vice President Wilson is at the Grand Central Hotel.

The Directors of the Cheap Transportation Association, after waiting until 9 o'clock for a quorum and the presence of President Baker, convened in Parlor F of the Fifth Avenue Hotel by the election of Mr. Watrous as temporary Chairman.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Oct. 12. Fremont County gives 250 majority for the Democratic State ticket, and elects Brooks, (Rep.,) to the Legislature.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 12. To-day's election in this city has passed off in a quiet and orderly manner. Much hard work has been done on both sides, but a determination, widespread among the voters, to have the best men, without regard to party, has led to much scratching of tickets.

Speaking at the Tammany County Convention the other night, JOHN KELLY made this instructive remark: "There was no law which prevented Mr. HACKETT receiving that amount of money. But there is a moral law connected with these things that should govern men's actions, and I shall let the members of this convention judge whether he was influenced by that moral law."
The Plymouth organ concerts are to be resumed on Saturday afternoon. Mr. George W. Morgan will preside at the organ, and Miss Lasar will be the soprano.
Wheeler vs. Remington. In this case I de- sire to have the motion papers before determining upon the appointment of the Receiver.
The convention was called to order by Mr. Emanuel B. Hart, who nominated Hon. Ira B. Shafer as Chairman.

The Tammany County Convention to select candidates for Coroner and for four Aldermen at large assembled yesterday in the large hall of the Wigwam on Fourteenth street, at 3 P.M. There was a full attendance of the magnates of the organization, either as delegates or spectators.
Mr. Algernon S. Sullivan, the newly-appointed Public Administrator, took the oath of office yesterday, in the Supreme Court, before Judge John R. Brady.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 13. The Canal Board met to-day at 10:30 A.M. Senator Bradley addressed the board, calling attention to the falling down of the State duck at Corning. Commissioner Stroud replied that it would be repaired were it not for the fact that there was no money available to do it with. Mr. Bradley said if the dock was not repaired, the water would rash through, and do hundreds of thousands of dollars' damage.
John T. Ford, of Baltimore, is at the Union Square Hotel.
The Cunard steam-ship Bothnia, which left Liverpool on Oct. 2, and Queenstown on Oct. 3, reached this port yesterday, with news later by two days.

DEMOCRATS TO MEET NEXT WEDNESDAY. The Second Judicial District Liberal Repub- lican Convention met at 1:30 o'clock yesterday in the County Court-house, Brooklyn. Judge Birdseye occupied the chair and called the convention to order, but immediately afterward vacated it in favor of C.L. Brown. Mr. C. Earle acted as Secretary. Judge Birdseye, after leaving the chair, moved that the convention adjourn for one week. ...
The Albany County Republican Convention will reconvene to-day to nominate a candidate for Senator in place of Hon. Henry R. Pierson, declined.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 13 1 A.M. Special dispatches received by the State Register up to this hour indicate a Republican majority of 30,000 a least and a steady Republican gain in the Legislature. Special dispatches sent at midnight show Republican gains of a Representative in Clarke County and in Fremont County, two in Mahaska County, one in Powesheik County, and one in Ber- lin. The head-quarters of the State Committee not ...

The other day Mr. STRAKOSCH wrote a letter to the Herald, in which he very prop- erly suggested that it was just possible that he knew his own business better than his critics did, and was entitled to conduct it in the way which he thought best.

In the Times of this morning there is a paragraph at the end of the leading articles which signifies, I believe, a good deal more than lies on the surface. It is as follows: "We are authorized to state that none of the programmes which have lately appeared regarding his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales' Indian tour are accurate in their details.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13. Returns from 565 pre- cincts nearly one-third of the State show a Repub- lican gain of 5,400.
Gen. A.S. Diven, of Elmira, was yesterday nominated for Assembly by the Republicans of Chemung County.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 13. Election returns were received at the Republican Head-quarters this morning through the regular press agencies till about 4 o'clock. The gains for Hayes, over the Republican vote of two years ago, compared with the gains of Allen, indicated a majority of about 7,000 in the towns heard from, and the Republicans were confident of a majority of at least ten thousand in the whole State.

Disposition was made yesterday morning in the United States Circuit Court by Judge Benedict of the cases on the criminal calendar. When the case against the firm of H.B. Claflin Co. was called, W.H. Arnoux, one of the counsel for the de- fendants, stated that he wished to withdraw a former plea of guilty and enter a motion to quash the indictment.
Her Majesty's steamer Bellerophon, with her tender Argus, arrived at Halifax yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 13. The Admiralty minute published yesterday, exonerating Vice Admiral Tarleton and Capt. Hickley from any responsibility for the sinking of the Vanguard, also dismisses Evans, the Navigating Lieutenant of the Iron Duke. The minute has called forth much criticism by the London press.

The Brooklyn Republican City Convention met at 8 o'clock last evening in the City Assembly Rooms on Washington street. During the day a telegram was received from Mr. F.A. Schroeder and published in an afternoon paper, indorsing the nomination of Mr. E.T. Backhouse, made by the reformers in the Academy of Music on Tuesday night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 13. For the first time since 1872 the Republicans of Cleveland are this evening canonading and burning fireworks over a political victory. It is only since the pressure of anxiety has been relieved this afternoon, by reports so complete as to leave no doubt of the election of Hayes, that they have begun to realize the importance and value of their triumph.
OMAHA, Oct. 12. Kearney County The Re- publican State, judicial, and county tickets are elected by handsome majorities.

It was not until 1 o'clock this morning that the complete rout of the Democrary in Ohio could be definitely known here, but as soon as it was settled a large delegation of the leaders of the Repub- lican Party called together their friends and had a street parade, headed by Col. William B. Mann and John E. Addicks, Esq.
It is very odd that one of the conquests of the Dutch in the sixteenth century should, at this late day, be the cause of a rupture of friendly relations between Holland and a South American republic.

Although yesterday was cloudy and threatening, the attendance of spectators at Jerome Park to witness the sixth day's racing of the present meeting far exceeded that of any preceding day. There were many ladies at the club-house, and several very pretty turnouts were displaced in the field.

The Republican conventions for the nomination of State Senators and District Aldermen were held last evening in the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, and Eighth Senatorial Districts, but only a few nominations were made. It was deemed desirable in most of them to give time for consultation with other organizations opposed to Tammany Hall before any decided action should be taken.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct.14 11P.M. The Republicans have been slowly recovering today from something akin to a panic, occasioned by the events of yesterday. Returns from eighty-six counties leave no doubt of Hayes' election by 4,000 majority. Two counties to be heard from, Carroll and Wood, gave an aggregate Republican majority in 1873 of 600.
In accordance with their programme, the Board of Trade introduced last evening at the Cooper Institute to the public one of the wellknown supporters of the 3.65 heresy Gen. Ben jamin F. Butler.
Antomette Butt, aged eleven years, died at her residence, No. 167 Monroe street, yesterday, from burns accidentally received.

A very fair idea of the present attitude of the public mind abroad with reference to American credit may be gathered from the expressions of the London Times of Oct. 1. At that date the news of the adoption of the Ohio financial doctrine by the Democrats of Pennsylvania, with the explanations of its correspondents, had just reached the Times.
State Senator George B. Bradley has been renominated by the Democrats of the Twentyseventh District.

The Senate Committee engaged in the inves- tigation of the conduct of the Municipal and Countty Governments continued its sessions yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Senators Booth and Tobey present, with Commissioner Davenport counsel to the committe. During the session ex-Collector Murphy and Senator Madden, of Orange County, called upon the committee.

We believe it to be perfectly practicable for the Republicans to carry twenty out of the thirty-two Senate districts of the State. They may do better than this, but they certainly ought to be content with no less.

AUBURN, N.Y., Wednesday, Oct. 13, 1875. Three weeks ago the Democratic leaders of New-York began to make nominations for State and county offices. At that time they professed to be confident of the complete success of their ticket, and many of the "gentlemanly gamblers" among them were prepared to bet large amounts that all their candidates would be elected by at least 70,000 majority.

Thomas Sorrell, the colored stableman of Col. McDaniel, was placed on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, on an indictment for manslaughter in the first degree, is having caused the death of Samuel Peterson, another colored man, by stabbing him to the heart with a clasp knife in Thompson street, near Spring, on Sunday, the 18th of last July.

A suit case to trial yesterday in Supreme Court, Special Term, before Judge Van Vorst, in which Henry E. Fletcher sought to foreclose a $1,000 mortgage held against Charles H. Clark. This mortgage was one of three, aggregating $3,500. The defense was a cover for a usurious loan, and that there was a want of consideration in the mortgagee.

Mr. Stephen N. Simonson, who heads the above ticket, is a member of the present Board of Aldermen. He is a native of this City, and a prominent real estate agent. He was elected School Commissioner about ten time's successively, and has an enviable record as a consistent and energetic school officer.

Since the close of the late rebellion, the world has heard very little from Hon. DANIEL WEBSTER VOORHEES. During that struggle, however, he was as prominent as a man of his figure and voice could possibly be.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct.14. There has been comparatively no abatement of the public interest in the result of Tuesday's election in this State. Some doubt having arisen as to whether Hayes or Allen has been elected Governor, both the Republican and Democratic Executive Committees have been flooded with telegrams to-day from all parts of Ohio, as well as from many other States, anxiously inquiring for definite news.

ST.JOHN, N.B., Oct. 14. The Advocate says information has been received by the son of the owner of the ship New Wabeno that this vessel has been abandoned off Cape Horn, loaded with guano. No other particulars have been received, further than that the Captain had arrived at Lisbon.

A meeting of the depositors of the broken Third Avenue Savings Bank was held at the chapel of the Morning Star Sunday-school last evening, Mr. Horatio N. Hardy in the chair. The hall was uncomfortably crowded with an excited audience, which was with difficulty kept in order.
The Flyaway Base-ball Club, of this City, will visit Philadelphia on Saturday of next week, Oct. 23, where they will play a game with the Active Club, of Reading, Penn.

Moses S. Herman Co., of No. 22 Walker street, the principal member of which is a brother of A.S. Herman, who recently went into bankruptcy, have also failed, and their creditors have appointed Messrs.
COLUMBUS, Ohio. Oct. 14. The returns, considered trustworthy, from eighty-five counties, received by the Republican State Committee show a majority of 3,463 for Hayes.

Every one remembers how prolonged and intense was the cold of last Winter. Such weather had not been known in this City for many years. The East and North Rivers were bridged over by the ice; water-pipes were frozen in nearly every house in the City, and the clouds contracted a confirmed habit of snowing upon the slightest provocation, which they kept up until late in the Spring.
Alexander McCoy, a Jersey City Justice of the Peace, was arrested yesterday for committing an assault and battery on ex-Constable George F. Langworthy. He was placed under bonds to keep the peace.

It is due to truth to state that Mr. Frederick Smyth, the Tammany candidate for Recorder, was in no manner connected with the proceedings against Sweeny. John McKeon has been, and is, Sweeny's attorney and counsel. Mr, Frederick Smyth has had nothing to do with either the civil or criminal proceedings.

The conduct of the British Admiralty, relative to the sinking of the Vanguard, reminds one of the attempt made by one of Mr. Pickwick's followers to rescue him from the officers who here taking him before the Mayor of Ispwich.

The race between the Resolute, Dreadnaught, and Vesta is ended, and it will probably be set down as one of the most famous yachting contests upon record. The kings County Republican Convention met yesterday in the Assembly Rooms on Washington street, Brooklyn. It was called to order by A. J. Perry, of the Sixth Ward, who said that the Republican campaign was begun in that room the night before, when the delegates to the City Convention nominated F.A. Schroeder for Mayor.
The residence of Mr. Thomas Graham, No. 1,082 Pacific street, was entered by thieves on Tuesday last, in absence of the family, and $40 in money stolen.

A bench wariant was yesterday issued by Judge Benedict, of the United States Circuit Court, for the arrest of William J. and Thomas C. Pollock, indicted for smuggling by the last United States Grand Jury.
In the Seventh Senatorial District James W. Gerard will probably be nominated by John Kelly for Senator.

The Independent Tax-payers' and Citizens' Reform Association of Brooklyn met last evening in the Academy of Music, Ruloff Van Brunt in the chair. The Chairman of the committee appointed to wait on Mr. Backhouse to receive his decision in reference to the nomination for Mayor reported that he had an interview with Mr. Backhouse.
Mr. John McAloney, of Long Island City, is the Republican candidate for Assembly in the Second District of Queens County.

The difficult task of satisfactorily interpreting, during the progress of a two weeks' season of opera, Meyerbeer's "Iluguenots" was last evening performed by Miss Kellogg's company at Booth's Theatre. A perfect rendering of that colossal work was certainly not supplied, but the defects of the representation being confined almost entirely to the work of the subordinate personages and the orchestra, yesterday's entertainment still contained much that deserved honest praise. COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. The timely discovery of the Democratic operations in regard to Wood County destroyed the last hope of success for the inflationists. We now have authentic reports from all the counties.
LONDON, Oct. 15. There were heavy gales around the coasts of Great Britain yesterday. The telegraph has already announced the wreck of several coasters and the loss of a number of lives.

It would seem that the increase of population in and near New-York has been faster than the adaptations of the machinery of health to the numbers. We have reached a kind of sanitary crisis. Drainage has not kept pace with population.

There was a largely attended meeting of the Indianapolis. Bloomington and Western Railroad Extension bondholders at No. 20 Nassau street yesterday afternoon. Mr. Sumner R. Stone presided, and Mr. Frank Shepard acted as Secretary. The committee appointed at the last meeting made the following report:

William H.H. Rogers, of Nos. 3 and 5 College place, yesterday charged Aaron Menzesheimer with embezzlement, before Justice Duffy at the Tombs Police Court. The Prisoner was held to answer in default of $500 bail.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. Returns have been received from all the counties of the State, which are considered as correct as can be obtained until the official returns are received by the Secretary of State. These returns show Hayes' majority in the State to be 4,753. The official returns may vary this count by 300 either way.
Clayton McMichael, of Philadelphia, is at the Albemarle Hotel. Judge Milton Brown, of Tennessee, is at the New-York Hotel.

Of the six sales noticed for yesterday, Friday, Oct. 15, at the Exchange only one was consummated, namely one lot 25 by 100, on east Seventy-fourth street, north side, 98 feet east of Avenue A, sold by E.A. Lawrence Co., by order of the Supreme Court in foreclosure. E.D. Gale, Esq., Referee, for $1,800 to J.B. Leavitt.

The Republicans of Westchester County held their County Convention at White Plains yesterday. The attendance of delegates was quite large, and the proceedings enthusiastic. Senator Robertson called the convention to order and proposed Hon. Amherst Wight, Jr., for Chairman.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 15. The body of Rufus Streeter, of Washington, aged seventy, was found to-day on the roadside one and a half miles from Barre Village, completely disemboweled. The murder causes great excitement at Barre.

It will be well for the people of New-York to be on their guard against the present attempts of our new Dictator to get the entire machinery of justice into his own hands. It was stated last night by the journal which follows "TILDEN'S gonfalon," that JOHN KELLY had decided upon suspending several of the Police Justices.

An affray resulting in the death of two colored men occurred at an early hour on Friday morning, in the neighborhood of Schuetzen Park, on Third avenue, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first streets, Brooklyn. The men killed were Samuel Jackson and Henry Thompson.

Francis Conboy obtained a verdict for $250 and costs against John Wren, in the Brooklyn City Court yesterday, for an unprovoked assault in January last.

MADRID, Oct. 15. The Epoca, of this city, has an editorial article explanatory of the note recently sent to the Vatican. "The note," the Epoca says, "points to the religious condition of Europe, and makes the deduction that Spain cannot be exceptional.

The first annual examination of the nautical school-ship St. Mary's by the Council of the New- York Chamber of Commerce, took place yesterday forenoon at the foot of East Twenty-third street. A committee of the Chamber of Commerce is by law associated with the Board of Education in the...

The Assembly District Republican Conventions were held last evening. In the First, Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, Tenth, Fourteenth, Sixteenth, Eighteenth, Nineteenth, and Twentyfirst Districts the conventions adjourned without making nominations. In the others the following nominations were made:

An adjourned meeting of the Republican County Convention was held last evening at Republican Hall for the purpose of completing the nominations for the County ticket. During the day conferences were held be- tween a subcommittee of the Republican Party and a subcommittee representing the anti-Tammany Democrats who made nominations at Irving Hall on Wednesday evening last.
By this time we certainly ought to know all about Alaska, its resources, products, geographical features, climate, soil, and capabilities. Nevertheless, it is evident that we do not.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. In political circles the sensation of to-day has been the exposure of a Democratic trick for giving votes by the wholesale to Allen and securing Democratic ascendency in the State Senate.
The Grand Jury of the Court of General Sessions, having transacted all the business before them, handed in a number of indictments yesterday and were discharged by Judge Sutherland with thanks.

A French correspondent of the Manchester Examiner and Times writes to that journal: "In one of my former letters I called your attention to the irresponsible power of Commissaires de Police. I may just as well leave out politics for this day again, in order to say a few words about a far greater and still more irresponsible power placed by French law in the hands of some of the magistrates, viz., the Juges d'instruction.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 15. In the whisky cases to-day Judge Drummond overruled a motion to quash the indictment against Taft Miller, and sustained the demurrers to the plea in abatement. In the letter decision he held that it is competent for the same Grand Jury to act for the District Circuit Court even though they are sworn but once.

The indictment by the United States Grand Jury of W.J. and Thomas C. Pollock for frauds on the revenue, was briefly mentioned in yesterday's TIMES. The history of their operations, which has never been published, shown that they have defrauded the Government out of over half a million dollars in duties.

Roebling and others, and Ferdinand Delroy Longchamp, creditors of Duncan, Sherman Co., to show cause why the orders of arrest obtained by them against the firm should not be vacated were returnable yester- day morning, before Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers.

Yesterday, the time fixed by the General Term of the Supreme Court for the serving of Tweed's answer in the six-million suit expired, and yesterday afternoon, at the latest possibie moment, Tweed's counsel served their answer upon Mr. Wheeler H. Peckham, of counsel for the People, and also a notice to the Attorney General, and filed the usual affidavit of merits in the County Clerk's Office.
The suit of August Seiler against City Clerk McCullough of Hoboken, has been dismissed, the defendant proving that he was not responsible for the record of property given defendant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. The President arrived here this morning, and this being the regular Cabinet day a session was called at 12 o'clock. There were present Secretaries Bristow and Belknap, Attorney General Pierrepont, and Postmaster General Jewell. Assistant Secretary Cadwalader represented the State Department and Assistant Secretary Cowen the Interior Department.
The judges of the Cape May yacht race yesterday decided unanimously in favor of the Resolute. Controller Green paid the salaries of the school-teachers for the month of September yesterday.

The Fall Meeting of the American Jockey Club will terminate to-day, and if the weather should clear, there will be a fine day's sport. The programme promises five races, the first of which will be a free handicap sweepstakes of $30 each, with $600 added, the second horse to receive $150 out of the stakes, one mile and five-eighths.

The trial of Police Captain John H. McCullagh was resumed at Police Head-quarters yester- day, before Commissioner Voorhis, Commissioners Matsell, Disbecker, and Smith being absent. ExMayor A. Oakey Hall appeared for Capt. McCullagh, and the prosecution was conducted by Mr. McLean, counsel to the board.

Hitherto the boys and girls of this country have been, with unanimous consent, awarded the palm before all others for the absence of those qualities which elsewhere, from time immemorial, have been considered essentially to belong to youth.

Coustantine Schnur was brought before United States Commissioner Shields, yesterday, upon a charge of smuggling. There was no evidence in support of the charge, and the defendant was accordingly discharged.

On Wednesday morning a lady went down town on a shopping expedition in a hired carriage, taking her two little boys, aged six and eight years respectively, with her. In Broadway she went into a dry-goods store, leaving the boys in the carriage, and during her absence a man who was selling in dia-rubber balloons on the sidewalk approached the boys and asked the younger if he did not want a balloon.

At the Parisian Varieties the stage will be occupied this week by a grand olio entertainment. The Carlo family are still at the Olympic, and several novel scenes and songs have been added to its already numerous attractions.

The possibility that English opera may become a fixed and abiding institution in this City is not so remote now as when Miss Kellogg's excellent company was first formed. It has already had several seasons of success, and there does not appear to be any reason why these intermittent seasons should not develop into continuance and permanence.
Assemblyman Emerson E. Davis, of Whitehall, N.Y., is at the Hoffman House. Charles A. Washburn, formerly United States Minister to Paraguay, is at the Astor House.

The Pennsylvania campaign was fought in Ohio. Whether it was won and lost there will not be determined till two weeks from next Tuesday. One party stoutly maintains that it was, and another as positively declares it was not. Both parties have done little work in Pennsylvania, because both have expected that the election of Hayes or Allen would determine the choice of Hartranft or Pershing.
The arrests by the Police last week numbered 1,928. The receipts for Croton water rents and penalties last week were $17,357 93.
John Cunningham, of the Twelfth Ward, Brooklyn, was nominated for Assembly last evening by the Independent Democrats of the Third District.
LONDON, Oct. 16. The Standard this morning publishes a special telegram announcing that the Turks now hold the district of Zubei, the last refuge of the insurgents.

Steam-ship Dorian. (Br.,) McRitchie, Bordeaux Sept. 28, with mdse, and 1 passenger to Henderson Bros. Anchored at sundown: 29th, proceeded down the river and anchored in Verdon Roads; blowing a heavy gale from W., N.W.; a verp heavy sea on the bar 30th, got under way at 8:30 A.M. and proceeded on the voyage, experiencing strong winds form W.S.W. to W.N.W., with heavy head sea. Thick, foggy weather from the Banks to Nantucket.
Major Charles E. Orvis, Inspector of Rifle Practice in the Second Brigade, has received his commission.

The principal etching in the current number of this, the most valuable of the art journals, is from a portrait of an Italian nobleman of the Bescian family, by Alessandro Bonvicino, commonly known as "Il Moretto," now in the British National Gallery.
The last of the county tax sales will take place at White Plains on Wednesday. The Sixteenth Battalion N.G.S.N.Y. will parade for drill and inspection at Sing Sing on the 22d inst.

There is no doubt that to be a Coroner in this City is to pursue a profitable and, in many respects, pleasant business. The fees pertaining to the office are large and frequent, insomuch that to be a Coroner for a single term is one of the surest means of making a comfortable fortune.

The Fifth Senatorial and Aldermanic Republican Convention which nominated Hon. James W. Booth for Senater on Thursday, met again last night at the Bleecker Building in Bleecker street. The committee appointed to notify Mr. Booth of his nomination reported that after a conference with Mr. Booth he had positively declined the honor tendered him, although strongly urged to accept.
BERLIN, Oct. 16. Secretary of State Von Bulow will accompany the Emperor William to Italy in place of Prince Bismarck.

Some twenty years ago the greatest of all modern chemists called into his laboratory an American student. "Will you be good enough," said the man of science, "to taste this? Perhaps you can tell me what it is." And the philosopher carefully poured from a large vessel into a test tube about a teaspoonful of a colorless fluid.

The London Theatre, hitherto known as the Alexandra, Park street, Gloucester gate, Regent's Park, was undergoing the process of redecoration, and was to reopen on the 16th of October, under the title of the Royal Park Theatre. The managers will be Messrs.Parravicini and Corbyn and the initiatory programme will consist of Offenbach's "Genevieve de Brabant," with Miss Emily Soldene.

The remains of the Confederate General George E. Pickett are to be removed on Sunday next from Norfolk to Hollywood Cemetery, in Richmond, Va.

The fifth contest for the "Luther" badge took place at Creedmoor yesterday. The heavy rain which prevailed in the morning deterred a great many marksmen from contesting in the match, and there were only four entries. Messrs W.B.Farwell, R. Rathbune, H.S. Jewell, and A.V. Canfield. Only the first two, however, completed their scores at all the ranges.

A fire broke out in Senrick's furniture ware rooms in Albany at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. The flames were soon subdued, but considerable damage was done to valuable furniture by smoke. The loss was $20,000 on the building and stock. The insurance is $35,000.

We have favorable reports from many quarters regarding a revival of business. In Boston, especially, there is not only a better feeling, but there is positive activity. Merchandise is changing hands. Merchants find that inquiries about goods are followed by purchases. The consumers have also come into the market to supply their present wants.

There is at present some little show of activity at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. About twelve hundred men are employed, of whom between five hundred and six hundred are in the department of the Naval Constructor. These are mostly employed in the work of finishing the screw steam ship-of-war Trenton, which was begun some ten months ago, and on which work has been suspended during the past Summer.

At noon yesterday the trial of the issues in the suit of the People vs. Margaret Watson, widow and Administratrix of the Ring Auditor, James Watson, to recover a portion of the six millions stolen by the Ring, was begun before Hon. Murray Hoffman, to whom the matter had been referred by Judge Lawrence. Messrs. Charles O'Conor and Wheeler H. Peckham appeared for the people, and Mr. John H. Strahan for the defense.
The Belleville Post Office was robbed on Friday night of stamps valued at $88. The Northern Railroad depots at Norwood, Tenafly, Cresskill, and Demarest were broken into and robbed Thursday night.
There was frost in Louisiana. Friday night, as far south as Pascagoula, and yellow fever there is reported dying out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. Ex-Senator Pease had a long interview to-day with the President on the subject of Mississippi, including the causes of the difficulties, the present condition of affairs, and the remedies. The President talked freely, and said that he was much gratified that the two political parties had effected an amicable adjustment, by which a fair election would be held and peace maintained in the State.
The Political Reform Council of the Sixteenth Assembly District held a meeting in Germania Hall last evening, Mr. Philip Frankenheimer presiding.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. The United States frigate Hartford, which sailed from Lisbon Sept. 19, arrived at Fortress Monroe last night, all well on board.

SPRINGFIELD, Oct. 16. The legal, social, and political circles of Berkshire County have been a good deal stirred up to-day by the arrest of one of the leading lawyers of the county, Thomas M. Judd, of Lee, for forging the name of Elizur Smith on the back of a $1,000 note, which he got discounted at the Mahaive Bank of Great Barrington a short time since.

Coming back to Rome after two or three months passed in middle Italy, I find the languor of the Summer solstice still resting upon the population. A number of Democratic newspapers in different parts of the State, taking their cue from a distinguished New-York journal known to be in the pay of Gov. Tilden, have recently made general denials of some of the charges brought against the Democratic managers and their candidates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. Sixth Auditor McGraw has completed his annual report to the Secretary of the Treasury, showing the business operations of his office for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1875. The report exhibits a large increase in the business of that bureau in every division.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. Post Office changes for the week ending Oct. 16, 1875.

A series of forgeries perpetrated on Canadian banks, and involving, it is supposed, an aggregate of about twenty thousand dollars, were brought to light yesterday in the arraignment of three persons two men and a woman before Justice Bixby, at the Washington Place Police Court.

Some thirty citizens went out to Jackson yesterday morning to see Gov. Ames about discharging the negro Militia. At the different stations the people of Hinds joined the party, until it was swelled try 200 when arriving at Jackson. The party marched from the depot to Angelo's Hali, and there organized,. with Dr. Rice, of Clinton, as Chairman, and H.H. Moore, of Vicksburg, Secretary.
A gold watch and chain worth $120 were stolen from the residence of Mr. McNamara, No. 2,210 Fulton street, Saturday night.
Col. S.B. Hayman, United States Army, is at the Everett House. Lieut. Commander Frank Wildes, United States Navy, is at the Westminster Hotel.

The impression received by our special correspondent now in the western part of Pennsylvania is that the canvass in that State is being conducted in an efficient but quiet manner, and that in the section, at least, of which Pittsburg is the centre the financial issue will not be strongly urged by either party.
The next convention of the Suffolk County Sabbath School Association will be held in Huntington on Wednesday and Thursday next.

The telegraph has informed you that we have just passed through another Ministerial crisis, but I have many reasons for doubting that a fair account of the incident has been sent across the Atlantic. It is true that we have had what the partisan press is pleased to call a crisis, but in reality it was nothing more than a party manoeuvre that failed in its object.

LONDON, Oct. 16 12:30 P.M. The rate of discount in the open market for three months' bills is 3 cent., which is cent. below the Bank of England rate. United States Bonds, 1865s, old, 103 7/8; new Fives, 103 5/8; Erie Railway Shares, 14 ; Preferred, 30.

There has been a show of London cabs and cab-horses at Alexandra Palace. It cannot be that these animals are very ill used. Several of those exhibited had been working in the shafts of a cab over London streets for eight years, one for twelve years, one for thirteen, one for fourteen, and two for eighteen years.

There is now no doubt of the election of the entire Republican State ticket in Ohio by majorities ranging from three to eight thousand, the lower figures relating to Auditor and Treasurer of State. In the following table are given the majorities for Governor in all the counties of the State.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 17. The Pacific mail steamer Great Republic, from China and Japan, brings the following intelligence:

At Nos. 165 and 167 West Twenty-sixth street, in this City, there stands a very modest-looking building, built of brick, two stories in height, and occupying two lots of land just east of Seventh avenue. Its dimensions are 95 by 44 feet. On the first or ground floor it is fitted up for two stores, and under these are two basements, which have also been fitted up for business purposes.

In Louisiana, the other day, there was a case of Lynch law which was somewhat peculiar. A woman in the family of one Mr. SAUNDERS administered to him a solution of arsenic in a cup of water, with the intention of poisoning him. SAUNDERS did not die, but public indignation against the woman at once ran very high. She was arrested, and confessed her guilt.
