The late Miss Sally Bronson, of Watertown, N.Y., left to Trinity College a legacy of $500. The twenty-ninth annual meeting of the Connecticut State Teachers' Association will be held in Hartford Oct. 21 and 22.

At the pending election in New-Jersey no State officers are to be chosen, and the Campaign is purely a local one. Considerable interest is nevertheless manifest, because of the important duties to devolve upon the members of the Legislature about to be chosen. The adoption of the amendments to the Constitution will impose upon both branches duties of peculiar responsibility and delicacy.

The Fall Regatta of the Yale University Boat Club took place on Saturday afternoon at Lake Saltonstall, the usual place. The weather in the morning was rainy, but the sun appeared sufficiently at noon to give promise of a favorable afternoon, and most of the students were present, as well as many citizens.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming Territory, Oct. 17. Prof. Walter P. Jenney, chief geologist of the expedition into the Black Hills, and his assistants returned here yesterday, having spent five months in the Hills, and made a thorough examination of the whole country, and mapped it from Bellefourche to the south fork of the Cheyenne River.
Mr. Joseph Blumenthal will probably be nominated by the opponents of Kelly Co. for Senator in the Seventh Senatorial District.

The inhabitants of Vicksburg were never more deeply shocked than yesterday morning when the announcement was made that three negroes had been shot on Tuesday night in the city one killed outright, one wounded mortally, and the other painfully but not seriously. There was a universal condemnation of the bloody acts.
The building No. 367 Ninth avenue, occupied by Mrs. Hennessy, second-hand dealer, was damaged $300 by fire yesterday.

The Noice-Brown trover case was concluded at the Mercer County, N.J., circuit of the Supreme Court, Saturday, and resulted in a verdict for the plaintiff, with damages to the amount of $1,887 16. A brief outline of the case may be given here. The defendant Brown induced the plaintiff, Miss Noice, to accompany him to Brazil, in April, 1873, under promise of marriage.

Mr. Amos Townsend, Cashier of the National New-Haven Bank, completed his fiftieth year of continuous service in its employ on Friday last. For eighteen years he has been the sole survivor of all his original associates in the bank. In a letter to the President, written on Friday, he says: "From my entrance into the bank in 1825 to September, 1865, I had not been absent from ill health...
The Democrats of Buffalo have nominated State Senator Albert P. Laning for Mayor. Mr. John I. Baker has accepted the Prohibition nomination for Governor of Massachusetts.

The Commission of Engineers, appointed in reference to the water supply of Philadelphia, has recently made a report. The object for which the commission was constituted was the consideration of measures to obviate the danger of injury to the quality and of inadequacy in the quantity of water.

The Pandora, which arrived at Portsmouth on Saturday last, began her explora- tions in the Arctic regions on the 13th of August, on which date she sailed from the little Greenland settlement of Upernavik. Her voyage has thus been remark- ably short in comparison with those of pre- vious Arctic expeditions, but it was not without important results.

John Kelly's district was awakened last night by a largely attended mass-meeting of antiTammany Democrats, held at Glass' Hall, East Thirty-fourth street. From 8 o'clock until near 11 the hall was filled with a crowd of working-men, who had assembled at the call of the Eighteenth Assembly District Democratic Committee to hear a review of the local political situation, and to ratify the Republican and anti-Tammany Demo- cratic nominations.

The speech of Senator CONKLING at Albany, last evening, is reported in full in our columns this morning, and it will be read with interest by those in this or other States who desire to see a full review of the merits of the two parties as they appear in New-York.

Yesterday was the closing scene of the Fall meeting at Jerome Park, the races of last Saturday having been postponed until Monday. Commissioner Davenport conducted the examination, which related entirely to the affairs of the Coroners' Office, and virtually concluded the investigation of that board.

BOSTON, Oct. 23. The failure of Robert Fitton, woolen manufacturer, proprietor of the Spring Mills at Cavendish, Vt., is occasioning no little excitement in the wool trade of this city. His Boston indebtedness is quite large, the result mainly of purchases of wool in this market. The total liabilities are about $140,000.
A representative of THE TIMES had the fol- lowing interview yesterday with Counselor John H. Strahan, in relation to Mr. Allen's statement about District Attorney Phelps and the Norton case.

The Republican Judiciary Convention of the Fourth Judicial District met last evening in Concordia Hall, in Avenue A, and John Lalor having declined the nomination, John A. Dinkel, the AntiTammany nominee, received the unanimous vote of the convention as their candidate for Civil Justice.

Neutral tints and coarse mixed goods are to be in favor this winter. Skirts will continue to be of plain goods, and cuirasses and tuniques of wool, silk, and velvet. The richest article made is figured velvet, in dark shades, on a light Java satin ground; thus, a bronze-colored faille skirt may have three scarf aprons bordered with bias bands of velvet, in checked bronze, on a burned corn-colored brocatelle ground.

This race is commonly looked forward to with great interest from the fact that many of the Derby horses for the next, year make their first appearance on this occasion.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 25. Dr. Thomas arrived at Vineland from Philadelphia on the 10:30 o'clock train this morning, and proceeded to the residence of Mr. Carruth's family, where the body of the deceased still lay.
A large and enthusiastic Anti-Tammany demonstration of the working men of the Fourth Senatorial District was held at Brookes' Assembly Rooms, in Broome street, last evening.

A day or two since, as a lad was walking rapidly, down Third avenue in the early twilight, he was suddenly thrown headlong to the ground. He rose evidently in great pain, with his hands torn, his trousers cut open at the knee, and limped off in a way that showed that his knee-joint was hurt if not seriously injured.

The suit of Samuel M. Archer against the Ocean National Bank for the recovery of $10,000 alleged to have been on special deposit, and stolen when the bank was robbed in 1869, was again before Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday morning.

WHAT CHEER RANGE, GREENWOOD, R.I., Oct 25. The opening of the range of the Rhode Island Rifle Association took place to-day at the What Cheer Range. The ground chosen by the association is admirably adapted for rifle practice, be ing about seven miles from Providence and on the line of the Stonington Railroad. The range is almost a level surface, 1,400 yards long by 400 feet wide.

Mr. Albert Daggett, the Republican candidate for Sheriff of Kings County, is making a splendid canvass. He has been Under Sheriff for three years during the adminstration of a Sheriff who saved the people $25,000 a year. Mr. Daggett is courteous and obliging, and being already well acquainted with the duties of the office, would make an excellent Sheriff.
LONDON, Oct. 25. Between the 14th and 22d of this month fifty-five persons lost their lives by shipwreck on the eastern coast of Scotland, between Pittenweem and Peterhead.
Dr. E.W. Thompson was nominated for Assembly last evening by the Republican Convention of the Fourth Assembly District.

LONDON, Oct. 25. The Cologne Gazette reaffirms the statement that the Crown Prince of Germany will visit the Centennial Exposition at Philadelphia, and says the eighteen-gun corvette Elizabeth will convey him to America.

John Dolan, the man indicted on the charge of having murdered Mr. James H. Noe, the Greenwich street brush-maker on Aug. 22, was arraigned for trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday before Judge Lawrence.

The contest which has for some days past been going on between the rival Democratic factions in Monroe County has gained increased strength and bitterness within the past twenty-four hours.

A mass-meeting of the colored Republican citizens of the Fifth Assembly District was held last night at the Republican Head-quarters, No. 185 Spring street, under the auspices of the colored Veteran Guard of the City and County of New-York, to ratify the nominations of the Republican Party. The hall was crowded to its utmost capacity, and the greatest enthusiasm prevailed.

The second Fall trotting meeting of the Prospect Park Fair Ground Association began yesterday, and notwithstanding the cold and dreary weather there was a respectable attendance of spectators.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 26. The Baptist State Pastoral Conference commenced in the Baptist Church in this place this morning. The conference was called to order by Prof. J.H. Gilmore, of Rochester, and after prayer by Rev. A. Coit, of Wellsville, Rev. A.S. Patton, D.D., of New-York, was chosen Chairman pro tem.
A Republican mass-meeting was held last evening at the Bleecker Buildings, in the Ninth Assembly District.

The trial of John Dolan upon the charge of murdering James H. Noe was resumed at 10:45 o'clock yesterday morning in the Court of Over and Terminer, before Judge Barrett. Several lady relatives of Mr. Noe, in deep mourning, sat in the front row of seats occupied by witnesses, facing the jury.

The Brooklyn Tabernacle was crowded to overflowing yesterday morning and an increase of fervor was manifested during the proceedings, which were opened by the singing of "I waited for the Lord, my God." A number of requests for prayer were then handed up and read. They were from parents for children, sisters for brothers, and friends for friends; asking for conversion from infidelity, or drunkenness.
A choice collection of modern paintings by Hart, De Haas, and other well-known artists, have been placed on view at No. 95 Fifth avenue, and will repay a visit. They are now open to the public.
Returns from Colorado show that the Constitutional Convention in that Territory has been carried by the Republicans, who have elected a majority of the delegates.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday in the private office of the Mayor, and effected further revision of the budget as submitted by the various departments.
The legislation affecting the City which was introduced last Winter was controlled by the New-York delegation in the Assembly, and that was in its turn controlled by JOHN KELLY.

PANAMA, Oct. 17. The national troops, so long and anxiously expected and feared, arrived from Bogota on the 11th inst., at Aspinwall, in the steam-ship Henry Chauncey. They number 400 men, under the orders of Gen. Camargo, the commander in chief of the Atlantic forces of the Army of Colombia. The troops were sent across to Pana- ma and arrived here in the evening.

The inauguration of Rev. Dr. Cyrus D. Foss as President of Wesleyan University occurred today. Dr. Foss delivered an inaugural address of considerable length, saying, at the outset, that he should consider collegiate education in a single but most momentous aspect.

On the assembling of the Board of Police yesterday Commissioner Smith made a personal explanation regarding his conduct at the meeting of the board on Monday, from which the reporters were excluded. He said that his attention had been called to an article in THE TIMES of yesterday.
That inflation is no longer a real issue in the present canvass is an opinion which it is much more pleasant than safe to hold.

The Fox-Morrissey contest for the Senator- ship in the Fourth District grows hourly more and more exciting and enthusiastic, the feature of its progress being, however, that all the excitement and enthusiasm seems to be with Morrissey.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. Virginia City, Nevada, was visited by a terribly destructive fire to-day, and in a few hours was nearly destroyed. The fire broke out about daylight in a dwelling on A street, near Taylor, a point in the southwestern limit of the business and thicklysettled portion of the City.

The trial of Col. Robert Des Auges, late Deputy Collector in the Custom-house, for alleged complicity in frauds on the Government, was begun yesterday morning in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Benedict.
The trial of the suit against the Ocean National Bank was resumed yesterday morning before Judge Wallace in the United States Circuit Court.
One of the largest and most important AntiTammany mass-meetings of the present campaign was held last night at Germania Hall, West Thirtysixth street, in the Fifteenth Assembly District.
The trial of Capt. John H. McCullagh, of the Seventeenth Precinct, was resumed before Com- missioners Matsell, Voorhis, and Disbecker yesterday.

The race between the Mohawk and Daunt- less, which came off yesterday, must be esteemed as one of the keenest in excitement, briskest in adventure, and closest in results of any which have occurred in these waters.

LONDON, Oct. 26. The Official Gazette of this evening announces that Parliament has been further prorogued to the 15th of December. It will then probably be prorogued again to the latter part of February, the usual time for the opening of the sessions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. The Post Office Department proposes to run a Fast Mail train over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, between Baltimore, Washington, and Chicago.
Massachusetts now has 351,066 voters. Hon. Cassius M. Clay is to take the stump in Mississippi for the Democrats.

This morning, before leaving Harrisburg, I met Senator Wallace at Bolton's Hotel, the home of all Democratic magnates when in the State capital. The Senator is making a more active canvass than any other Democrat in the State, and is showing qualities as a politician that cannot fail to place him ahead of Sam Randall as the leader of the party.

About five thousand circulars, inclosed in unsealed envelopes, each bearing a one cent stamp, and addressed to persons residing in this City, were left at the Post Office yesterday afternoon by a small boy.
PANAMA, Oct. 17. Ecuador is taken up with the elections for President, but no special disturbances have been reported.
PANAMA, Oct. 17. Attention in Central Amer- ica seems takes up with promoting the union of Central America, to which the most of them seem disposed, except Costa Rica.
Harry Genet's Harlem house was sold yesterday at auction, and purchased by the Charlick estate for $70,000. Particulars will be found in the real estate column.

A mass-meeting of Republicans took place last evening at the City Assembly Rooms in Washington street, Brooklyn, for the purpose of indorsing the State and local tickets. The attendance was very large. The meeting was called to order by Mr. Jacob Cohen, and Mr. Joseph Reeves was made Chairman.

Another day was spent yesterday in the trial, in the United States Circuit Court, the suit of Samuel M. Archer against the Ocean National Bank, to recover an alleged special deposit of $10,000, stolen at the time of the robbery of the bank in 1869.

In the Marine Court, General Term, yesterday, before Judges Shea, Spaulding, and McAdam, an appeal in the case of Joseph Ross against Robert Finan was argued. This was an action from a judgment ordered by Judge Alker, at the Trial Term in June last, for about one thousand dollars in favor of the plaintiff against the defendant.

Mr. Joseph R. Thomas, who, after much urging, has accepted the Republican nomination for Assembly in the Seventh District of Kings County, is in every way fitted for the position. Large business interests, which take up much of his time, made Mr. Thomas hesitate at first, but these he has concluded to sacrifice, to some extent, for the honor of serving the people in the State Legislature.

The excitement caused by the failure of the Ottoman Government to meet its obligations has not yet abated, and all foreign stocks, our own alone excepted, have suffered to a certain extent. The first feelings of anger and disappointment have given place to feelings of the deepest indignation against the men who profited by this piece of dishonesty to make enormous fortunes.
The Common Council of Bayonne requires $97,000 to carry on the city government next year. Eugene Bateman, a watchman on the Erie Railway, was run over at the tunnel yesterday, and was badly hurt.

The trial of John Dolan for the murder of James H. Noe was concluded in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday. At 10:30 o'clock, the hour for opening the case, the witnesses and jury had taken their places, and a few minutes later Judge Barrett ascended the bench.

The Seventh Senatorial District Republican Convention assembled last evening at No. 457 Fourth avenue to nominate a candidate for State Senator in the district, which comprises the Eleventh, Fifteenth, Sixteenth, and Eighteenth Assembly Districts. Mr. Seymour A. Bunce presided, with Mr. A.S. Bugbee as Secretary.

The Assembly Investigating Committee on Crime met yesterday in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen, Mr. T. Cooper Campbell presiding. Mr. Desser and Mr. McGowan, of the committee, were also present, with Mr. Townsend, their counsel. Testimony was given in regard to matters connected with the Excise Department and on other matters of minor importance.

We are told that we must submit to be "bossed;" that there is no help for us, but that we must meekly stretch out our necks, and take and bear the yoke laid upon us by the heavy hand of some Municipal master. It may be so.

On the pay-roll of the Mayor's office is the name of one John D. Newman. He is certified to by the Mayor as being employed in the office of the latter in the public service at a salary of $1,500 per annum. He has, on the certificate of the Mayor, been paid by the Controller his salary up to and in- cluding the month of September last.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct., 26. A special dispatch to the Call from Virginia City says that the destruction of the city was owing to the bad management of the engineer of the Fire Department at the beginning of the conflagration. The fire started in an undertaker's establishment on B street, spreading to adjoining livery stables. Streams of water were turned upon the stables, allowing the flames to communicate to the county buildings.

An enthusiastic ratification meeting was held at Rose Hill Hall, at Second avenue and Twentyfourth street, last evening, under the auspices of the Young Men's Republican Club of the Sixteenth Assembly District. Mr. Thomas Bettridge presided, supported by a number of well-known residents of the district.

The regular weekly meeting of the Thirteenth Assembly District Republican Association was held last night at Liberty Hall, West Sixteenth street, Col. John W. Marshall in the chair. The names of fifty-eight new members were proposed for election, and stirring addresses were delivered by Isaac Dayton and Sylvester R. Kehoe.

Charles H. Reilly ran for Assembly in the Twentieth Assembly District on a split Tammany ticket at the last election. He gave Dr. Feodor Mierson a note for $500 to be used to help to carry the district. The note was not paid, and Dr. Mier- son sued Reilly to recover its amount.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 27. Hon. Roscoe Conkling delivered one of the best political addresses ever heard in Western New-York at St. James Hall, in this city, this evening. He spoke for nearly three hours, and was listened to with the greatest attention by upward of 3,000 persons. The Senator commenced his speech by referring to the early history of the Republican Party and rapidly sketching its many noble acts.
Mrs. Sarah Wilson, the mother-in-law of Dr. William D. Wood, of Jamaica, died at his residense on Tuesday night, aged ninety-two years.

The trial of Deputy Collector Col. Robert Des Anges, upon an indictment charging him with complicity in frauds upon the Government, was continued yesterday morning in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Benedict.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. Last Spring the Court of Claims, in the case of the Union Pacific Railroad Company against the United States, decided as its conclusions of law that the railroad company should recover the one-half of its transportation accounts against the United States, and that the counter claim of the United States should be dismissed.

The owners of the Montana have produced as a witness in their behalf a sea Captain who was a passenger on board the steamer during her recent attempt to cross the Atlantic, and whose story is intended to show that the Montana is a good sea-boat, and her commander a skillful seaman.
An unknown man, supposed to be a tramp, was run over and killed on Wednesday night on a branch road of the Morris and Essex Railroad, at Newton.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 27. The Pacific Stock Exchange has started a subscription for the Virginia City sufferers. It expects to raise $4,000 or $5,000. F, Babcock, and other prominent citizens.
The trail of Deputy Collector Col. Robert Des Anges for alleged complicity in the silk frauds on the Government was continued yesterday morning in the United States Circuit Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company submitted to the Post Office Department to-day a schedule which was approved, providing for two lighting-mail trains daily, instead of one as heretofore, between Baltimore, Washington, and Chicago. The service is to begin on Monday next, and will shorten the present schedule one day's time for all points west of the Mississippi River.
Gen. Stewart L. Woodford is to speak in Faneuil Hall, Boston, on Monday evening.

Many years ago there existed a variety of Irishman known as the "United Irishman," and so called apparently for the Hibernian reason that he belonged to a society which divided all Ireland into two hostile political camps. The "United Irishman" held his meetings, accomplished his shindies, was betrayed by his united associates, and having thus fulfilled the purpose of his being, became extinct, and other varieties of united disunionists flourished in his stead.

Alexander A. Johnson, successor to the late Lewis B. Woodruff as Judge of the Second Judicial District, will take the oath of office today at 11 A. M., in the United States Circuit Court, Room No. 43 Post Office building.

Those of our readers who were in California and Nevada before the completion of the Pacific Railroad will recall, as one of the most original scenes of that singular country, the appearance of "Virginia City."

Messrs. Field and Deyo, counsel for William M. Tweed, served yesterday on Mr. Wheeler H. Peckham, the representative of Attorney General Pratt, an amended answer in the six million suit against their client, the amended answer being served under the same protest made by them at the time of serving the original answer that sufficient time had not been granted for appeal from the action of the General Term.

Any voter who will take the trouble to ascertain what officers are to be elected this Fall, and what will be their general powers and duties when elected, will find the canvass freed from a good deal of the confusion which the extraordinary claims of the Democratic Party have brought into it.

Fairfield Trask, butter merchants, of No. 150 Chambers street, notified their creditors yesterday that they were in difficulty. A meeting of creditors was subsequently held, at which an extension was gives of thirty, sixty, and ninety days. The firm stated their liabilities at $40,000, and showed merchandise assets amounting to $60,000. Mr. Fairfield is President of the American Exchange, and the firm has a high standing in the business.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 28. The Virginia division of the Association of the Army of Northern Virginia, Gen. William H.F. Lee, President, held its annual meeting to-night in the Capital. The attendance of ladies and gentlemen was large, among them being Gov. Kemper, Mrs. Stonewall Jackson, and other distinguished personages.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 28. The Evening Journal to-day contains the following: "The statement of Gov. Tilden's approval of the award of $55,000 on Willard Johnson's contract, and of his promise to let it become a law, having been denied, and Delos De Wolf having written a letter reaffirming the statement, all its essential points are now admitted in the article, authorized by the Governor, in the Argus.

The House of Bishops (Protestant Episcopal) of the United States is holding a special meeting at Grace Church, called for the election of a Bishop for the new Church of Mexico and to fill vacancies caused by the death of Bishop Williams, of China, and of Bishop Auer, of Africa.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 28. The first annual prize meeting of the Rhode Island Rifle Association closed to-day. The weather was cold and the wind strong.

Between 6 o'clock on Wednesday evening and 8 o'clock yesterday morning the store of L.B. Biasse Co., importers of fancy goods, situated on the second floor of the building Nos. 425 and 427 Broome street, was entered by burglars and robbed of property valued at over $5,000. The building mentioned is situated on the south-east corner of Broome and Crosby streets, with an entrance on both streets.

The Board of Apportionment reassembled yesterday for the purpose of considering the estimates of the departments and bureaus for 1876. Each was taken up in the order in which it appeared on the general budget. The first reached was that of salaries of the clerks of the Board of Aldermen, for which $20,000 was asked.

Mr. Henry L. Clinton has served so many political factions that his power to benefit or to injure any cause has been pretty thoroughly used up. Mr. Clinton is one of the disappointed aspirants for the Kelly nomination for District Attorney, and probably feels the disappointment as keenly as he does the poor success of his efforts at defending Richard Croker, to which that disappointment is mainly due.

The yachting of the season may be fairly presumed to have been brought to a termination with the Cape May race between the Dauntless and Resolute. As a race in the proper acceptation of that term, involving doubtful issues and alternating chances, it cannot be esteemed as of much account, but as an instance of splendid sailing on the part of the winning yacht, the Dauntless, it must come within the description of phenomeual.

The interest in favor of Morrissey against John Fox for the Senatorship of the Fourth District is growing stronger. John H. Palmer, residing at French's Hotel, reported at the Central Office yesterday that on Thursday evening while he was attempting to get on board car No.15, of the Third Avenue Line, at the corner of Bowery and Grand street, he was as- saulted by two thieves, who robbed him of his pocket-book, containing notes, checks, and valuable papers and $769 in currency. No clue to the thieves has been obtained by the Police.

The Brooklyn photographer who sued for the value of seventeen negatives, all purporting to represent one and the same sitter, and all rejected by the latter as being unsatisfactory, has won his case. YOKOHAMA, via SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. The events in Corea point to the possibility of speedy hostilities. The Japanese Government is still silent. A Japanese man-of-war was fired upon from a Corean fort near the capital, and, according to a report which is considered authentic, though it is not yet fully confirmed, a landing was effected, and the fort and neighboring village were destroyed. The results and the determination of the Government are anxiously awaited.

The examination in the matter of the will of Isaac Merrit Singer was resumed before Surrogate Coffin in White Plains yesterday. Mr. Singer left something by will to almost all of his children, but of the five women with whom he had lived, Isabella E. Singer, the last, was the only one to whom he left anything.

The new Erie and Chicago through line, via the Atlantic and Great Western, Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati, and Indianapolis, and Baltimore and Ohio extension, will go into operation on Monday. The trains from this City will leave Jersey City at 9:15 A.M. and. 7:15 P.M. each day, and will reach Chicago at 9 P.M. and 8:30 A.M. respectively.

Hon. Francis E. Spinner, the veteran United States Treasurer, and nominee for State Controller, was born in German Flats now Mohawk this State, on Jan. 21, 1802. He was educated chiefly by his father, a German minister of high standing. His early business career was in the capacity of executive officer of the Mohawk Valley Bank, which position he held for twenty years.
EX-Secretary Boutwell spoke at a Republican meeting in New-Bedford, Mass., on Tuesday evening, most of his remarks being devoted to the national finances.

The House of Bishops adjourned sine die at 7 o'clock last night, having been in session throughout the day. The principal business transacted was the election of Dr. Schereschewsky, Bishop of China, and Rev. William H. Clarke, of Augusta, Ga., as Bishop of Africa. Samuel L.J. Scheres- chewsky, D.D., the Bishop elect to China, is a native of Poland, and was originally a Jew.

The 2d of October is the anniversary of the Roman Plebiscite. In 1870, twelve days after the Italian occupation. the liberated citizens were called to the polling booths, and, according to the register. 45,000 male adults gave their voices in favor of the abolition of the temporal power of the Pope and union with the kingdom of Italy.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 31. A severe easterly rain-storm visited this city yesterday, continuing nearly all night, with a high wind after midnight. The sea was very high in the harbor, interfering with the ferry-boats, most of which entirely suspended trips after midnight. No damage to vessels in the harbor has been reported. The gale was severely felt all along the coast to Rockland, Me.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2. The State has gone overwhelmingly Republican, but the returns received up to midnight are very meagre. The exact extent of the victory cannot be stated.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 2. B. Platt Car- penter, Republican, for Senator, is elected by an estimated majority of 5,000 a gain of nearly nine thousand. He carries this city by nearly fourteen hundred and the county of 3,000. This was owing to his popularity throughout the district.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 2--8:30 P.M.--One hundred and ninety-one towns have been heard from. Rice (Rep.) has 46,958; Gaston, (Dem.,) 43,136; Baker, (Prohibitionist,) 5,180; Phillips, 193; Adams, 1,139.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 2. Trustworthy information, obtained from Democratic as Republican sources, leaves no doubt that the Republicans have elected a good working majority in the Senate. It is probable that the lower House of the Legislature will also be Republican. In this district the Republicans have gained a truly remarkable victory. Hamilton Harris has been elected Senator by at least 200 majority.

The Democratic leaders in Pennsylvania probably realize this morning that they made a mistake in following their Ohio brethren in trying to win votes by assailing the national credit. Inflation and repudiation have lost them the State. Last year, for the first time in eight years and the second time in eighteen years, the Democrats carried Pennsylvania by a small majority.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. The election in this county to-day was one of the most remarkable ever held here in point of interest taken and maintained throughout by the honest and law-abiding business portion of the community, especially here in Chicago.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. The result of the election in this State is a Republican victory by between 6,000 and 7,000 majority. The vote has been small and, as was anticipated, there has been a vigorous scratching of ballots in every section. Two hundred and thirty-eight towns give Rice 72,000, against 66,000 for Gaston.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. The returns received here up to 1:30 o'clock this morning have been exceedingly meagre. The leaders of both parties claim the State by a small majority. The Democrats are despondent and quiet, while even at this hour the streets are filled with rejoicing Republicans.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 2. Magee, Republican, for Senator in Union County, has 153 majority in the Second District of Plainfield; Republican gain, 60. Vail, for Assembly, has 134 majority in the same district; Republican gain, 10.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 2. Fowle and Simpson, Conservatives, are elected to the House of Delegates by about 250 majority. In London, Matthews and Carter, Conservatives, are elected. Sinclair and Clanghton, Conservatives, for the Senate, are elected in the First District over Mckenzie and Gray, Independents.

From all the States which held elections on Tuesday, the returns which continue to come in show that the anticipations of a Republican victory have been fully realized. It is not only a victory but a great and sweeping one. Everywhere the Republicans report heavy gains. In some places the large Democratic majorities of last year have been changed to the Republican side of the column; in others, they have been reduced almost to nothingness.

PANAMA, Oct. 21. Some serious news up to the 14th has reached here from San Juan del Nerte, Nicaragua, where robberies, gambling, and riots seem to have been the order of the day. All through the month of September last many houses had been robbed, and the Police were quite at fault as to the perpetrators of the robberies.

A fate long feared by all has befallen Virginia. Tuesday morning at 5:30 the fire began in a small lodging-house kept by Kate Shay, alias Crazy Kate, a woman of ill repute. A neighbor saw the unusual light, entered the house, and found the room next to Kate's in flames.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4.?Rear Admiral Almy, commanding the naval forces on the North Pacific station, reports to the department under date of Honolulu, Sept. 25, that he would leave that port on the flag-ship Pensacola on that day for Lower California and the west coast of Mexico. The result was quite satisfactory, as the entire line gave evidence of steady, noticeable, and substantial improvement, fully justifying the commendation bestowed, in our report of 1874, upon the General Superintendent and his several assistants.

It is now twenty years since the Home Government gave to this colony what is somewhat grandly called "an independent Constitution." One of its salient features is the presence of a viceregal Governor, usually selected from the nobility of England, and a man who has been trained in the military or civil service of his country. His appointment is made by imperial authority for a term of seven years.

The elections just passed into history developed some wonderful changes, prominent among which stands the voice in Columbia and Dutchess Counties. These counties, forming the Eleventh Senatorial District, the localities which for the past few years have been the scene of hotly-contested political battles. Last year the Democracy carried Dutchess by a majority of 3,413, and Columbia by a majority of 1,346.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 9. The annual reunion of members of the Pennsylvania Legislature prior to 1850 will take place to-morrow at 12 o'clock in the ball of the House of Representatives. WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. The report of Supervising Architect Potter has been completed and given to the Secretary of the Treasury. It begins by referring to the public buildings in course of construction when Mr. Potter assumed charge of the office, and gives an account of the general condition of them, in alphabetical order, together with the total amount of the appropriations, the total amounts expended to Sept. 30, 1875, and balance remaining in the Treasury.

It is suspected that the stuff was not oil at all, but naphtha or gasoline, as it was shipped to a gas-light company in Galveston.

JOYCE, one of the active agents of the St. Louis whisky ring, was sentenced the other day to three years and a half in the Penitentiary. This man had served in the rebellion as a Colonel, and he was, at the time his crime was committed, a Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue.

An inquiry which our correspondent has made into the causes of the Republican defection in Suffolk County, at the recent elections, shows that the free use of money by the Democrats, and the obstinacy of the Temperance or "Prohibition" Party, fully explain all that happened adverse to us in that particular locality.

An important meeting of bank Presidents and Cashiers was held in the Continental Building, on Montague street, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, for the purpose of considering the propriety of reducing the present rate of interest. The meeting was a secret one, but some of the gentlemen who participated were of opinion that no harm would result from making the proceedings public.
CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, Nov. 17. The bark Katie McDonald, ashore here, has been condemned and will be sold on Saturday next he 20th inst.

The financial circles of London have for several weeks past been agitated by controversy between the London Times and Hour newspapers and the so called Co-operative Credit Bank, growing out of the attempt of the latter institution to float a gold loan of 500,000 sterling in favor of a certain remote, and to the vast majority of the financial world hitherto unheard of, company, the Keokuk and Kansas City Railroad.
Erastus Corning, of Albany, is at the Gilsey House.

Now that GUIBORD is finally buried, it is suddenly found out that no one takes any further interest in his bones. Those who were most determined that he should be safely buried assert that in all probability his grave will be robbed at an early day, but they evidently care very little whether it is robbed or not.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. To-day Mr. Riddle, in the Criminal Court, called attention to the case of W.S. King, indicted for perjury in connection with the Pacific Mail subsidy. He stated that early in the term the case had been continued in consequence of Col. Irwin being in Europe. Mr. Irwin was now in this country, and his attendance could be secured, and Mr. King was anxious for a speedy trial.

The Worcester (Mass.) Spy says: "The great November shower of 'falling stars' or meteors cannot be expected this year. It comes once in about thirty-three or thirty-four years and appears about the 12th, 13th, or 14th of November for three years in succession, the shower of the first year being much more brilliant than the others.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 18. The joint legislative committee to investigate alleged canal frauds met at the Appraisers' office this morning; present, Senator Cole, Assemblyman Seward, and their counsel, Henry Smith and Rufus W. Peckham. Several witnesses were examined touching the Otisco Lake Dam, the measurements of the lake, and the construction of the dam.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 18.--A frightful accident occurred last night on the Charlotte, Columbia and Augusta Railroad, near Pine House, about twenty-five miles from Augusta. After the regular passenger train left Columbia, yesterday afternoon, for Augusta, it was followed by a train of empty cars. The two trains traveled at the rate of about twenty miles an hour, one following close on the other.

The following is a synopsis of the work done during the past season by Major Powell's exploring party. Major Powell has had but small appropriations, and has kept but a small party in the field, but he has accomplished a great deal, and his work is all done with the most painstaking efforts at scientific accuracy.
Small-pox is decreasing, but a slight increase of cases of diphtheria is reported by the Health Board.
The Jersey City and Albany Railroad has suspended operations.

This is not because the City of Brotherly Love is so unaccustomed to enterprises of great pith and moment that the Quaker heads are easily turned. Those who deride the brave old city may give it that turn if they choose.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Nov. 18. The brig Chance, ashere at Lambert's Cove, was hauled off to-day and towed to this port. She has about fifty tons of lignumvitae and fustic on board. The balance of the cargo was discharged and brought here. The steam pump is used to keep the vessel free of water until she is hauled on the marine railway.

The members of the Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity had a reunion dinner last night at Delmonico's, Fifth avenue and Fourteenth street. About one hundred members representing all the leading colleges in the United States, were present, and rendered the occasion one of the most pleasant of the season.

Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning Leonard Raden, of No. 174 Bank street, heard a strange noise proceeding from the office and workshop of John H. Hessman, at No. 63 Morton street. Going to the place, he saw two burglars coming out of the building, one of whom fired a pistol shot at Raden. Both men then ran off, and made their escape.

Stimulated by the universal applause which greeted the recent transit of Venus across the sun, the moon has determined to show that she can perform feats of the same general character with quite as much skill as Venus or any other provincial star. No just person will be disposed to deny to Venus all the credit that she deserves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. Gen. A.G. Lawrence, of Rhode Island, and A.H. Ashby, of Nebraska, arrived in Washington and presented to the Secretary of the Interior the report signed by themselves and associates as Commissioners to negotiate with the Sionx in reference to the Black Hills country.

The Garnier tournament opened yesterday with a game between A.P. Rudolphe and William Sexton. In the betting the odds were in favor of Sexton. Rudolphe won the lead, but failed to carom. Sexton made 4, and then a nought fell to each. In his third inning Rudolph made 17. His second storke was a short draw, but it was necessary to cause the object ball to takes three cushions to get it back in position.

Martin, of the opposition line of ferry-boats to Staten Island, was almost totally destroyed by fire yesterday afternoon while making the trip from her landing at Pier No. 8, North River, to the Stapleton landing on Staten Island. The business session of the annual meeting of the National Woman's Suffrage Association opened yesterday at 10:30 A.M., Col. T.W. Higginson, of Newport, presiding. The attendance, including a few gentlemen, consisted of 154 delegates, representing eleven States.

The World states that JOHN KELLY has begun a libel suit against THE TIMES, and speaks in rather a pathetic manner of the heartless way in which poor, meek, inoffensive KELLY has been "vilified." The attorneys representing JOHN KELLY have also managed to get in a little puff of themselves of which we should judge that they stood greatly in need.
The regular meeting of the Central Organization of the German-American Independent Association was held last evening at Beethoven Hall, on East Fifth street, Oswald Ottendorfer presiding.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 19. John Clark, the murderer of John Trovor, was banged in the jailyard here at 11 o'clock this morning. He slept a little last night and ate a hearty breakfast this morning. He conversed with those about him with apparent unconcern, and when the time came for the execution marched to the scaffold with steady steps, smoking a cigar.

LONDON, Nov. 19. A special telegram to this evening's Pall Mall Gazette from Berlin says that negotiations are now progressing with the great powers relative to the Turkish difficulty, based on the understanding of the preservation of the status quo in regard to Turkey. Tha Seblime Porte has notified the foreign powers of the impending issue of a circular detailing the reforms it proposes, and stating the guarantees offered for their execution.

We go on to-day with a very disagreeable task, but one which it is absolutely necessary to perform, and which has been too long neglected. It is the exposure of two rascals known as J.H. C.M, GOODSELL, who have been making use of the press in this City for purposes which are destructive at once of the safety and honor of the community.

The fifth day of the Garnier tournament was opened with a game between Albert Garnier and Maurice Daly. The attendance was first-rate for an afternoon's performance, several ladies occupying seats on the stage. These was considerable money invested on this game, the odds being slightly in favor of Garnier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. The Collectors of Customs at Boston, New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, San Francisco, and New-Orleans have been directed by the Secretary of the Treasury to reduce the working expenses of their respective Customhouses fifteen per cent, the reduction to begin Dec. 1. The manner of reduction is left to the Collectors.

On last Tuesday night a gang of burglars forced an entrance into the cigar store of Edward J. Sweetser, No. 590 Third avenue, and carried off the entire stock of the establishment, consisting of cigars, tobacco, and cigarettes, and several articles of wearing apparel, valued in all at $300.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 19. The morning session of the Convention of the American Institute of Architects was devoted to executive business, the features of which were the discussion of the system of contracts, and amendments to the by-laws. On the opening of the doors. Mr. John R. Nierusee read "Some Observations on the Apartment Houses of Vienna," which was received with much interest by the convention, and referred to the Publication Committee.

Senator Booth presided, and the witnesses were examined by Mr. Davenport, Counsel for the committee. President Salem H. Wales, of the Dock Department, was the first witness called.

Boardman Smith appeared to make a statement, as he had acted as counsel for the State in the Chemung Canal claims heard in 1869. Judge Brooks called on him and asked him to appear for the State.

Capt. BURTON does not intend to permit geographical facts to interfere with his systematic depreciation of the late Capt. SPEKE, who committed the capital crime of proving that there was a large African lake where BURTON insisted that there was only a collection of marshy ponds.

NEW-YORK, Nov. 19. The bark Svalen, (Norwegian,) before reported spoken Nov. 7, dismasted, , which arrived at Baltimore to-day from Copenhagen, was struck by lightning Nov. 5, in latitude 36 , longitude 71 30', and had her forerigging, bowsprit, maintopgallantmast and mizzentopmast carried away.

The proceedings on the part of the principal creditors to throw Vyse Co., straw goods, of No. 537 Broadway, who failed last June, into bankruptcy having been successful, an expert for the creditors has prepared a statement of the claims against the firm.

The "Eastern Question" is maturing very rapidly. Some three weeks ago the Russian Government brought public attention in Europe "back with a wrench to the old ways of Muscovite diplomacy" by a somewhat startling manifesto in the form of an article in the Official Gazette.

Capt. Ira L. Beebe, of Howitzer Battery, Brooklyn, has received a commission of Brevet Colonel for gallant and meritorious services during the war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. Ron. John Eaton, Commissioner of Education, has completed his annual report for the year 1875. It contains the usual abstracts of the reports of several State and City Superintend lits and other educational publications, together with increased tables of statistics, coming as replies to inquiries addressed to various State and city educational officers and institutions, throughout the country.

Davenport, counsel to the committee, conducted the examination of the witnesses.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20. Public interest in the whisky trials has not abated. Quite a flutter was created this morning, just after court met, by the entry of the Grand Jury with the announcement that they had found a batch of fresh indictments. Great curiosity is evinced to know who the parties are. It is certain that two of the indictments are against William McKee, and two against ex-Collector "Con." Maguire.

The fifth competition for the Luther Badge took place at Creedmoor yesterday morning at 11 o'clock. There were only five entries, and as the weather foreboded rain, the several ranges were rapidly shot over, and the match was completed before 1 o'clock. The wind blew lightly from the south-east across the line of fire, but not with sufficient force to interfere with the marksmen.

He cannot see that it is involved in the freedom of our institutions that our eating should be both bad and dear; but he is obliged to admit that it is so, particularly at our hotels and restaurants. SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 20.--The Pacific Mail steamer China, from Hong Kong via Yokohama, arrived at this port to-day.
Six Italians were arrested yesterday in NewOrleans for passing counterfeit nickels, and imprisoned.

James Russell, charged with passing a counterfeit $20 greenback, had a further examination yesterday, before United States Commissioner Osborn, and was able to await the action of the Grand Jury, aud committed in default of $500 bail.
The Post Office deposits of the week past are as follows: November 15, $8,300; 16th, $9,100; l7th, $10,100; 18th, $9,400: 19th, $9,300; 20th, $11,300; total, $57,500.

A few weeks ago the Bishop of Manchester, in a speech delivered in England, attempted to destroy a theory which is held by a large section of anthropologists. Advocates of the strict and literal interpretation of the Genesis, insist that the first man was a perfect being, and consequently they are forced to accept the inference that the race has degenerated.

People have been accustomed to consider the Count of CHAMBORD, otherwise HENRY V., of France, as the most ridiculous of royal pretenders. His mediaval notions and highflown sentiment have amused the world whenever he has had occasion to open his month.

A grand fair, under the auspices of Hebrew citizens, will open at Gilmore's Garden on Dec. 6, in aid of the Mount Sinai Hospital, on Lexington avenue. The foral features of the fair will be peculiarly beautiful. The entertainment is under the superintendence of Hon. Emanuel B. Hart, Chairman of the Working Committee of the Hospital.
Thomas Moore was held in $1,000 bail yesterday by Justice Kilbreth, at the Washington Place Police Court, to answer a charge of keeping a policy shop at No. 48 First Street.

If Congress sincerely desires to practice economy at the next session, we recommend it to pay attention to the appropriations for public buildings. Few persons who have not had occasion to look into the expenditures on this account have any correct idea of the sum which they annually amount to. The Government has fallen into the habit of unjustifiable extravagance, and there can never be a more appropriate time to correct it than the present.

Yesterday was the anniversary of the execution of Marie Antoinette. From 7 in the morning until noon there were in the Chapel Expiatoire masses performed for the repose of that poor proud soul, so cruelly tried and humiliated here, but for eighty-two years comforted by infinite love and pity--sheltered in "the bosom of her Father and her God." The the bosom of her Father and her God."

LONDON, Nov. 20. The recent gales around the coasts of Great British have been terribly destructive of life and property. Lloyd's agent at Dover telegraphs that it is believed thirteen vessels foundered in the Downs during the storm last night, and that forty or fifty lives were lost. It is estimated that five or six hundred vessels of all sorts are now anchored in the Downs, off Deal, waiting for fair weather.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. The Board of Naval Officers, composed of Capt. William G. Temple, Commander Richard W. Meade, and Civil Engineer B.F. Chandler, appointed by the Secretary of the Navy to inquire into the advisability of disposing of a portion of the site occupied by the Brooklyn Navy-yard to the City of Brooklyn for market purposes have reported against such action.
Street pianos and organs have been prohibited in the town of Lilie as being inimical to the maintenance of public order and morality.

There can be no doubt that the trade of black-mailing is carried on in this City to an extent little imagined, even by those who are in a position to know many of the secrets of social and public life. Most of us have heard of stories of men or women generally men who have become involved in some scandal which they are anxious to conceal from the world.

The first game yesterday afternoon in the Garnier tournament was between George Slosson and A.P. Rudolphe. The betting was largely in favor of the former. Though Slosson won the lead he showed miserable play during the first few innings, five naughts falling to him in succession. In his tenth inning he played better, and soon secured a run of 39 caroms. This he supplemented with one of 27.

Connecticut has lost by death an able citizen who has done her and the nation much service. Orris S. Ferry, a member of the United States Senate, died at Norwalk, yesterday afternoon. He was a native of Connecticut, having been born in Bethel Aug. 15, 1823. He was graduated at Yale College in 1844, studied law, and was admitted to the Bar in 1846.

One of the latest changes in the buildings of New-York is the demolition, just completed, of a structure which was at one time one of the most notorious in the City. On the south-west corner of Broadway and Houston street is to be erected a five-story building, 50 by 100 feet, designed for mercantile purposes, and to be first-claas in all respects.

The swarms of foreigners who will come to see the Centennial International Exhibition will be thunderstruck at the enormous amount of space inclosed. Other expositions have been limited to a single building, but at philadelphia the excellent plan in vogue at the State fairs of having different structures according to a broad classification has been most sensibly adopted.

Two unusual circumstances marked the result of the recent election in Niagara County. A Democratic Sheriff was elected, and the county gave a majority of 294 for the Democratic State ticket. None but Republican Sheriffs have ever before held office here, since the rise of that party, and only once before has the county gone Democratic.

The political campaign which is just opening in New-Hampshire is perhaps the most important the people of that State have ever known. The Judiciary needs reforming, for the outrageous tinkering which it underwent at the hands of the Democratic Party, during its short term of supremacy, has wofully impaired the efficient administration of justice.

Coroner Woltman yesterday afternoon held an inquest in the case of James H. Hallock, aged fifty-four years, a resident of Scotch Plains, N.J., who died on Saturday at the Homeopathic College, corner of Twenty-third street and Third avenue, from inhalation of ether while undergoing an operation by the hands of Prof. William Tod Helmuth, as already published in THE TIMES.

KINGSTON, Jam., Nov. 13.--The new Government bank at Port-au-Prince is not likely to last long. The Haytian capitalists who were to contribute largely to the investment with which the bank was to start, have failed to carry out their engagements, stating that their resources now are not what they were when the promise was made.
Mr. Henry Neville has again been compelled, through indisposition, to relinquish for a time his professional duties, but it is hoped that he will soon find in rest a complete restoration to health.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--Vice President Henry Wilson died this morning at 7:20 o'clock. A meeting of the creditors of J.B. Ford Co., publishers, of No. 27 Park place, was held yesterday at the office of Isaiah T. Williams, Register in Bankruptcy, No. 4 Warren street. In the papers submitted by the firm the total liabilities are placed at $226,025. Sixty-one creditors proved their debts, and of these fifty-nine were present.
Lord Houghton will be tendered a reception by the members of the Union League Club, at their club-room, this evening.

The Union League Club extended a cordial welcome and reception to Lord Houghton in the theatre of the club-house last evening in the presence of a select body of some three hundred members and a few invited guests. The entrance to the theatre was draped with the British and United States flags.

The trial of McDONALD, formerly Supervisor of Internal Revenue for the St. Louis District has been conducted with great ability. The jury were impaneled on Monday of last week. On that day the District Attorney read the indictment to the jurymen, charging McDONALD with conspiring to defraud the revenue; he then opened for the prosecution. The case for the Government was closed on Friday, after the production of abundant proof against McDONALD.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 23. Col. Benson. of the First Regiment. National Guard of Pennsylvania, has offered the services of his command to the authorities of this city as an escort to the remains of the late Vice President during the stay or passage through Philadelphia of the funeral cortege. The official report of the proceedings at the last session of the American Philological Association shows that the purpose of that body in appointing a committee to take into consideration a reform of the spelling of the English language, is far less alarming and much more reasonable, than it at first appeared to be.

Mr. Wheeler H. Peckham has served notice of trial for the December Term upon Mr. John McKeon, counsel for Peter B. Sweeny in the suit brought to recover the $6,000,000 alleged to have been stolen by the Ring.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 23. The schooner Chenango, with a cargo of iron, has been wreeked on Grand Island, in Lake Superior. The crew narowly escaped with their lives. The schooner Wayne, with a cargo of lumber, for Chicago, is ashore at Ausable, Lake Huron. The schooner Iroquois, with a cargo of coal, is ashore at Manistee, and will probably be a total loss.

The most destructive conflagration that has visited this City for months occurred last evening, involving the complete destruction of an extensive brewery and several tenement-house adjoining. The fire broke out a few minutes past 5 o'clock on the second floor of the brewery of David Jones, in Sixth street, near Avenue C, and is supposed to have been causes by an explosion of gas.

The contestants were Cyrille Dion and Maurice Daly, champion, and besides the emblem there was a stake of $1,000 involved. The championship emblem was originally won by Maurice Vignaux, at the Delaney tournament of last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--Under orders issued to-day Supervisor Sewell, of the Internal Revenue, will go from Boston to New-York, and Supervisor Foulke, of San Francisco, will take charge of the Boston district. These changes are for the purpose of securing rotation of Supervisors, which is considered useful to the service.
There is a rumor going about that the Marquis of Bute intends to rejoin the Anglican communion.

Mr. William B. Astor, after an illness of only a few days, died at his residence in this City yesterday at 9:30 A.M., aged eightytwo years. Mr. Astor was in his usual good health, except for a slight cold, until Saturday of last week. On that morning his cold began to trouble him and occasioned a severe cough.

LONDON, Nov. 24. The Morning Post of to-day gives prominence to the following: "Right Hon. George Ward Hunt will resign his position as First Lord of the Admiralty, and will probably be succeeded by Right Hon. Lord Henry G.C. Gordon Lennox, at present member of Parliament for Chichester and First Commissioner of Works. This step will render necessary the re-election of Lord Lennox as a member of Parliament."

The Senate Committee, having on Tuesday terminated its inquiry into the management of the Dock Department, and the condition of the City's piers and bulkheads, yesterday turned its attention to the Fire Department matters. Senators Booth and Bradley were present, and Mr. Davenport, as counsel for the committee, conducted the examination.

Rumored Criminal Indictments by the Grand Jury. There are rumors about town that the Grand Jury have brought criminal indictments against the editor and proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, based on the charges made by Mr. JAMES T. KING. Our reporter called at the District Attorney's office, but was denied information on the subject.
The Ontario Legislature met at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and elected R.M. Wells Speaker. The Lieutenant Governor announced that he would deliver the speech to-day.
Nine Congressional districts in Pennsylvania, in which Democrats were elected to Congress last year, gave Republican majorities at the recent State election.

A laborer in one of the manufacturing districts of England recently offered his wife for sale to the highest bidder. She was sold to a young man for the sum of four pence, and the matter was duly settled in a written agreement, signed by attesting witnesses. The woman, who is thirty years old, persists in carrying out the contract.

In this case, which is one in involuntary bankruptcy, the petition was filed on the 25th of February, 1875. An order to show cause was issued on the same day, returnable on the 6th of March.

There has hitherto always existed a marked difference between promises made by a lover before marriage and those made by him while actually undergoing that process. The latter have been universally regarded as forming part of a contract capable of being enforced or abrogated by the courts.

Yesterday I went out to Versailles to take a look at the Deputies after their Summer vacation. Dr. Von Bulow's seventh concert at Chickering Hall took place last evening. The eminent pianist played Raff's concerto in C minor Opus 185; Weber's polonaise in E. set by Liszt and "Ricordanza" and "Venezia e Napoll, two of Liszt's minor compositions. This programme can fairly be accounted one of the most effective Dr. Von Bulow has as yet interpreted.

A commission de lunatico inquirendo, appointed to inquire as to the sanity of William Vandeberg, of Newtown, who some time since attempted to murder his wife and commit suicide by cutting his own throat, met at the Queens County Jail yesterday and pronounced him insane.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 1. The Rowing Association of American Colleges concluded its sixth aunual convention at the Massasoii House, in this city, at 5 o'clock P.M. today, having failed to accomplish the most important object of the meeting, namely, the choice of a course for the next regatta.

The reduction made in the salaries of the Custom-house employes to cover the deficit in the appropriation of Congress to defray the expenses of collecting the revenue in this port went into effect yesterday.

For the past month the officials of the Post Office in this City have been unusually troubled by the reported loss of five $100 bills from a registered letter. CANINE SUICIDE. He was born in Springfield and had in some strange way broken both his hind legs. He lingered in agony, though kindly cared for by many who pitied him. At length, one day, dragging his mutilated legs behind him, indifferent to suffering, he sought the nearest pond and deliberately went into deep water until the water en- gulfed him. Unable to endure his misery the poor brute had deliberately committed suicide.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 23.--The ice in the St. Lawrence River is again broken up, and boats are running between Cape Vincent and Kingston, Ontario. New-Hampshire presents the spectacle of a State that has outgrown her Constitution. That document has been little changed since its adoption in 1792. It was an excellent Constitution in the day of New-Hampshire's infancy, but by no means meets the demands of a modern political community.

A recent arrival at this port reports that an abandoned bark, loaded with Oregon pine, was picked up near Manzanilla, west coast of Mexico. Her name is supposed to be the Midas. Nothing is known as to the fate of her crew. The bark Midas sailed from Victoria May 2 for Queenstown via San Francisco and Altata, and was reported sailed from Altata Aug. 10. This may be the vessel referred to.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28. The Mayor of this city, in "official recognition of the beginning of the new century in the life of our Republic," has directed that the great bell on the City Hall and the bells of the Fire Department be rung for half an hour, commencing at midnight of Friday, and that the dome of the City Hall be illuminated.

WORCESTER, Dec. 28. The suspension of James A. Smith and G.N. Smith, woolen manufacturers, is announced. James A. Smith operated three mills in Cherry Valley. Leicester, and one in this city, and in connection with G.N. Smith a mill at Milibury, Mass., and another at Graniteville, R.I. These mills ran thirty-six sets of machinery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. The Signal Service observer at Sandy Hook reports that the bark Gentoo, Capt. Staples, from Calcutta Aug. 22, for NewYork, is ashore off the point of the Hook. She is on a stone pile.

CHARLESTON, Dec. 28. The largest and most enthusiastic public meeting held in Charleston since the war, took place this evening in response to a call to sustain the action of Gov. Chamberlain in refusing commissions to Messrs. Whipper and Moses.

Yesterday was the day fixed for a pigeonshooting match between Hart and Burritt, at Dexter's, on the Jamaica road, Long Island. For some reason not stated, Burritt failed to make his appearance, and his representative paid a small forfelt to Hart.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. The Board of Commissioners of the Canal Fund met at 10:30 o'clock this morning to consider the charges made against Hon. Francis S. Thayer, Auditor of the Canal Department. There were present the Lieutenant Governor. Attorney General, Constroller, Secretary of State, and the Treasurer a full board. The Auditor was present, and also his counsel, G.W. Miller.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. The Post Office Department has received a cable dispatch from the British Postmaster General saying: "Money orders advised on lists from United States largely exceed the usual amount. Please remit 30,000 on account." This unusually large balance is accounted for as the result of international money orders sent for holiday presents.

ST. THOMAS, Dec. 16. The Dutch war steamer Princess Marie arrived here on the 12th inst., from Holland, and left next morning for Curacoa. It is rumored that the questions between Venezuela and Holland will be settled diplomatically.

Since the plea of insanity became fashionable as an aid for the relief of unfortunate murderers, the uselessness of Coroners' juries has become more obvious than ever. Of course, inquests yield fees and amusement to industrious Coroners and jurymen; but that does not alone justify their cost.

(the sum asked for) to $1,163,000, the Board of Commissioners find that it will be not only necessary for them to effect a general retrenchment, but to discontinue what they consider one of its most important and needful institutions.

It is by no means a sordid view of the new year which attaches prime importance to the business outlook. Upon that depends a great deal of the happiness which we are in the habit of wishing each other on such occasions; and upon that, also, however much we may dislike to face the fact, depends, directly and indirectly, much of our morality.

The Troy Press tells an amusing story of the vexatious disappointments which befell a recentlymarried pair. It reads thus: "George W. Pratt, of Pittsford, Monroe County, and his wife were made one just before Christmas, and like most people started on a wedding trip.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--The umpire in the United States and Mexican Commission, Sir Edward Thornton, rendered his decision on the 29th inst. in the case of the La Abra Silver-mining Company, of New-York, against Mexico, which was submitted to him for decision some months ago upon a difference of opinion between the Commissioners.

CHICAGO, Dec, 31.--The important seizures of the illicit distilleries and rectifying establishments on Wednesday have been followed up by the arrest of a number of prominent men in this city, who have, up to the present, escaped being positively implicated in the "crooked" whisky business.

The Westminster Hotel, corner of Irving Place and Sixteenth street, was yesterday evening the scene of a probably fatal shooting affray between two prominent citizens. Mr. John R. Dillaber, the well-known wholesale liquor merchant of No. 49 Beaver street, was shot by Mr. Romaine Dillon, brother of ex-Park Commissioner Robert G. Dillion.

That small boys should run away from home and tell wonderful stories about themselves is nothing new. In these days of dime novels, the mind of youth is too frequently excited by reading of the lawless exploits of pirates and plumbers, and many a boy dreams of arming himself to the teeth with a kitchen-knife, and of entering upon a bloody and desperate career in the back-yard.

The decision in an interesting suit, involving the construction of the Sunday law of the State, was handed down in the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday. The action in question was brought by A. Neuendorff to restrain the City and Police Commissioners from interfering with the giving of Sunday entertainments in the Terrace Garden Theatre, of which the plaintiff was proprietor. E.D. Bassford's Cooper Institute, is the leading house-furnishing, hardware, wood-ware, china, glass, crockery, tin, iron, copper, and silver-ware store on this broad continent. All the wealthiest and most opulent class in New-York make their purchases here, to the exclusion of all other houses not doing the same business, and the stock of silver-ware displayed in Bassford's is something which Tiffany or the Gorham Company do not pretend to rival.

Father Boehm, the centenarian preacher, was buried yesterday afternoon, the funeral services taking place in the Woodrow Church, Staten Island, under direction of the Pastor, Rev. Mr. Relyea. There was a large assemblage present. The clergy was fully represented. Besides the Pastors...

WASHINGTON, Jan.1--12:30 A.M.--No elaborate preparations were made to celebrate the beginning of the Centennial year, but its advent was not entirely unannounced. Many of the inhabitants remained awake to welcome it, and those unsentimental souls that sought early slumber were not permitted to sleep unconscious of the hour. A few minutes...

Americans have frequently been accused of a lack of patriotism and a want of that demonstrative love of country which characterizes the people of other lands. No one who witnessed the scenes which were presented in the streets of New-York last night and this morning could fail to be impressed with the belief that this accusation was an unjust one.

It is a great comfort to know that Siam is to be represented at the Centennial Exhibition. We can endure the absence of certain effote European monarchies, which have coldly declined to take part in celebrating the birthday of the Republic, but we should have felt seriously hurt if Siam had followed their example.

The common disposition to criticise and disparage the management of the American postal system, and particularly of the system as administered in this City, often leads people who are imperfectly informed to question the efficiency of the Post Office and indulge in comparisons unfavorable to its management.

The offices in the City Hall, including the Mayor's, will be closed today. Rev. Dr. Foss, President of Wesleyan University, will preach at St. James M.E. Church, Harlem, to-morrow morning and evening.

WASHINGTON,Dec.31.--Referring to the report of the Legislative Committee made yesterday at Montgomery, Ala., Senator Spencer says that there is no truth whatever in any of the charges of the committee,which consisted of four Democrats and one so-called Republican, the latter being a personal enemy whom he had refused to aid in securing his appointment as Collector of the Port of Mobile.
It is stated that the losses on the tour of the Gye-Benedict combination amount to over two thousand pounds.

BOSTON, Dec. 31.--The Boston Commercial Bulletin of to-morrow will contain the following: The old firm of Gardner Bremer Co. changes its style to J.L. Bremer Co.--a change only in style, as both John L. and W.M. Bremer have been the active partners in the house for very many years. J. H. Conuors, dealer in wholesale liquors, of Haverhill street, Boston, has failed, with liabilities of $70,112 48.

The mortality in this City for the year just closed, contrasts in some respects unfavorably with that of the year preceding. The deaths for 1875 were 30,590 against 28,727, showing an increase of 1,863, which, to a large extent, is due to the prevalence of small-pox and diphtheria. The deaths from these diseases have increased to an alarming extent since 1873.

The Special Committee of Five, appointed by Plymouth Church to call a mutual council of Congregational churches to consider the matters at issue between the church and Mrs. Moulton, met at the residence of Mr. Thomas G. Shearman, in Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning.

The concerts given by Dr. Von Bulow, at Chickering Hall, continue, and the distinguished pianist played, last evening, in presence of a large and unusually appreciative audience. The entertainment commenced with a performance of the same quintet by Rubinstein interpreted at the previous concert.
Thomas Knowles and Delia Conway were arrested yesterday and locked up on the charge of picking pockets.
Surrogate Hutchings yesterday rendered a decision in the John Q. Burke contested will case, admitting the instrument.

ALBANY, Dec. 31.--Fog, mud, and drizzle make up the weather report for this locality, and Albany is trying hard to be cheerful under it. The Centennial year is to have a rousing welcome. At midnight every steeple in the city rings out its greeting, and there will be parades, illuminations, bonfires, fire-works, and other manifestations of public joy. Legislative matters have been almost for-...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan.1--A.M.--This will be a memorable night in the Centennial city. The patriotism of the citizens is thoroughly aroused, and there is scarce a dwelling or business house but what is decorated, and from the windows of which lights stream forth, making the otherwise dull and foggy weather bearable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--Chip Thompson, a rope-walker, fell yesterday from a rope, at the corner of King and Royal streets. Alexandria, thirty feet to the cobble-stone pavement, fracturing his arm and breast bone. The injury is dangerous, but not necessarily fatal.

Mr. Lester Wallack was greatly surprised and delighted by the midnight proceedings at his theatre yesterday. Having been kept in the vestibule of the house, on the pretext of an intended supper, some minutes after the representation had terminated, he was finally allowed to stray into the auditorium, which he found to be brilliantly lighted, though empty.

Yesterday opened bright and pleasant for the thousands who were anxious to celebrate the new year in the accustomed manner. The weather was beautifully fine, very mild for this season of the year, very pleasant for the numerous pedestrians who, in previous celebrations of the day, were forced to undergo considerable personal discomfort before their visits were brought to a close, and very enjoyable to all who had occasion to be out of doors.

Mr.and Mrs. Threestars,a young couple blessed with very moderate means, began their wedded life by taking a room in a well-known hotel, but after some months of felicity Charles Threestars became dissatisfied. Frenchman (with a few inevitable exceptions) must now be a soldier a longer or a shorter period. The "good" numbers now award the short (one year), the bad ones the longer period (five years) of military service. Practically, both those periods are abbreviated, in the case of good conduct and rapid progress in drill.

The Assembly created to conclude a treaty of peace with Germany went out of existence with the year which has just closed. There will be but a brief lull in political affairs in France. The Assembly has elected seventy-five of the three hundred members of the new Senate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--Mr. Springer, of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, the same gentleman who helped to destroy the Domocratic third-term ammunition, by the resolation which he offered in the House, has been looking over the estimates from the State Department for the consular and diplomatic service, and has concluded the cost can be very greatly reduced.

When the members of Congress return to Washington the middle of this week they will have had an opportunity, which we hope they have not neglected, of finding what the people think of their exploits before the recess, and also what is expected of them duriug the session which may be said to be in reality only just opening.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day, the following decisions were rendered:

We can breathe freely once more. Count VON MOLTKE has not been guilty of expressing doubts as to the value of the West Point system of education. We need neither abolish West Point, nor demand of the German Government a formal disavowal of any sympathy with VON MOLTKE'S alleged opinion. We are spared the pain of entering upon a new year under the shadow of the great Captain's disapprobation.

Probably one of the largest and most interesting experiments at stock farming on a mammoth scale in this country, is that which was instituted some three years ago in the then uninhabited region of Kansas, by Mr. George Grant, of London, England. Mr. Grant's estate is known as the Victoria Colony, and is situated in Ellis County, Kansas, on the Kansas Pacific Railroad, 250 miles west of Kansas City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--Senator Cooper, of Tennessee, will, on the 11th inst., introduce resolutions relative to the death of Andrew Johnson, when, as customary, eulogies will be delivered. The committee, of which Senator Boutwell is chairman, have not yet fixed the day for the announcement of the death of Vice President Wilson.
The number of immigrants who arrived at this port during 1875 was 84,544, being 55,793 less than the arrivals in 1874.

Intemperate indulgence in doctors is a vice to which hypochondriacal men and nervous women are occasionally addicted. Its victims, however, have hitherto been few, in comparison with those of alcohol or opium, and no one has though it necessary to form a society to combat it or to circulate a pledge of total abstinence from doctors in every form.
