WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--The public debt statement for December will be issued to-mor row. It is not yet made up, but will be completed in the morning. There may be a considerable increase, but that is not quite certain, as it will depend upon the amount of expenditures for the month, which are not yet footed up.

Mr. Southworth, the Receiver of the Bleecker Street and Fulton Ferry Railroad Company, has already made considerable progress in the examination of the books and accounts of the concern. Mr. Pardoe, who has been appointed the bookkeeper of the Receiver, reports that there is a large deficiency in the cash account.

On last Friday morning Samuel and Ovington Benedict, comprising the firm known as Benedict Bros., reported at the Mercer Street Station and at Police Head-quarters that during the morning their jewelry store under the Grand Central Hotel had been entered by burglars and robbed of $199 in money and jewelry valued at $3,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--The chief and almost the only topic of discussion is the question of who shall be elected to the pro tem. Presidency of the Senate. The office itself is so unimportant that, seeing this earnest contest, one feels inclined to suspect either that there is something behind it or that men have suddenly become unreasonably anxious for an empty honor.

Yesterday was a busy one at the City Hall. The corridors and passages were filled with politicians and laborers, the latter expecting that the new Common Council would pass resolution providing for their employment on the public works, at the former rate of wages, $2 a day. A convention of the Rowing Association of American Colleges will be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to-day, when it will be decided where the next regatta shall be. The delegates were mostly in town last night, and made their head-quarters at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where the merits of each of the proposed courses were discussed until a late hour.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. The preliminary organization of the Legislature of the State was completed this evening, with the utmost harmony, and with a good feeling and unanimity which was in marked contrast to the noisy and confused proceedings that characterized the caucus of the Democratic House last Winter.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. The final report of Controller Hopkins will be transmitted to the Legislature on Wednesday. It is expected to be an interesting and important document in its exposition of the State finances, and its recommendations on the subject of taxation.

Intemperate indulgence in doctors is a vice to which hypochondriacal men and nervous women are occasionally addicted. Its victims, however, have hitherto been few, in comparison with those of alcohol or opium, and no one has thought it necessary to form a society to combat it or to circulate a pledge of total abstinence from doctors in every form.

Bernard Delaney, a lad eight years of age, was found on Saturday night in Forty-second street, near the Grand Central depot, grossly intoxicated. He was taken to the station-house at the depot by a policeman, but, owing to his extreme youth, Acting Sergeant Stewart allowed his brother to take him home. It was learned that a strange man had given the lad some liquor to drink.

We can breathe freely once more. Count VON MOLTKE has not been guilty of expressing doubts as to the value of the West Point system of education. We need neither abolish West Point, nor demand of the German Government a formal disavowal of any sympathy with VON MOLTKE'S alleged opinion. We are spared the pain of entering upon a new year under the shadow of the great Captain's disapprobation.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES is the best family paper published; it contains the latest news and correspondence. It is free from all objectionable advertisements and reports, and may be safely admitted to every domestic circle. LONDON, Jan. 11.--A special dispatch from Paris to this evening's Pall Mall Gazette says the retirement from the Cabinet of M. Leon Say, the Minister of Finance, appears certain, notwithstanding the denials published. The other members will probably remain. A Cabinet council was held at noon to-day, at which Marshal MacMahon presided.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 11.--The trial of Howe Hubbell, rectifiers, was concluded to-day, with a verdict of not guilty. The case was brought against them in May, 1875, charging that whisky found at several different points in original packages, with tax-paid stamps, had been consigned to them for rectification, and reported emptied and stamps destroyed.

The excitement over the Republican Senate caucus, which was high last evening, culminated this morning. The Senators assembled early, in a room at the American House, and proceeded at once to make another--and this time successful--attempt to elect a presiding officer.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 11.--The Message of Gov. George W. Emery was read to the Territorial Legislature this afternoon. It shows the value of the various ores mined in Utah during the past year as amounting to $7,000,000. He calls attention to the necessity of establishing a system of free schools in the Territory. He asks that claimants for divorce shall be required to become residents of the Territory.

The planets in this month present some unusually interesting points of observation, says the Providence Journal, to those who take pleasure in following the movements of these bright wanderers among the stars. Antoine Martens, the proprietor of a cigar store at No. 213 East Twenty-eighth street, during a quarrel last night with Thomas Rodgers, a member of the Fire Department, shot Rodgers four times, wounding him fatally, and immediately thereafter shot himself through the head, killing himself instantly.

A dispatch from Santa Fe, New-Mexico, announces the death, on Monday evening at that military post, of Gen. Gordon Granger. The announcement will cause profound sorrow not only in military but in all civic circles. He was one of the most distinguished division commanders ever known.

The sugar-house reported in THE TIMES of yesterday to be in difficulty is that of Ockershausen Co., of No. 87 Wall street. As the suspension was not admitted by the firm until yesterday, the reporter, while giving the facts correctly, did not publish the name of the house.

ALBANY, Jan. 11.--The annual report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction, presented to the Legislature to-day, gives the result of the ex aminations last December for granting State certificates to teachers as follows: Nine candidates presented themselves, who fur nished evidence of good moral character and the required experience as teachers.

HARRISBURG, Jan. 12. Of a large number of bills read in place in the Senate to-day the most important bore the following titles: An act to provide for the refunding and redemption of the existing indebtedness of counties, cities, and boroughs issued prior to the 20th day of April, 1874; an act relative to writing threatening letters; an act to punish persons for pointing or discharging fire-arms at other persons within the Commonwealth.

Buffet, to the French people, confirming the policy of the Cabinet in accordance with the programme of the 12th of February, 1875.

After the routine business in the Assembly this morning, Mr. Weiant called up his resolution relative to official corruption. In moving the adoption of his resolution Mr. Weiant, who is a young and inexperienced man, took the very unusual course of moving the previous question, which was lost, the vote standing 43 to 68. Mr. Strahan, of New-York, made the first set speech of the session and created a favorable impression.

CONCORD, Jan. 11. The Democratic Convention met here at 11:15, and was called to order by George F. Putnam, Chairman of the State Committee. William W. Bailey, of Nashua, was elected permanent President.
NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 12.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was held here today, 92,512 shares being represented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. The first stage of the amnesty debate will have ended to-morrow. It has been agreed that Mr. Blaine shall have the floor to-morrow morning, for the closing speech before the vote of reconsideration is taken, and he will move the previous question.

The sale of paintings at Mr. Schenek's Art Gallery, No. 60 Liberty street, was continued yesterday, when the finest pictures of the collection were put up to auction. They realized high prices in most instances.

The legislation of the present session has been principally noticeable for its lack of either interest or importance. This dainty little Volume presents in an English version a story of the Tyrol which is of peculiar character and interest. Geier-Wally is the name given to its heroine because of a feat of daring performed when she was little more than a child, at the bidding of her father.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--The Amnesty bill was reported from the Judiciary Committee. Proctor Knott took charge of it, refused to use any part of his hour in debate, or to permit anybody else to speak, and in an hour had lead the Democratic majority, precisely as Randall had on Monday, to an unpleasant defeat. The bill failed to get the two-thirds vote.

The body of the pauper who recently fell down stairs at the Queen's County Poor-house on Barnum Island, was picked up and carried to the hospital, where he was pronounced dead, and was buried, as alleged, with indecent haste, has been exhumed by order of the Superintendent of the Poor, and an inquest held.

Rev. Dr. E. P. Rogers, of the South Reformed church of Fifth avenue, preached last evening in Association Hall to a large audience. Davis.

M. Charles Gounod was lately present at the Paris Opera to witness the performance of "Don Juan." The composer of "Faust." although still suffering, and compelled to carry his arm in a sling, came to hear Mile. Krauss, to whom he proposes to confide the part of Pauline in his "Polyeuote." There is, in fact, a question of producing that important work in 1876.

Among the bills passed was that authorizing Police Justices and Justices of the Peace to take recognizances during trial or examination. The Bergh bill to prevent cruelty to animals by prohibiting the throwing of salt, nails or glass into the streets, was also passed, the vote being 84 to 18.

The first bill that has run the gantlet in both Houses this session passed to-day, and is now in the hands of the Governor. It is the Senate bill requiring that all applications for local or special legislation, during the present session, shall be first advertised for ten days, and in other years at least once a week for four weeks prior to the sitting of the Legislature.

Marks, remarkably tree-like, have sometimes been found on the bodies of persons struck by lightning. MM. BOSTON, Feb. 18.--Charlotte Cushman died at the Parker House at 9:10 this morning. She had been afficted with cancer for a long time, but was better last week, and took a short walk on Saturday last, when she took cold and pneumonia resulted. She was quite cheerful yesterday, but a change occurred at 2 o'clock this morning and at 7 she became unconscious, and death followed at the hour mentioned.

LIVERPOOL, Feb. 21.--The owners of the Italian bark J. Mille, Capt. Del Balzo, recently sued the Inman Steam-ship Line for $55,000, as compensation for their vessel, sunk by the steamer City of Brooklyn off Fastnet, on Thursday night, Jan. 6. Judgment was given against the Inman Company, with fourteen days' stay of execution to allow an opportunity to appeal.
